PROCTEXT.PARA: The PRESIDENT (Senator the Hon. Kerry Sibraa) took the chair at 10 a.m., and read prayers.

TALK.START.PARA: —Petitions have been lodged for presentation as follows:

PETITION.TITLE: X-Rated Videos
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and members of the Senate in Parliament assembled.
The humble petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth that:

The Parliamentary Joint Select Committee on Video Material has concluded that ``Adverse effects upon people, and especially upon children, of exposure to material containing various degrees of violence, pornography or obscenity have been demonstrated''.
The majority of the Select Committee strongly opposed the proposition for a new NVE (non-violent erotica) category, which would have entrenched X-rated video pornography.
All six State Governments have, through their Attorneys-General, expressed unanimous opposition to the circulation of X-rated videos.
We consider the continuing distribution of X-rated videos from the A.C.T. to be reprehensible and to be contrary to the wellbeing of the Australian community in general.
We strongly request urgent Government action to prohibit the distribution of X-rated and excessively violent video material.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Australian Broadcasting Corporation: Commercial Sponsorship
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and members of the Senate of the Commonwealth Parliament assembled.
The petition of these residents of the Commonwealth of Australia respectfully showeth
that the Australian Broadcasting Corporation provides the citizens of the Commonwealth of Australia with the only nation-wide, independent radio and television service.
that the independence of the Australian Broadcasting Corporation must be preserved in the interests of the citizens of the Commonwealth of Australia.
that the introduction of commercial sponsorship or any form of advertising material from commercial sources would destroy the independence of the Corporation.

Your petitioners therefore humbly pray that the Honourable Senators will oppose the introduction of any form of sponsorship or advertising material from commercial sources into the programmes of the Australian Broadcasting Corporation.
And your petitioners, as in duty bound, will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Kakadu National Park
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and members of the Senate in Parliament
The petition of the undersigned shows:
That we oppose any mineral exploration or mining in any part of Kakadu National Park, the Kakadu Conservation Zone, or the Alligator Rivers Region.
Your petitioners ask that the Senate, in Parliament assembled, should:
Halt all mineral exploration and mining in the Kakadu conservation zone by revoking current leases and licences and by incorporating the zone in Kakadu National Park and;

Prevent proposed mining in Kakadu stages one and two by incorporating the Jabiluka and Koongarra project areas in the National Park and by proclaiming the whole park under the World Heritage Properties Conservation Act, 1983.
And your petitioners as in duty bound, will ever pray.
PETITION.PRESENTER.BLOCK: by Senators Jones (from 70 citizens) and Zakharov (from 70 citizens).

PETITION.TITLE: War and Violence-related Toys, Games and Video Games
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President of the Senate and members of the Senate in Parliament assembled:
The petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth, that
1. they are gravely concerned over the availability of war toys and other combat or violence related toys and games, including video games, in our country.
2. They believe there is sufficient scientific evidence to show that these kind of toys and games are educationally unsound, psychologically damaging to children, and socially undesirable.
Your petitioners therefore humbly pray:
That the Senate will take measures to end all trading in war and violence related toys, games, and video games, through either self-regulation by the traders in these products, or legislative action.

PETITION.TITLE: Proposed Pulp Mill, Wesley Vale, Tasmania
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable President and members of the Senate in Parliament Senator for the State of Queensland.
The petition of the undersigned shows:

That we oppose the siting of a paper pulp mill at Wesleyvale in Tasmania. That we are concerned about the environmental impact of the mill on both the forests of Tasmania which are listed on the Register of the National Estate and the quality of the air, soil and waters in the vicinity of the proposed mill.
Your petitioners ask that the Senate, in Parliament assembled should:
Ensure that licences for the proposed paper mill at Wesleyvale NOT be granted while there is any doubts as to the environmental safety of the mill.

We ask that the Senate as an independent body, investigate the likely environmental effects of pulp mills on the Australian environment and report to Parliament before allowing any new licences to proceed.
And your petitioners, as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: The Last Temptation of Christ
PETITION.PARA: The petition of the undersigned Citizens of Tasmania respectfully showeth:
1. That we strongly object to the contents of the film ``The Last Temptation of Christ''
2. That the film is blasphemous, grossly offensive and obnoxious
And your petitioners pray that the Senate take all necessary steps to require the Film Censorship Board to prohibit the release of this film for showing or sale in Australia
And your petitioners, as in duty bound, will ever pray

PETITION.TITLE: Aborigines: Treaty
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and members of the Senate in Parliament assembled.
The petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth:

1. That it be recognised the proposed Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Commission Bill is a public, legal acknowledgement that Australians who are non-aboriginal do not have sovereignty in their own country.

2. That the Australian people are opposed to the idea of a treaty, compact or makarrata between the Australian people who are non-aboriginal and those who are aboriginal, and the Government has no mandate or authority to pursue it.
3. That the proposed legislation and treaty
will damage Australia's position under international law and in any conflict,
will cause distrust and conflict between our aboriginal population (1%) and the non-aboriginal population (99%),
will extend aboriginal land rights, contrary to the wishes of the Australian people,
will not be acceptable to the aboriginal people themselves,
will solve none of the problems of aboriginal people who need housing, health services, education and employment.

That therefore, the Senate reject absolutely the announced proposals for an Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Commission Bill, and the negotiation of a treaty, compact or makarrata between the Commonwealth and aboriginal people.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Violent Television Programs
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President of the Senate and members of the Senate in Parliament assembled:
The petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth, that:
We are concerned about the increase in violent television programmes for children and particularly those programmes promoting violent toys that are available for sale in Australia.
Your petitioners therefore humbly pray;

That you support the Broadcasting (Prohibition of Violent Programmes for Children) Act 1988 which has been presented by WA Independent Senator for Nuclear Disarmament, Jo Vallentine. This act aims to prohibit the broadcasting of children's TV programmes that are violent and that promote toys modelled on characters, weapons or other war accessories which are also available for sale in Australia.
PETITION.PRESENTER.BLOCK: by Senators Cook (from 13 citizens), Hamer (from 13 citizens), Jones (from 172 citizens), Vallentine (from 99 citizens) and Zakharov (from 14 citizens).

PETITION.TITLE: Great Sandy Region: World Heritage Listing
PETITION.PARA: To: The Honourable the President and members of the Senate in Parliament Assembled-
The petition of certain citizens of Australia shows:-That Fraser Island and the other parts of the Great Sandy Region qualify for World Heritage Listing because of outstanding Values
Geological-The World's greatest sand mass and the oldest age sequence of Giant Coastal dunes; perched dune lakes; barrage dune lakes unkown elsewhere.

Biological-Coastal heathlands, freshwater swamps, mangroves, the World's only rain-forest growing on high coastal dunes, ancient paperbarks; 750 species of flowering plants and ferns; wallum; wide diversity of marine, terrestrial and avian fauna, some of which is rare or endemic.

Aesthetic-40 kilometres of coloured sand cliff faces, volcanic outcrops, over 40 perched dune lakes, the majestic Noosa river, wildflower-strewn heathlands, vast surfaces of loose mobile sand, rainforests, crystal-clear fresh-water streams.

Cultural-Evidence of large populations of Aborigines in the region-middens, bora rings, canoe trees, implements and other artefacts; historical artefacts from the last 150 years-2 operating light- houses, shipwrecks.

Your petitioners therefore pray that the Commonwealth Government take action to place Fraser Island and the other parts of the Great Sandy Region on the World Heritage List to ensure proper recognition of the region's international importance and to ensure appropriate management to preserve its unique qualities.

PETITION.TITLE: X-Rated Videos
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and members of the Senate in Parliament assembled, the petition of the undersigned shows:
That X rated videos harm the community, especially women and children, as outlined in evidence given to the Joint Select Committee on Video Material.
Your petitioners request that the Senate should:
Pass a bill to prohibit the registration of X rated videos by the Commonwealth Censor.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Sydney (Kingsford-Smith) Airport
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President of the Senate and members of the Senate assembled in Parliament; the humble petition of the undersigned showeth:
That Kingsford-Smith Airport is becoming increasingly congested and existing facilities are inadequate to handle the number of aircraft or their passengers.

The Federal Government's plans to divert aircraft from Mascot to Bankstown and/or increase landing charges for peak periods will do little to relieve congestion and will place enormous financial and other burdens on commuter airlines and their passengers.
We therefore call on the Federal Government to take heed or airline and travel industry warnings and-
1. give immediate approval for the construction of a third runway at Mascot
2. upgrade existing radar and other traffic control facilities to enable Australia's high safety record to be maintained.
And your petitioners, as in duty bound, will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Bruce Stadium
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and members of the Senate in Parliament Assembled.
The petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth:
(1) We oppose the Federal Government's decision to allow the Canberra Raiders Rugby League team to use the Bruce National Athletics Stadium as its home ground.
(2) We believe that this decision will be detrimental to the major international sport of track and field athletics within Australia and the ACT in that it will . . .
destroy one of only two international standard facilities for the sport in Australia;
use millions of dollars of funds of ACT taxpayers for which no commitment was made in the original 1988/89 Budget to pay for this destruction;

deprive thousands of disabled athletes, athletes from schools and Little Athletics associations, senior athletes ranging from interclub, veteran and recreational to national and international standard, from being able to use this facility;
mean that track and field events of national and international championship standard will no longer be able to be conducted in the national capital;
result in much less frequent use of this fine facility.
(3) We call upon the Government to reverse its decision immediately.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.
PETITION.PRESENTER.BLOCK: by Senators Jones (from 119 citizens) and Reid (from 2,611 citizens).

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave-Mr President, I claim to have been misrepresented. My personal explanation refers to a notice of motion given by Senator Short yesterday and to an article which appeared in the Australian newspaper on 14 January. In relation to the first and second points of Senator Short's notice of motion, I say that the origin of the trip lay with Richard James, the New South Wales member of the Australian Democrats, who suggested to Robert Pash of the Libyan Cultural Embassy in Melbourne that an Australian delegation of parliamentarians should visit the chemical plant at Rabta to ascertain the nature of that plant. SPEECH.PARA: In his third point, Senator Short says that we allowed ourselves to be used as pawns by the Libyan Government. On my return, I made statements in which I expressed my serious doubts about the nature of the plant, particularly in view of its military surroundings and its defence. I showed very clearly in my statements that I was not a pawn of the Libyan Government. I point out that although the Government has ceased to have diplomatic relations with Libya, it still trades with that country. I point out also that a week after I returned from Libya, Senator Puplick had discussions with Yasser Arafat.

In relation to the fourth and fifth points of Senator Short's notice of motion, I point out that, of course, the Libyans stated that our presence in Libya was a sign of solidarity with the country. However, in every single meeting I had with Libyan officials, including Colonel Gaddafi, I stressed very strongly my abhorrence of the development of the chemical weapons arms race in parallel with the nuclear weapons arms race. I described and supported the Australian Government initiatives in this area, including the ban on the export of chemical weapons precursors. I said that I had received a briefing from the Department of Foreign Affairs before my departure and that I would give it one on my return. I also deviated to Geneva on the way back to talk to David Rees, Australia's Ambassador for Disarmament.

TALK.START.PARA: —On a point of order, Mr President, I point out that a personal explanation, which is the subject for which Senator Dunn was given leave, must relate to the extent to which she was personally misrepresented rather than be a generalised debate about her trip to Libya or her friendship with Colonel Gaddafi or whatever it is that she is currently entertaining us with at the moment. DEBATE.TITLE: INCOME TAX ASSESSMENT (SAVINGS ACCOUNTS INTEREST) AMENDMENT BILL 1989

PROCTEXT.PARA: Motion (by Senator Haines) agreed to:
That the following Bill be introduced: A Bill for an Act to amend the Income Tax Assessment Act 1936 to grant exemption from income tax of certain income from savings accounts.
Motion (by Senator Haines) agreed to:
That this Bill may proceed without formalities and be now read a first time.
Bill read a first time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Haines Sen J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Bill be now read a second time.
I seek leave to have the second reading speech incorporated in Hansard.
Leave granted.
The speech read as follows-

This Bill will have three important effects on the current deregulated mess that passes for the Australian economy. The first will be to encourage savings. The second will be to offer small investors, especially the aged and those who have retired, a secure investment with a good return. The third effect will be to assist those who are currently saving to buy their first home as property prices rise or are struggling to meet their escalating mortgage repayments as interest rates rise.

The Bill will exempt from tax the first $2,000 of interest earned by anyone who deposits their money into accounts paying no more than 12 per cent with financial institutions which lend for housing. So people with bank and building society deposits will benefit. More money will be available at a lower interest rate to those borrowing to buy their own home. This Bill will therefore make a substantial contribution to increasing the level of savings in Australia and to ensuring that people buying their own home to live in do not have to pay the massive interest rates currently dictated by unregulated financial markets.
Savings

In December 1988, the Economic Planning Advisory Council (EPAC) issued a paper entitled ``Trends in Private Saving''. It noted that private savings have trended down since the mid-1970s and stated that without a significant improvement in the incentive framework for saving, private saving is unlikely to make a major contribution to the further adjustment in domestic savings that is needed.

Since then, our deteriorating balance of payments problem and ever growing foreign indebtedness have resulted in economists, bankers and business people demanding that something be done to increase the incentive to save. Recently two Ministers of this Government have been prepared to advocate publicly the need for incentives to increase the level of savings in Australia.

Why is it important to increase our domestic savings? Australia is buying too much from overseas countries and exporting too little. Our increasing level of foreign indebtedness and foreign ownership means that we must pay increasing amounts of rents, interest and dividends to the foreign owners of Australian assets and to foreign lenders. If we could save more in Australia, we would need to borrow less from overseas and we could reduce the rate at which we are selling off Australian businesses and land and property to overseas buyers. We would therefore begin to reduce our repayments to overseas lenders and owners of Australian assets. As Australians save more, they buy less and this means that we will buy fewer imports.

There is little argument about whether we need to increase our level of domestic savings. The argument is really about how to do it. The deregulationists and expenditure cutters who determine the economic policies of the Hawke Government, the Liberal- National Party coalition, Australian big businesses, and the foreign bankers who have been generous enough to lend us our foreign debt, all want to increase savings by inflicting more pain on Australians. They want us to use monetary policy-i.e. higher interest rates-fiscal policy, that is, more expenditure cuts, and tax increases in the form of consumption taxes to increase domestic savings. In short, they believe that we must suffer pain in order to increase savings.

The Australian Democrats are not interested in yet another attack on the living standards of low and average income households to wrench more savings out of the economy. We oppose expenditure cuts which enable the Treasurer to gloat about the size of his domestic surplus. We oppose consumption taxes because they cannot be avoided by low income earners who get pushed further into debt and poverty. We oppose more increases in interest rates. We know that many Australians will save more if we give them a direct incentive to save by not taxing the first $2,000 of interest earned. That is what this Bill will achieve. Someone with $10,000 of savings and $20,000 of other income will currently lose money by investing in a savings account at 12 per cent. They will earn $1,200 in interest and pay $412.50 in income tax and Medicare levy, approximately $500 in provisional tax, leaving them with a return of less than $400 on their $10,000 investment. With inflation running at 7 per cent, they lose at least $300 by investing their money at 12 per cent given the existing tax regime.

This Bill will enable existing and potential savers to achieve a real return on the first $2,000 of interest they earn. The limit of $2,000 will mean that people with a lot of money will not get the tax concession for interest above $2,000. For all Australians with savings, but particularly for retired people and the aged, this will be a good opportunity to invest some money safely. They will not need to invest in complex bonds, trusts and elaborate tax minimisation vehicles which may be risky, to avoid the punitive taxes on savings. They will be given access to an honest, secure and simple form of investment.

Last year, the Japanese Government began to take a 20 per cent slice of the interest earned on savings accounts which had been totally exempt from taxes for 25 years. These tax free savings accounts, called maruyu, have been a major inducement for the Japanese to save. Japanese industry has had ready access for many years to a vast reserve of cheap capital. It was estimated last year that almost $US2.5 trillion were in these accounts. The Japanese Government acted to reduce, but not abolish, the tax concession after pressure from the United States Government to do something to increase Japanese domestic consumption. I doubt whether the Japanese Government sought the advice of our deregulationist Treasurer or his Liberal Party counterpart. Japan acted sensibly in the first place to give a tax concession to encourage domestic savings and now under extreme pressure they are only removing a small part of that exemption. Japan was able to restructure the economy without becoming dependent on foreign investors and foreign lenders because it had adequate levels of domestic savings.
Housing

This Bill will also make it easier for those who are saving to put a deposit on a home. Escalating house prices have widened the deposit gap for many prospective home buyers. If they struggle to save something, the Government taxes away their earnings. As house prices increase, they cannot save enough to keep up with inflation in general let alone the inflation in property prices in most of Australia. The Bill deliberately gives the tax incentive to save in such a way as to encourage people to save with financial institutions that lend for housing. This will mean that more money will move into financial institutions which lend for housing. Savings banks and building societies will be able to attract more money at lower interest rates because people will save with them to get the tax benefits. Consequently banks and building societies will be able to pass on the lower interest rates they are paying for money to those who are borrowing to buy a house to live in. Interest rates on home loans will fall.

The Hawke Government and the Liberal and National parties have voted to give a tax incentive to those who are buying their second, third or fourth properties as investments. That is their priority. The person who owns many houses gets to claim the interest payments on borrowings as a tax deduction and can then offset any further losses against income they earn from other sources. The Laboreals can come up with exotic reasons to support tax concessions for property investors. This is the first of two Bills which will give the Government and the Opposition the opportunity to support tax concessions which will benefit those who are trying to buy their first home and those who are struggling to pay it off. The Australian Democrats believe that Australians wanting to buy a home to live in and those who are attempting to pay off the homes they are living in deserve a tax break too. If we cannot afford to help them, why are we helping property investors? Why are we suffering expenditure cuts and high interest rates so that wealthy Australians can buy more luxury imports and Australian companies can borrow more money overseas?

In looking at the cost of this proposal, we must recognise that we can save future revenue on public housing and social security payments due to the increasing poverty created when housing becomes less affordable. In terms of our balance of payments and foreign indebtedness, we will be able to make future savings on the interest repayments to foreign lenders. We can save Australia from increasing dependence on foreign investment and begin to reduce the increasing proportion of our wealth which goes in the form of rent and dividends to foreign owners of Australian assets. At the end of 1988, all savings bank deposits totalled $67 billion and all building society deposits totalled $19 billion. These accounts were of course in a variety of term deposits, cheque, pass book, investment and statement accounts, with varying interest rates. To calculate the possible revenue loss means making a number of assumptions:
First, about the proportion of current deposits that would be attracted to accounts of up to 12 per cent;
Secondly, about the higher rate at which new savings will grow as a result of this measure;
Thirdly, about the number of people earning interest who are already below the tax threshold;
Fourthly, about the level of interest rates in the future; and
Finally, about the marginal rates of tax on current and future savings and therefore what if anything the Government will deliver as tax cuts this year.

Clearly, it is impossible to come up with a precise costing because of these assumptions. In June 1988, the total interest paid by savings banks was $4.1 billion. If we assume that this grows to $5 billion this financial year and about half this amount is paid on accounts that attract the concession then $2.5 billion of interest payments would not be taxed. If we assume that the average tax paid on this amount is about 30 per cent, then the Government will lose some $800m in revenue from interest on savings accounts with banks. If building societies continue to attract about one-third of the savings attracted by banks that would add another $270m, making the total cost just over $1 billion.

The cost would be reduced when interest rates fall and the 12 per cent limit is reduced. Similarly, the cost would be lower with lower tax rates. This cost, however, is less than the almost $2 billion the Government has given away in company tax cuts. It is also less than the cost to the Government of giving a tax concession to Australian companies which borrow overseas and use the deduction on the interest they pay on their borrowings to pay little or no tax. However, it will be money well spent to encourage savings and home ownership, rather than allowing the wealthiest Australians to import luxury goods and giving tax concessions to property investors so that they can pay more for a home than Australians looking to buy a home for themselves to live in.
Debate (on motion by Senator Knowles) adjourned.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Chaney Sen The Hon F.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —Pursuant to my contingent notice of motion relating to conduct of business, I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That so much of the Standing Orders be suspended as would prevent the Leader of the Opposition in the Senate (Senator Chaney) moving a motion relating to the conduct of the business of the Senate or to provide for the consideration of any other matter.
I understand that that motion will have the support of the Australian Democrats and, if that is indicated, I will not need to speak at any great length on this matter.

TALK.START.PARA: —On the grounds that you would have spoken at considerable length if you had not got it, you have got it.

—I appreciate the very gracious response from the Leader of the Australian Democrats. Could I very briefly explain, for the benefit of the Government, which has had advice of this through the Whips meeting, as I understand it, that the concern of the Opposition is that there was a very significant attack on the Senate committee system just a couple of weeks ago. This is the first opportunity we have had to come to grips with that. It is the view of the Opposition that it is extremely important that there should be a clear statement from this chamber defending the operations of what we regard as one of the outstanding elements of the parliamentary system in this country. I therefore commend the motion for suspension of standing orders to enable us to deal with the matter in substance.

SPEECH.PARA: Question resolved in the affirmative.

PROCTEXT.PARA: Motion (by Senator Chaney) agreed to:
That notice of motion No. 272 standing in the name of the Leader of the Opposition, relating to Senate Committees, may be moved forthwith and take precedence over all other business until determined.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Chaney Sen The Hon F.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move: That the Senate-

SPEECH.PARA: (a) condemns the Minister for Aboriginal Affairs (Mr Hand) for his intemperate and unjustified attack on the Senate committee system and, in particular, the work of the Select Committee on the Administration of Aboriginal Affairs;

(b) rejects Mr Hand's assertion that civil liberties are threatened by the operation of Senate committees, that individuals have no right of reply and that the recently concluded inquiry into Aboriginal Affairs policy is a `political stunt';
(c) reminds the Minister that the Aboriginal Affairs Committee has a majority of Government members;

(d) calls on the Leader of the Government in the Senate (Senator Button), on behalf of the Prime Minister, to dissociate the Government from Mr Hand's comments, and from similar attacks by the Premiers of Western Australia and Victoria; and
(e) reaffirms its confidence in the integrity of the Committee system which has enjoyed all-party support for a period of almost 20 years.

In moving that motion, I wish to say to the Senate that I think that it is incumbent on this chamber to defend its own operation and to assert its value. I say that because I think the position is that the institution of parliament around Australia has not retained as high a regard in the public mind as I believe it should for the welfare of our system of government. I think that one of the most encouraging developments in the parliamentary system in this country over the last 20 years is the development of the Senate committee system. As I will indicate later in my speech, the Australian Labor Party, which now forms the Government of the Commonwealth, was instrumental in pursuing the expansion of Senate committee activity, and the Labor Party to this point has adopted a stance which has been common with that of the Liberal and National parties, and indeed I think with Independents and the Australian Democrats in this place-namely, an attitude which is supportive of a system of Senate committees. Indeed, it is a feature of the present Government that it chose to extend the Senate system of committees into the House of Representatives and to provide a very similar committee arrangement during the term of this last Parliament.

What we saw just two weeks ago was an intemperate attack by Mr Hand on the Senate committee system, and I will deal in some detail with what Mr Hand actually had to say. But the fact is that that attack was nearly coincidental with attacks by a number of other leading Labor politicians in this country, the Premier of Victoria and the Premier of Western Australia, who attacked not the work of the Senate Select Committee on the Administration of Aboriginal Affairs but the committee which is looking at the vexed question of the use of drugs in sport. One would hope that the coincidence of these three attacks was coincidence and not a matter of arrangement between the three participants; but in any event, it is a matter of concern that these senior Labor politicians should undertake an attack on the Senate committee system in this way.

I want to focus today on Mr Hand because he is a member of this Parliament and he ought to have been in a position-and no doubt has been in a position-to see much more closely than those Labor premiers the operation of the Senate committee system and the value that it has been to Australia. What is it that Mr Hand had to say? Perhaps before I get on to that I should say that the thing that Mr Hand and those two premiers have in common, as I said in a press release issued at that time, is that all three are guilty men in the sense that they have recently been shown up by inquiries to have matters of government within their administration which had something which they would prefer to have seen hidden away. We know that in Victoria we have had the scandal of the Victorian Economic Development Corporation-a scandal which has cost the Deputy Premier of Victoria his place in the Victorian Government. We know that in Western Australia we have had the scandal of W.A. Inc., which Mr Dowding has desperately tried to distance himself from over recent months and particularly before the recent election.

But here in Canberra we have had the exposure in this Parliament of elements of the administration of Aboriginal Affairs under the Minister for Aboriginal Affairs, Mr Hand, which led Mr Hand to dismiss his own departmental head. It is an extraordinary feature of Mr Hand's administration that the committees of which he is so critical disclosed to him information which led him to dispose of his own departmental head. One could not get a more dramatic demonstration of the importance of the operation of Senate committees than that, and one could get no more dramatic illustration of the fact that a parliament which is prepared to do its job to get behind the matters which are otherwise matters of secrecy and on which there is no public knowledge, in that circumstance can prevent a government from making more serious errors and wasting more of the taxpayers' money. If Mr Hand is so contemptuous and dismissive of the work of Senate committees, it is odd that he chose to dismiss Mr Charles Perkins on the basis of the information which was disclosed by the Senate Estimates committees under the questioning of Opposition senators.
Just two weeks ago Mr Hand attacked the Senate committee system. I would like to quote some of the things that he said:

I think the Senate has gone far beyond, in recent years, the role it was set up to do. You have a system of committees now where evidence is taken, the most outrageous claims are made, whether they be true or not, about individuals. Civil liberties of those individuals are just swept aside, while some senators strut around this country, you know, floating on their own ego picking up these sorts of wild stories which are then able to be run in the media, and people's characters are just absolutely destroyed, all but destroyed in a lot of cases, where the person has no right of come-back at all.

And in the Senate, we've seen some frightful claims made about individuals and organisations in my area, and without really any evidence at all, other than a bit of hearsay. Now if there is a problem about an individual there are proper legal processes, I would have thought, for those matters to be addressed.
And so on. He then went on to refer to Peter Dowding. He referred later in the interview to the Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander (ATSIC) Committee and said:

My difficulty is that the Senate committee dealing with ATSIC, as one classic example, has roamed around the country-normally you're lucky if half of them turn up-taking all sorts of evidence from people, some of it in camera, and now leaking and making statements to the Press, about what they think ought to be done to improve ATSIC.

I would like to pause at that stage because I think that passage, detailing Mr Hand's complaints, very clearly demonstrates why Mr Hand was so concerned about the ATSIC inquiry. If we look at the report which was tabled in the Senate today-a report which I do not intend to debate because I think we will have an opportunity to do that later and it is not the subject matter of this motion-we actually find that the majority of this Committee is made up of Labor members of this Senate. The whole of that Committee found that Mr Hand's Department had engaged in activities which were striking down the reputations of people who had been in policy opposition to Mr Hand and who had been sacked by him from the Aboriginal Development Commission (ADC). We find this not in the minority report of the Committee, but in the majority report. I refer to paragraph 5.48 which states:

It is a cause of concern to this Committee that the leak of confidential information from within the Aboriginal Affairs portfolio was used to damage the reputations of some of the current and former Commissioners of the ADC and that no investigation into the source of the leaked material took place.

This is a matter which is squarely within the administration of Minister Hand. He has the authority over and the control of this Department. He has the clear constitutional responsibility for it and authority over it, yet we find the Committee reporting that a whole series of Aboriginal people of good character who had given very good service, many of them for 15 to 20 years, to successive governments and, most importantly, to the Aboriginal community, found their reputations damaged. The Committee went on to say:
The Sydney Morning Herald article-
which was based on this leaked material from the Department-

was demonstrably wrong and unjustifiably damaged the reputation of the Commissioners. No evidence was presented to the Committee that reflected on the honesty of the dismissed Commissioners. However the article received wide circulation. Facsimile copies of it were distributed to remote areas where the newspaper itself was not available.

Not only were these people traduced in New South Wales because of that report but also, apparently, official facilities were used to traduce these people throughout Australia. No action has been taken by this Minister about the actions of his legal agents in traducing the reputations of these people. I stress that all the members of the Committee, including the Labor members, in paragraph 5.53 of the report said:

. . . even at this stage, the Minister for Aboriginal Affairs should write to each of the dismissed Commissioners thanking them for their services to the ADC and advising them of this Committee's conclusion in paragraph 5.50.
Paragraph 5.50 says this:
The impression created-
that is, by this leaked material, the reports and the sending of facsimile copies of the report from the Sydney Morning Herald around Australia-

caused considerable distress to a number of former commissioners. This was combined with the failure of the Minister to offer any acknowledgement of the contributions made by the former Commissioners, some of whom had served the ADC for a number of years.

I dealt with some of those people who were traduced. I remember dealing with Pastor Ossie Cruz when he was a member of the National Aboriginal Conference and we were in government. He was often a strong and public critic of the Government of which I was part and of the portfolio, including at the time when I was the Minister. I would say to Minister Hand that if he is prepared to tolerate that sort of treatment of people just because they have been critics of the policy of his Department, then it ill sits in his mouth to make the sorts of complaints that he has made about the Senate committee system. Minister Hand should be ashamed of himself and I trust he will follow the advice of the Senate Committee and write and apologise to those people in a very public manner. The last words of the Minister I wish to quote are those spoken in the course of that same interview when he said:

And so I say to the Senate committee, you know, anything they suggest, any proposition they put up-because it is a stunt, the whole thing's been a political stunt-doesn't automatically mean that I am going to accept it.

I think that the passages I have quoted from that report bear out the comment that I made earlier-that Mr Hand's comments are the cry of a guilty man who knew that the Senate Committee would report in a way which would reflect badly on his administration and, indeed, on many of the statements he has made about the whole approach he has adopted to Aboriginal Affairs and to the formation of ATSIC. For this Senate to tolerate that sort of self-interested criticism without a response would be pathetic and letting down the system of which we are all part.

Yesterday we saw the fruits of the ATSIC inquiry which was the subject of such severe criticism from the Minister. It is interesting to compare his allegations with the report, not just in the part that I have quoted, but also in the extensive passages of the report which relate to the issue of consultation. Minister Hand put one test on the introduction of ATSIC. He said that it would only be introduced if it were according to the will of the Aboriginal people. He made a great deal of the process of consultation undertaken by him. That process of consultation involved his visiting many communities and having a whole series of discussions. The majority report of the Senate Committee deals extensively with the evidence it received about that process of consultation. We find that throughout chapter four of the majority report-and again I stress that this is the report of the Committee under its Labor chairman, not a minority report of those who dissented from some of the views of the majority in respect of proceeding with ATSIC-there is evidence of dissatisfaction with the process of consultation. We find that whilst there may have been some broad in-principle consideration of the concept of ATSIC, there was, in the Aboriginal community itself, a sense that there was a need for much more explanation before the people would understand what was involved. Paragraph 4.27 of the majority report quotes from what Dr Coombs had to say about the Aboriginal process of decision making and the difficulty and time consuming nature of consultation if one is to have genuine consultation. The Committee observes in paragraph 4.28:
This . . . demonstrates the difficulty in conducting consultations whether by a Minister or a Parliamentary Committee through a series of short meetings with the object of reaching a decision . . .

At a number of reported meetings of the Committee-and I stress that this is not the minority, it is the whole Committee report-ATSIC was presented on a take it or leave it basis. The only alternative was the continuation of the existing situation which was supported by hardly anyone at the meetings.
So we have a situation where the Committee throws up the deficiencies of the process of consultation. We find that paragraph 4.38 states:
Thus it was inevitable that the focus of some meetings became blurred and that participants' perceptions of the process may have been at variance with those of the Minister's party.

We find that the support that was given-I quote from paragraph 4.39-`was qualified by the expectations of further extensive and detailed consultation which did not occur'. We find, in paragraph 4.42, the Committee reporting:
. . . `follow-up' meetings conducted after the Ministerial meetings provide ample support for three points:
That understanding of ATSIC was not as widespread as was hoped;
that further detailed consultation on the legislation was required; and
that more information was needed on the details of the operation of ATSIC.

We find quotations from Aboriginal Affairs officers on the deficiencies of the process of consultation. The whole report of the Committee bears out the Opposition's concerns about the inefficiency or ineffectiveness of the consultation process. I quote again from paragraph 4.56 of the Committee's majority report:

The Committee asked virtually every witness who appeared before it in the latter part of 1988 whether they wished the Bill to proceed, given their current level of knowledge. With very few exceptions the answer was `no'. Support for the immediate passage of the Bill tended to come from well funded organisations which had supported ATSIC from the outset, for example the Northern and Central Land Councils.
Paragraph 4.73 states:
The Minister for Aboriginal Affairs did set his own criterion for the success of the consultative process, namely `. . . . positive endorsement from the Aboriginal and Islander community . . .'

I am staying right away from the contentious aspects of this Senate Committee report. I am quoting only from those sections which have the imprimatur of all the Government members of that Committee. The simple reality is that the report, whatever its debatable conclusions, bears out quite clearly why Minister Hand had a cause for concern about this inquiry. His reason for concern was that it has exposed the fact that he cannot live up to tests that he himself has placed on the process he commenced.

The truth of the matter is that the evidence as it is brought out in this report simply shows that the Minister has not achieved the objective of gaining Aboriginal community support through this process of consultation. What he has is the support of those few well-funded organisations, in particular the land councils, which have been virtually the administration of the Minister. The administration has not been the Department of Aboriginal Affairs; it has been the Minister's office and those organisations which have been sympathetic with his own private political aims. They are the land councils, which are of course substantial economic bodies but they certainly do not represent the generality of Aboriginal people in this community. What we have is a situation where the Committee's report shows the inconsistency between the Minister's complaints about the committee system not protecting individuals and the Minister's own behaviour and the Department's behaviour with respect to this matter.

TALK.START.PARA: —You have cleared the gallery. There are only three left.

—I did not hear the Minister's interjection, but I am not concerned about it. What we have is a situation where in the late 1960s and early 1970s Labor, very properly set out, to strengthen this Parliament's capacity to contribute to good government in Australia. I go back to the policy put forward by the then Labor leader, Mr Whitlam, in the 1967 Senate election policy speech when he said:

SPEECH.PARA: The Senate can take important initiatives in drawing attention to important national problems, establishing the facts about those problems and suggesting remedies for them. The Senate has unlimited opportunities to search out the facts, sift the evidence and propose remedies on a whole range of urgent national questions.
That is the Labor lead-in, if you like, to the work of then Senator Murphy and others to establish the Senate committee system in roughly the form it is now.

TALK.START.PARA: —Garbage. It is just a way of getting into government.
—It is worth having that interjection of the Minister in the record. He said, `Garbage'. It is just a way of getting into government.
—That was Murphy's real motive. Why dress it up?

—That is the view put by the Minister at the table. He can put that forward as his view in this debate if he wishes, but I would have thought that the performance of a succession of Senate committees from the 1970s onwards would have demonstrated on a bipartisan basis the value of the system which has been established other than the value which has been given to it by Senator Ray. If one looks at the first major inquiry into the securities industry, one will see that it was the foundation of substantial reforms in the operation of that system. If one looks at the major inquiry which was undertaken into the proposed national compensation scheme during the Whitlam Government, one would say that that the Government was held back from an incredibly expensive mistake by the careful work of that committee, which unanimously suggested that the Bill should be withdrawn and redrafted, and which put forward a whole series of reasons why the Government's proposal was flawed.

SPEECH.PARA: The Senate's capacity to deal with policy matters of that sort is only part of the story. The Senate committee system-the Estimates committees, for example, which disclosed the maladministration in the Department of Aboriginal Affairs in the latter part of the last year and which led Minister Hand to act in the way I have already described in achieving the dismissal of his own departmental head-is a further illustration of the value of the work which has been done and which should be accepted by governments as a contribution to good government. I am sorry that the Minister at the table, who has recently promoted an inquiry into how we might facilitate doing the business of the Senate in a better way, an inquiry which I understood has a part of its intention ensuring that the Senate give better consideration to legislation, has expressed the extremely cynical and one-sided view he has today. I suppose that raises the question about whether the exercise that he promoted with respect to the consideration of business in the Senate was simply a political exercise in the sense that it had nothing to do with the Senate, except the preservation of the present Government in office.

The allegation of the Minister for Aboriginal Affairs was in part that no protection is given to witnesses in the Senate committee system. I do not think anyone would deny that any process of inquiry gives rise to problems of conflict between getting to the facts and protecting the civil liberties of those people involved. That conflict arises whether inquiries are made by parliamentary committees, by committees of inquiry, by royal commissions or indeed by policemen. Inevitably in all those systems rules develop which go to the protection of the civil liberties of witnesses and of people who may be reflected on by witnesses. Again, there has been a bipartisan approach to the issues raised. On 25 February 1988 the Senate adopted a series of resolutions relating to the issues of parliamentary privilege and the operations of committees. One finds a whole series of procedures which were established to protect the position of witnesses before committees. The Minister's remarks went more clearly to the interests of those people who are not themselves witnesses before committees but who are reflected upon by people who are giving evidence to committees. The resolution that we adopted in February last year made clear provisions to protect the interests of such people. Paragraph (12) of the resolution of 25 February provides:

Where a witness gives evidence reflecting adversely on a person and the committee is not satisfied that that evidence is relevant to the committee's inquiry, the committee shall give consideration to expunging that evidence from the transcript of evidence, and to forbidding the publication of that evidence.
Paragraph (13) provides:

Where evidence is given which reflects adversely on a person and action of the kind referred to in paragraph (12) is not taken in respect to the evidence, the committee shall provide reasonable opportunity for that person to have access to that evidence and to respond to that evidence by written submission and appearance before the committee.

One can raise all sorts of arguments about the efficacy of any system of reply or response. One can, on the other hand, as the Minister for Aboriginal Affairs has, and most recently this morning on the AM program, criticised committees because they take steps to protect witnesses and people who may be affected by the evidence of witnesses. Only this morning on the AM program Mr Hand was highly critical of the fact that certain evidence was taken in camera by the ATSIC Committee, presumably because the Committee thought that it was necessary to protect those people who were either giving evidence or who were reflected upon by the evidence. Minister Hand cannot have it both ways.

The truth is that the obligation is on committees to preserve the necessary balance between disclosure in the public interest and the protection of individual reputation. To try to escape totally meeting that balance would require giving up the process of investigation. I do not believe that anyone can seriously argue that that would be in the public interest. The truth is that any process of inquiry gives rise to that need for balance. Extensive rules govern the operation of the Senate committees in this area. If Mr Hand, any other Minister or, indeed, any other member of this Parliament believes that those rules can be or should be improved, that is a matter that he can take action on and it should not be a difficulty.

The attack by Mr Hand received widespread media comment. I will not refer to it in any detail, but I think all honourable senators would know that it received extensive comment in both the electronic and the print media. I think it is essential that this Parliament make it quite clear that it has confidence in the integrity of the committee system which, as the motion says, has enjoyed all-party support for almost 20 years. I would be sorry if the attitude which is taken by the Government were in line with the attitude which has been expressed by Senator Robert Ray, that this is a matter which is to be judged solely in terms of its capacity either to elect or not to elect Labor or to elect or not elect the coalition to government. I believe that the parliamentary institution has roles which, if properly filled, enable either side of politics to govern better than it would without an effective parliamentary instrument. My own view is that the parliamentary system of inquiry enables any government to avoid mistakes, to govern better and, in particular, to legislate better.

In the instant case there is absolutely no doubt that there will be substantial amendments to the ATSIC proposal if the ATSIC proposal ever goes through this Parliament. Those substantial amendments will be the result of the painstaking work of this Committee. Quite strong and differing views will be expressed in the debate on the Committee report about some of its conclusions. The truth of the matter is that, as Senator Peter Baume illustrated in debate last night, as did Senator Boswell, it is possible even within the Committee itself to be highly critical of some of the conclusions which were drawn by the majority, just as the majority would, in turn, be critical of the conclusions drawn by the minority. But the truth is that whatever judgment one makes about those differing views on detail, this Government and this Parliament will make very substantial changes to the ATSIC proposals on the basis of the light which has been thrown on those proposals by this inquiry.

The cheap and self-protecting attack on the committee system made by Minister Hand needs to be replied to by this chamber. He should be told clearly, as the public should be told clearly, that this chamber supports the work of the Senate committee system. We believe that with the safeguards we have, which include, as in this case, the Government having a voting majority on the Committee, it is absolutely pathetic for the Minister to have made the attack that he has made. I do not know whether the Minister will take part in this debate. If he is going to take part, I am sure that someone else will have a chance to respond to the comments that he wishes to make. I commend the motion to the Senate and trust that it will be carried with the support of all parties in this place.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ray Sen The Hon R.F.
SPEECH.MINISTERIAL: IMMIGRATION, LOCAL GOVERNMENT AND ETHNIC AFFAIRS

TALKER.NAME: Senator ROBERT RAY
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Immigration, Local Government and Ethnic Affairs)

TALK.START.PARA: —The Government will not be supporting this motion. I must thank Gerry Hand for his comments in one sense. At least they have drawn from Senator Chaney something that I have missed for a long while and something that I thought I may not see again, that is, a Fred Chaney sanctimonious special. Senator Chaney thinks so much of this institution and its committee system that he cannot wait to get out of it. I want to go to an interjection I made. Senator Chaney, as usual, put up the straw man and knocked it down. He was talking about the motive for setting up the Senate committee system. He talked about all sorts of nobility. I was cynical enough to say-and I stand by it-that the origins of the Senate committee system were cynical. They were a way to get the Government.
—On the part of the Labor Party.

—Yes. But I say to Senator Stone and others that what I could also go on to say is that the Senate committee system has evolved from those origins into something completely different. We have seen develop in this chamber a strong committee system, a system that works well, a system that has flaws. One would not believe that if one listened to Senator Chaney's speech today. It is a good system, a robust system, but still a system that has flaws. It is a system whose image is slightly purer than the reality. When we read the descriptions of the committee system in Odgers or any other Senate publication, or when any of us go to primary or secondary schools to give our blurb, a slightly higher and more noble gloss is put on the committee system than maybe it deserves. But I would never support the dismantling of the committee system in this place. On the whole it is the one thing that justifies the existence of this chamber, that this chamber can be proud of. It is the basis on which this chamber can say that it is entirely different from any other chambers around the world. That is the strength of our committee system.

SPEECH.PARA: This motion, however, will not get my support. Because that system is so robust and so entrenched I do not believe that we have to react to every criticism of it, whether that criticism is justified or not. I believe that we are showing too high a degree of sensitivity if, every time a Minister, a Premier or someone else criticises the committee system, we have to waste several more hours of the Senate's program debating the matter. One does not have to be much of a theoretician to conclude that we could well end up by 7.30 tonight not having discussed one ounce of legislation in the first two days of sitting. It is eminently possible.

Senator Chaney's motion talks about Mr Hand being intemperate. He is a bit of a black Irishman; I have to admit that. He says what he thinks. He did not go to a finishing school. He came through the university of hard knocks. Gerry Hand has always stated his views clearly and fearlessly. He has not learnt the political art of saying one thing and meaning another. He has not learnt the art of using vocabulary in a nice, prissy way and then sticking the knife in.

TALK.START.PARA: —You talk about sanctimonious humbug!
—He has not learnt some of the arts that Senator Crichton- Browne has learnt. He says what he thinks.
—Why don't you give a burst yourself?

—If we are talking about intemperateness, a few honourable senators opposite, and maybe a few on this side, could also qualify. I have followed the debate in this chamber, although I have never entered the debate on the Aboriginal affairs issue in the last few months. I have heard some pretty intemperate statements made on both sides of this chamber. No-one has had a censure motion moved against him for that. I have heard some wild and unsubstantiated allegations made that have now dropped out, that are now not being pursued. Yet people were happy to get up in this chamber and fling them around. That is the role of this chamber. But honourable senators opposite should not spit the dummy out the first time they are criticised. They should not come into this chamber and put up pompous motions because they cannot cop the criticism. If the Senate committee system is as durable as they think it is and I think it is, it is quite capable of taking this sort of criticism and in no way being dented by it. Yet this motion had to be moved today.

SPEECH.PARA: The first paragraph of the motion refers to Minister Hand's attack on the Senate committee system being `unjustified'. Minister Hand had to sit through most of December listening to a whole series of allegations and attacks on him in this chamber which bordered on the vicious. Therefore I believe he is entitled to respond. I do not agree-I put it on the record-and I suggest that most of my colleagues do not agree with every aspect of Mr Hand's response in criticising the activities in this chamber and the Committee. Of course, I do not agree with everything he said but I have my doubts as to whether it was totally unjustified.

In point (b) of Senator Chaney's motion he refers to a political stunt. There have been a few political stunts on this, starting at the Estimates Committee. There was no necessity before Estimates Committee E met for members of the Liberal Party of Australia or the National Party of Australia to go out and background the press like they did. They went out and blew up this issue. They went around the gallery and said, `Ah, look! A Black mafia is running Aboriginal Affairs'. When later interviewed, Senator Tambling said that it was to get the press's attention. There have been plenty of political stunts involved in all of this. One thing that surprises me-I do not ascribe this to all members of the Opposition-is that people say that this is a serious matter and that they feel deeply about it. I have seen members on the Opposition side ask those sorts of questions-I am not referring to Senator Chaney but there are others-and they then sit down with a smirk and a smile on their face. These are supposed to be serious issues about which people feel passionately. Yet I have seen the smirk and the smile come out. Therefore I tend to ascribe some other motives to people; that they are using this to advance not the interests of Aboriginals but their own political careers. That, from sitting on this side of the chamber, is obvious of a few of the individuals. Therefore when I hear people say, `You know we're only concerned for the Aboriginals and Aboriginal people', I have to doubt that when I see the body language of some of those people involved in this particular exercise.

The big point has been made in paragraph (c) that there is a majority of Government members on the Committee. I say, `So what?'. If the committee system is what Opposition senators say it is, objective, and that committees assess the evidence as such, it does not matter whether there is a Government majority. Not all committees that this Senate has set up have had a Government majority or a casting vote. When it is a contentious issue, when the fix is to be put in, the real key is found by reading the one to 15 points setting out how the committee will operate which follow the substantive motion. When the Opposition is really interested in making political points, that is when it describes the Government as a majority. All of us in this chamber know that that has happened. It happened over the identity card. Very cleverly, people pranced around afterwards and said, `Aha! We tricked you; you don't have a casting vote'. Of course it happens.

Point (d) of the motion calls on the Government to dissociate itself from Mr Hand. Of course, that would be typical of those opposite where loyalty means nothing. We are not going to dissociate ourselves from Mr Hand. He is the Minister. We will support him. What the motion suggests would be typical of the sort of thing Liberals would do and the way they operate. The real key to this question is in point (e). It states:
(e) reaffirms its confidence in the integrity of the Committee system . . .

I am happy to do that. But I say do not do that uncritically. It is not as though the committee system in my experience here has been completely objective. I have seen people caucus. I have seen people express a view one day, get nobbled overnight and come back with a different view on the committee system the next morning. I have seen people go in to committees with such preconceived ideas that all they do is look for evidence to support those ideas. I have seen people in the committee system not attend virtually any hearing, yet they have been able to put out a 40-page dissenting report. I am not talking about the ATSIC Committee now, but the committee system generally.

TALK.START.PARA: —It would not be true of the A committee.

—I am sure it would not, Senator Baume. I do not know whether Senator Baume has seen it happen; that someone who has never turned up, and quite clearly has never read the evidence, can write an effusive 40-page dissenting report. These things occur.

SPEECH.PARA: Leaks also occur from a committee that imperil the integrity of the committee system. One only has to go back to the Privileges Committee inquiry into the Murphy affair. Not one member of that Privileges Committee remained unconvinced that it was a senator who leaked that. We all remain convinced that it was not a staff member. There are faults in the committee system. They are, for the most part, relatively minor. But let us not get on our high horse and say that the committee system is absolutely perfect. It is as good as any in Australia and it may be as good as any in the world for all I know.

We must be willing to take criticism. We must be willing to cop it as well as dish it out. That is really what this debate is about. This Senate spent most of December dishing it out. It gets one boot back and it squeals. It spits the dummy and says, `Oh, my gosh! We must have a motion on this. We must protect it'. This committee system will endure with or without these types of motions.

I do not have much more to say on this matter. I think Senator Chaney filled in the middle part of his speech with remarks on the ATSIC committee. That is something I am not capable of doing. I want to respond to one or two things Senator Chaney said. He raised the question, `Was there a conspiracy between Dowding, Cain and Hand to attack the Senate committee system?'. We all have our differences in politics, even Gerry Hand is known to have his differences. He has had his differences with Mr Dowding. Recently, on the pay rise, he has had his differences with Mr Cain. I am looking at my colleague Senator Childs and wondering whether he could possibly believe they were involved in a conspiracy; that they sat down over dinner one night and plotted an attack on the Senate committee system. We are not that important to them. That is certainly a rather ridiculous allegation.

This comes down to the chamber's ability to absorb criticism. There is no doubt about this chamber's ability to dish it out but there is doubt about whether it should absorb. I do not agree entirely with Minister Hand's attack on the committee system. I do not think it was totally fair. In his own mind he thought it was and I am quite happy to see people respond to that criticism. It does not justify a motion; it does not justify the condemnation; it does not justify honourable senators wasting two or three hours of this chamber's time on this subject.

I reiterate our attitude to the committee system so that it will not be distorted by Senator Chaney or anyone else. We support it. I do not retract what I said about the motives behind the setting up of the committee system. They were not as noble as he ascribes. These things have a life of their own. This committee system overcame what I would call its less than principled start. It is something that needs to be supported. When I refer to supporting the committee system, I mean that it does not just need our moral support. The committees need to be properly staffed. Senators need to take their committee duty seriously. I conclude by saying-it is not really relevant to Minister Hand-that this committee system is in danger of breaking down. That danger arises from the creation of too many committees in which too many senators are strung out too far. That is where the mistakes occur. We have to think about the workloads these committees are putting on senators and how we can consolidate that workload. Otherwise, if we keep on setting up select committees on such things as paper mills, on Staples, as has been suggested, et cetera, we will overload this committee system. It will then collapse under its own weight because senators will take the short cuts. They will get their staff to read the evidence. They will rely on the committee staff to write the reports instead of doing it themselves. Lack of staff for the committees and the overemphasis on committees by creating far too many represent a far greater danger to the committee system than Gerry Hand letting off a bit of steam. This chamber should be mature enough to cop criticism and not respond every time it is made. By doing so, one indicates a fragility of the committee system that simply does not exist.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Coulter Sen J.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Australian Democrats will be supporting the motion moved by Senator Chaney but I will be formally moving an amendment to it at the end of my speech. I will read the words of the amendment so that honourable senators are aware of what I will be moving later on. We seek to insert the following words between the ultimate and penultimate paragraphs:

SPEECH.PARA: condemns statements in similar terms made by any other member of the Senate or the House of Representatives criticising the Senate Committee system . . .

I begin by picking up several of the points made by Senator Robert Ray, because I think he attempted to muddy the waters on several issues. First, he said that the committee system was robust and that therefore it should take no notice of the sorts of criticisms which had been made of it by Mr Hand and the Premiers of Western Australia and Victoria. It does not matter how robust a system is; any system can be killed off if it receives sufficient criticism. Certainly that is more likely to occur if the criticism which is mounted against that system is unjustified. The motion makes the point that the criticism which Mr Hand made of the Senate committees in general and the Senate Select Committee on the Administration of Aboriginal Affairs, in particular, was completely unjustified. Therefore, it is completely appropriate for the Senate to seek to defend its own committee system. It is indeed politically disingenuous of Senator Ray to attempt to claim that the committee system will continue to operate, irrespective of the attacks which Mr Hand and others have made on that committee system. A sufficient number of such attacks, reported in the press sufficiently frequently, will eventually lead to damage to the committee system. Therefore, I totally reject the claim which Senator Ray has made.

Senator Ray further attempted to muddy the waters by dealing with the attacks which were made by the Opposition on Mr Hand, in particular, and on the administration of Aboriginal affairs during the month of November. Honourable senators will know that the Australian Democrats made a deliberate point of not joining with the Opposition during those attacks. However, those attacks on Mr Hand and on the administration of his Department had absolutely nothing to do with the committee system and nothing to do with the operation of the Committee inquiring into the Administration of Aboriginal Affairs and the Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Commission (ATSIC), in particular. Whether Mr Hand was justified in responding to those attacks again is quite irrelevant to the question of whether he had any justification to attack the committee system. It is a non sequitur; it deals with a completely unrelated matter.

I was disappointed to hear Senator Ray also say that members on his side of the House would place loyalty to Mr Hand above their loyalty to good government. I was particularly disappointed to hear him say that because in a matter like this which goes substantially to the heart of good government, of which he himself has said the Senate committee system is part, his loyalty to good government should surely supersede his loyalty to a Minister in a particular government at a particular time.

Senator Ray also attempted to muddy the waters by going back to the history of the development of the committee system. By implication, he suggested that Mr Hand was referring to that history, yet it is absolutely clear that Mr Hand was referring specifically to the motivation which surrounded the formation of the Select Committee into the Administration of Aboriginal Affairs.

The history of the development of the committee system, interesting as it might be and perhaps flawed as it might be, again is totally irrelevant to the matter of the attack which Mr Hand made on the committee system and therefore should not be taken into consideration in this debate today.

The first paragraph of the motion condemns the Minister for Aboriginal Affairs for his intemperate and unjustified attack. Mr Hand's attack arose historically after the Premier of Victoria, Mr Cain, and the Premier of Western Australia, Mr Dowding, criticised specifically the inquiry into drugs in sport of the Senate Standing Committee on Environment, Recreation and the Arts. I would certainly not imply that Mr Hand entered into any conspiracy with the two Premiers in his criticism of the Senate committee system, but I would certainly say that he took the opportunity to jump on the band wagon and very quickly turn around the attack on committees in general to an attack on the Committee inquiring into the Administration of Aboriginal Affairs. His remarks were certainly intemperate and unjustified.

In my short time in the Senate, I have served on a number of Senate committees, three of which have already reported. My experience of work on those committees is that they are hard working. Contrary to what goes on in this place, party differences are substantially submerged during consideration within committees. Senators are hardworking. In the case of the Select Committee on the Administration of Aboriginal Affairs, I am completely unaware of any backsliding by any senator. I am unaware of any member of that Committee not attending every meeting of the Committee for which he was available. Senator Collins pointed out yesterday that he had been to every meeting other than those he was unable to attend for very good reasons. I have certainly attended every meeting other than those in Queensland where a prior engagement prevented me from attending. That applies to every other member of the Committee on both sides of the chamber.

It is fair to say that Mr Hand's remarks were also politically stupid. They came at a time when the Aboriginal affairs Committee was within a very short time of reporting to the Senate. Through his remarks and his attack claiming that the setting up of the Committee was a political stunt, he painted himself into a corner, out of which he is now having considerable difficulty in extricating himself. On the AM program this morning, he turned around and said that he would now consider the report of the Committee and the amendments proposed by that Committee.

He cannot have it both ways, as Senator Chaney said in a somewhat different context. He cannot on the one hand claim that the Committee was a political stunt and a charade and that it was just going through the motions of considering ATSIC with ulterior motives of holding up or blocking the legislation and then turn around and say that out of this deeply flawed Committee can come suggested amendments to the ATSIC legislation which he is now prepared to consider seriously and to implement. I would go further than Senator Chaney has gone and say that Mr Hand was politically very unwise. It would have been far more sensible for him to have remained quiet at this time; if interviewed regarding the Senate committee system, to have said things such as he would be interested to have a look at the report of the Committee when it became available and would give consideration to the deliberations of that Committee. However, he chose not to go down that path. That reflects very much on the personality of the man in that position, Mr Hand himself.

As I indicated in speaking to the report yesterday, this is not the only time on which Mr Hand has behaved in that way. Indeed, throughout consideration of the ATSIC legislation, he has taken an attitude that it is this legislation or no legislation. He has been unprepared to talk with those who have alternative views. The alternative views which he is not prepared to accept are held in good faith, even though they might be at variance with his views. I think this is a great pity, because what is at stake here is the better administration of Aboriginal affairs for the betterment of the Aboriginal people of this country. I do not think their well-being is in any way served by a Minister who takes the confrontationist, arrogant attitude of not being prepared to take advice from other sources and directions when that advice disagrees with a position to which he has become committed at the early stage of consideration. It is also worth while pointing out that the Committee itself, on the morning after Mr Hand's attack on it, moved a motion of condemnation. That motion was not supported by the Labor members of the Committee, but nonetheless it was supported by the Opposition members and by me and it led on to a press release. I certainly had the feeling that the Labor members were annoyed by that attack.

Senator Chaney has dealt to some extent with clause 2, Mr Hand's assertion that civil liberties are threatened. I point out that, as with the courts, there are a number of provisions in Senate committees which protect the rights of individuals. The right to be heard in camera is one which this Committee used on several occasions so that witnesses could give evidence to the Committee in camera. An undertaking was given to those witnesses that, whilst the substance of their claims might be used, the witnesses would not be identified with those claims. Moreover, where evidence is not given in camera, there is the right for people who become aware of evidence through the newspapers and other media to appear before the Committee and to counter any claims that have been made. Finally, there is the possibility that a person who feels maligned could take action against a witness and the witness would then have to use the defence of privilege to defend himself or herself.

I think it is very unwise of Mr Hand to go down this road. It is quite clear from the Committee report that an article which appeared in the Sydney Morning Herald in May 1988 attempted to malign the Aboriginal Development Commission (ADC) and by implication, as this was about the time of the dismissal of eight ADC commissioners, those commissioners in particular. It has already been pointed out that, as to the article that appeared in the Sydney Morning Herald, not only did it contain information which could have come only from the files within the Minister's own Department but also it was faxed widely throughout Australia.

It is worth mentioning that very early in the morning of the day the article appeared, I had a phone call from Mr Pat Dodson, of the Central Land Council, drawing my attention to the article. I said, `No, I have not seen the article. I will get hold of a copy of it'. The copy of the Sydney Morning Herald, which was available in Canberra did not contain the article.
