It was not until the afternoon that I was able to get a copy of the article faxed down from Sydney, because it was in the Sydney edition of the Sydney Morning Herald that that article appeared. Yet Mr Dodson in Alice Springs had a copy of that article early in the morning. I was told only yesterday by one of the journalists in Parliament House that a copy of that article was also boxed in the journalists' boxes around Parliament House. Mr Hand is being-to use the word I used earlier-sanctimonious about the intrusions into civil liberties by this Committee. At the same time, he is allowing that sort of attack on individuals to go unchecked, an attack which, as I have indicated, must have come from someone very close to him within his portfolio.

TALK.START.PARA: —And which he has done nothing to rectify.

—As Senator Chaney says, he has done nothing to rectify it, and both the majority and minority reports recommend that he should do something to rectify it. Indeed, it is worth interpolating here that the letter Mr Hand sent to the eight sacked ADC commissioners was indeed a very grudging and very mean letter and in no way drew attention to the extensive work which those people had done for the ADC and for Aboriginal people over a long period. This is a point to which Senator Chaney has already drawn attention.

SPEECH.PARA: Clause 3 is merely a statement of fact that the Minister was reflecting on a committee which had a majority of Government members. It is worth drawing attention to the fact that the Minister himself consistently resisted any investigation into ATSIC and that at the inception he certainly resisted and objected to the creation of the Committee. For the record, I repeat what I said yesterday in response to Senator Devlin, who claimed that the contrary was the case. This Committee arose initially out of a motion, which I proposed, that the legislation lie before the Senate for six months so that Aboriginal people would have an opportunity to look at it and make representations on it. Following that, Senator Chaney moved to create the Senate Select Committee essentially to give effect to that process. We supported that motion because clearly it was a good way of proceeding.

I think it is also worth pointing out that the Committee found that, following 24 August, when the legislation itself became available, neither Mr Hand nor the ATSIC task force engaged in any consultation whatsoever. There has been no consultation since that time. To the extent that there has been any, that consultation has been carried on by the Senate Committee. For Mr Hand to turn around this morning and say that he is prepared to look at the amendments that have been recommended by the Committee just seems to me to be a peculiar twist of events when throughout he has both resisted the processes of consultation and attacked the Committee that has made those recommendations.

Clause 4 calls on the Leader of the Government in the Senate (Senator Button), on behalf of the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke), to dissociate the Government from Mr Hand's comments. I think this goes to the matter that was raised by Senator Ray and on which I have already spoken; that is, that the Leader of the Government has a responsibility to the Parliament which transcends his or her own party loyalty. I will be very disappointed if that is not the case, as I was in the Committee, when the Government members did not join with the Opposition and me in criticising Mr Hand's attack on the Senate committee system. I think it is absolutely appropriate that the Government in this case recognise that its responsibility to Parliament is far more important and significant than its responsibility to its own party loyalty.

Finally, clause 5 calls on the Senate to reaffirm its confidence in the integrity of the committee system. I have not been in the Senate for a great length of time but I have been associated with three Senate committees which have already reported in that time. I am associated with a number of others which are still in process and with a number of references. My own opinion is that the committees are probably the most productive part of the operation of the Senate. It is worth interpolating here that I am disappointed with what goes on in this chamber, because essentially we talk to Hansard. But in the committees we really sit down and talk to each other. We talk in non-party terms; we take evidence; matters are debated informally; and we come to conclusions which very often cross party lines. Following the first draft of the report of the Senate Select Committee on the Administration of Aboriginal Affairs, I made a number of submissions to the Committee-they ran to six or seven pages-on suggested changes to the report which went to the matter of recommendations for amendment to the legislation. All except one of those recommendations were accepted by the Committee, and by the members on both sides, as an improvement on the legislation. It is certainly my experience that the committee system works well and it is productive. It is absolutely appropriate that the Senate reaffirm its confidence in the integrity of the committee system.

Reflecting again on what Senator Robert Ray has said-that the system is robust and, therefore, we do not need to defend it-I think it is vital that we defend the committee system against attacks and particularly those attacks which really have no justification in fact at all, as this attack by Mr Hand had no justification. My colleague Senator Powell will be speaking particularly to the clause which we wish to interpolate between the last two clauses. I move:
After paragraph (d), insert the following new paragraph:
``(da) condemns statements in similar terms made by any other member of the Senate or the House of Representatives criticising the Senate Committee system; and''.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Powell Sen J.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —I will not hold the Senate up for very long, but it is important that we place on the record the reasons for the Australian Democrats amendment to Senator Chaney's motion. I will not rehearse the matters which Senator Coulter, as a member of the Senate Select Committee on the Administration of Aboriginal Affairs, referred to in the motion and as the Australian Democrats spokes- person on Aboriginal affairs has already put in the debate, but we felt that it was important to broaden the scope of this motion; indeed, in the interests of the last clause of Senator Chaney's motion, reaffirming confidence in the integrity of the committee system, which has enjoyed all-party support for a period of almost 20 years. It is an historical fact that although the Senate committee system has, on the surface, fundamentally enjoyed all-party support, there have been periodically, and perhaps even consistently, attacks on that system. Senator Chaney's motion focuses on one particular attack and extends itself to two others in terms of the Premiers of two States. The Democrats simply believe that it is important to put on the record that this sort of attack takes place fairly often. Indeed, Senator Haines was reflecting in our discussions on our amendment on the first Senate Select Committee established by the Australian Democrats, moved by herself, the Senate Select Committee on Private Hospitals and Nursing Homes. She assures me that had we had time to go back to the Hansard on that occasion we would have seen many intemperate and unjustified remarks about the potential of that Select Committee to do inordinate damage to one particular sector in the community, and yet, as it transpired, that has been a most valuable and longstanding exercise on behalf of the Senate, a very valuable contribution to policy making in this country, which indeed goes on.

SPEECH.PARA: Senator Robert Ray has expressed the view that this chamber should be mature enough to take criticism of this kind and that it should not respond every time it happens. The point is that we do not respond every time it happens and the Democrats amendment is perhaps saying that maybe we should more often respond to this kind of criticism.

In addition to making a general reference to the comments that Senator Haines said were flying around the place in the early 1980s on the inquiry into nursing homes being set up, I want to refer to specific comments by members of this chamber and one comment by a member of the other place with relation to another Senate committee-the Senate Select Committee on Agricultural and Veterinary Chemicals in Australia. In that debate, which extended over almost a year during the formation of that Committee, many intemperate and unjustified statements were made by members of the Opposition. I have a stack of Hansards and I have been through some press releases that were issued at that time. I would like to begin with a quote from the Opposition spokesperson on primary industry, Mr Bruce Lloyd, who stated:
. . . the Select Committee had the ability to create adverse publicity by fringe groups whose interests were more in line with self-promotion rather than in helping agriculture.
. . . publicity had the ability to damage Australia's reputation as a major agricultural exporter . . .

TALK.START.PARA: —Who said that?

—That was said by Mr Bruce Lloyd, Deputy Leader of the National Party of Australia, on 2 November 1988. I would say that it was an intemperate and unjustified attack on the Senate committee system. In April last year Senator Lewis, in this place, stated:

SPEECH.PARA: If our primary products are besmirched by the sort of inquiry which the Democrats are intending, it may very well put at risk all markets for Australian primary produce.
Senator Boswell, in this chamber, stated:
I warn the Senate that fools step in where angels fear to tread. We are going to open up the greatest Pandora's box in the rural industries that we have ever seen.
In October 1988, Senator Lewis picks up the point made by Mr Lloyd. He stated that the setting up of a Senate committee, which is what we are defending through Senator Chaney's motion:

. . . will mean that there will be opportunities for all sorts of people to come before that committee and give evidence about what is the environmental impact on Australia of chemicals in primary production.

What a shame! The Democrats thought that that is what the committee system was all about-to enable all sorts of people to come before committees and give all sorts of evidence. However, on 17 October 1988 Senator Lewis argued strongly, vehemently, passionately and, I would say, intemperately and unjustifiably, against that sort of process. There are many other quotes from Senator Lewis's speech which I think I should spare the Senate, but basically they revolved around the terminology of a Senate inquiry being a witch-hunt. I refer honourable senators to page 1489 of the Weekly Hansard. Again, Senator Archer, in that same debate on 17 October, referred to the Senate Committee on Agricultural and Veterinary Chemicals as being:

. . . a stupid, pointless and dangerous exercise where there is no possibility of producing a result of any benefit to Australia . . . under no circumstances can I do other than pour scorn on the proposed inquiry . . .
Senator Panizza, in the same debate, talking about the sorts of witnesses who come before Senate committees, stated:
. . . there is nothing wrong with respected scientists putting their case to an inquiry. Respected scientists will be judged by their peers.
But then he said:
Nutty type people, people who are vindictive against farmers and veterinarians, can make whatever statements they like and get away with it . . .

That is the very point that part of Senator Chaney's motion goes to-an accusation that people can come before Senate committees and make unjustified statements and there is no protection for anybody under that system. Senator Panizza, at least in October of last year, did not seem aware of that point and perhaps in party room discussions since then he has been made a little bit more aware in the terms of Senator Chaney's motion. On 19 October, two days later, Senator Brownhill said in the same debate:
Fringe groups will cause problems and their accusations will do a great deal of damage to this country's trade in the future. This will threaten the reputation of Australia . . .
On that same day Senator Crichton-Browne said:

This proposed committee is designed to attract all the fringe lunatic groups that attach themselves like some plague to the body politic of the Democrats. This Committee will do nothing to enhance the rural sector . . .
Senator Crichton-Browne also said:
. . . it will have the purposeful and acknowledged effect of attracting unwanted, unnecessary and certainly undesirable publicity, of a distorted nature, to Australia . . .

Senator Panizza also used terms such as `fishing expeditions'. A little later in the same debate Senator Boswell referred to the fact that he was concerned about how long such a committee might run and how much it might cost. Senator Lewis, who reflected on the question of evidence before parliamentary inquiries, prefaced his remarks by saying:
I do not prejudge the issue.
He then said:
. . . evidence will then be blown right around the world to the detriment of Australian primary production and to the detriment of Australian primary producers.

Those are quotes from only two editions of the Hansard that I have before me reporting the debate on one Senate inquiry. As Senate committees have come under attack again and again and will probably continue to do so, both in this chamber and in the wider community, the Australian Democrats believe that this motion should be extended so that we, as a chamber, in passing this motion make sure that we are not engaged in a political stunt and that we are addressing the significant issue.

This is where we part company with Senator Ray. We believe that this chamber should react, at least now and then, when its committee system comes under attack so that these sorts of attacks will not be made in such cavalier fashion, so vehemently, so intemperately and so unjustifiably. The question of who or who is not engaged in a political stunt is very much at issue in this motion. The Democrats' amendment condemns in similar terms statements by any member of the Senate or the House of Representatives, not just Mr Hand or the Premiers of a couple of Labor governed States in this country. This chamber should condemn all such comments from wherever they come.

As a member of many Senate committees I endorse the remarks that people have made. In particular, I endorse those more honest remarks which point out that not all deliberations of all Senate committees are totally devoid of any partisan activity or prejudice. If we have an exercise in which we, as members of the Senate, can engage which is worth while, where decisions are made on their merits, it is certainly the committee system. None of us is perfect and none of our committees is perfect but it is certainly a system worth fighting for. For that reason the Australian Democrats want to do everything they can to reduce unnecessary, intemperate and unjustified criticism. I, therefore, strongly support the amendment which has been moved by my colleague Senator Coulter and I commend it both to the Government and to the Opposition. If ever there were a Democrat amendment which should be passed by this Senate it would be the amendment to the original motion which, in its last clause, reaffirms the Senate's confidence in the integrity of the committee system which has enjoyed all-party support for a period of almost 20 years.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Cooney Sen B.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —No matter what else we say about this motion, it is a political exercise. I do not say that in a condemnatory way. I will tell honourable senators why it is a political exercise. If it were anything else we would have dealt with it in a different way. I put some propositions to the Senate. Opposition senators and the Australian Democrats have already indicated that they have made up their minds to support this motion. Had we dealt with this motion in some sort of quasi-judicial way and had we given temperate consideration to it, honourable senators would at least have waited until the end of the debate before making up their minds. Can any honourable senator who may be listening to this debate indicate that he or she has had an open mind throughout the debate on this motion this morning? Is any honourable senator willing to say that he or she had not agreed within the party room to support the motion as it has been put or as it is proposed to be amended by the Democrats?
—Are you included?
—Of course. I will vote on two bases. I am a loyal member of the Australian Labor Party and I am a very close friend of Gerry Hand.
—Well you've got an open mind then!

—I do not have an open mind on this issue but that is not the point. This matter has not been raised in an open way. When Fitzpatrick and Browne were condemned and gaoled back in 1955 at least they were brought to the Bar of the House of Representatives and given a chance to answer the matters that were put before them. Has anybody in any party told Mr Hand of the nature of the allegations that have been made against him? Has anybody put this motion to him? Have we, as a Senate, invited him to reply to this motion, or is the position here today that we have made an accusation that we, as a Senate, have been brought into disrepute or have been attacked? Quite clearly, that is the situation.

SPEECH.PARA: We are condemning Mr Hand for an intemperate, unjustified attack on the Senate committee system and, in particular, the work of the Senate Select Committee on the Administration of Aboriginal Affairs. By condemning him for attacking one of our committees we are, in effect, condemning him for attacking us. The only evidence that has been produced has been by way of assertion. There is no other evidence. Having made the accusation and having filed the charge-we have not served it, as it were, on the person accused-we then make up our minds on what evidence to accept without hearing from Mr Hand, without giving him a chance to answer, and we impose a penalty.

TALK.START.PARA: —Justice by contempt.

—It is justice by contempt. Having followed that process we then reject Mr Hand's assertion that civil liberties are threatened by the operation of the Senate Committee. What has been said about civil liberties this morning? I ask those people who are listening to this debate to consider the following scenario: a person is accused of being a thief and of having stolen from a local club. The club, in that person's absence, chooses what evidence it wants to accept and it condemns that person without having heard from him. Senator Chaney laughs at this. His laughter implies that it is a matter of small moment to condemn a Minister of the Crown for an intemperate and unjustified attack on a Senate committee. Apparently, Senator Chaney has said that no notice of this should be given to Mr Hand before he is condemned. Is Senator Chaney saying that Mr Hand should be given no chance to be heard? Would it not have been better for Senator Chaney to have got his colleagues in the House of Representatives to do something about it? Why did he not make an opportunity available for Mr Hand to answer this? What is the point of our going through an exercise of self-congratulation in which we say what a terrific system this Senate has?

SPEECH.PARA: I believe that our system of Senate committees is a good system. People who are listening outside must be very impressed to hear that this institution cannot stand any criticism of itself by a Minister who was-and this is not denied-blackguarded, condemned and insulted day after day, week after week during November and December last year. As soon as he replied, this mighty and august body condemned him without hearing from him or in any way giving him proper warning that this issue was coming on. Where is the sense of balance in that? The minority report of the Select Committee on the Administration of Aboriginal Affairs has been tabled and talked about. Let us see what it says about the Minister. On page 4 it says:

Consultation about the ATSIC proposal has been incomplete and inadequate. Certainly neither the quality nor the quantity of consultation have been adequate to redeem the promises of the Minister that ATSIC would proceed only after full and extensive consultation.
That in effect condemns the Minister as inefficient, as not being a man of his word and not properly consulting with the Aboriginal communities around Australia. On page 5 the minority report says:

As set out later, the Committee heard general allegations of the most serious kind to the effect that the consultation process was corrupted by intimidation, coercion, enticements and stand-over tactics. The Committee has also received a list of funding `commitments' entered into during the course of the Minister's first-round consultations.

The inference is that this Minister has been in some way connected with intimidation, coercion, enticements and standover tactics. That is a fairly serious allegation which I, for one, would have thought a person would be entitled to answer. It is an allegation which might rouse in the mind and heart of any reasonable person feelings of outrage and which might lead to a response. The Minister was condemned in these strong terms and he made a response, then this fair minded chamber condemned him again without giving him any chance to answer the allegations made against him. Why is it all right for this Senate to condemn, blackguard and call for the resignation of the Minister time and time again, week after week and to produce, through one of its committees, a minority report by two very senior senators which condemns this man, but it is not all right for him to defend himself? If that is the way this chamber considers fairness should be dispensed then we have something to worry about. Where is the test of natural justice? That test should consist of two elements-bringing an unbiased mind to considerations of the matter and hearing the other side. How can we say we have looked at this motion with an unbiased mind, when members of the Opposition and the Australian Democrats have on their own admission come here already prepared to pass this motion condemning a senior Minister of the Crown, a man who has struggled hard over the years?

TALK.START.PARA: —He is a junior Minister.

—I want to take up that point. I called Mr Hand a senior Minister of the Crown. Senator Chaney then properly corrected me and said that he was a junior Minister of the Crown which is absolutely right. By that, I take Senator Chaney to mean that had Mr Hand been a senior Minister of the Crown a bit of natural justice would have been applied, but since he is a junior Minister the motion is all right. In other words, natural justice is only for those who have a certain status in life. Otherwise why did Senator Chaney go out of his way to correct me?

SPEECH.PARA: I would just like to say something general about certain bodies-not only the Senate and Senate committees-which can cause great damage to people and organisations through their proceedings and reports because they possess absolute privilege. This chamber and its committees have absolute privilege. But the problems go beyond that. That absolute privilege extends to courts, royal commissions, judicial inquiries, parliaments and parliamentary committees and a whole string of people have been affected by their actions. Most recently there was the case of the Queensland ministry which unintentionally was unjustly blackguarded and unjustly put at risk of disrepute by people-or a person in particular-speaking under privilege. Those Ministers had to swear statutory declarations and try to redeem their reputation. In my view, members of the Ahern Government were most grossly dealt with. Similarly, when Kerry Packer was named, he had to make a chase to redeem his reputation. Mr Justice Murphy went through the same difficulties because of the actions of bodies which have absolute privilege. I adhere to the view that there must be provision for absolute privilege for the good of the community. There must be the opportunity for open debate, for the exchange of views and for good, vigorous and proper discussion of matters. But because of the tragedy and injury that bodies with absolute privilege can visit on people, these bodies should act with fairness-and fairness includes hearing both sides of the argument and bringing an unbiased--

TALK.START.PARA: —Perhaps Senator Cooney should bring the Minister to the Bar of the Senate.

—Senator Chaney suggests that we bring Mr Hand to the Bar of the Senate. I suggest that the least we should do is rephrase this motion so that it reads, for example, `that the Minister for Aboriginal Affairs, Mr Hand, be invited to respond to allegations that he has made an intemperate and unjustified attack on the Senate committee system'. At least that would provide the Minister with the chance of being heard. If we do not do that, do we proceed on party political lines? It will be demonstrated that this body, which is said to be so fair minded, august and elevated, has proceeded on party political lines when the vote is taken. Every member of the Opposition and the Australian Democrats will be on one side and every member of the Government will be on the other side. Yet, we will go to the public and say, `Well, this Senate has considered this motion in a dispassionate and unpolitical way'. How does that stand up?
—It will be a nonsense.
—It will be a nonsense. It will be reported, as it should be, that votes were taken along party lines. What does that do for the reputation and the standing of this chamber?

SPEECH.PARA: A report was prepared on the ATSIC legislation and a dissenting report was made by Senator Coulter which was separate from the main body of actions. There was a strong attack on the Minister. The Minister anticipated that attack and made a strong attack in response. In that political scene this Senate purports to be outraged and offended to the point where it now has to pass a motion condemning the Minister for Aboriginal Affairs. It will take that action on a political basis but it will pretend-and this is where the vice rests-that it did so on a judicious, fair minded and considered basis. That is just not true. That is the problem and the vice we are facing. The reality is one thing; the pretence is another. If we simply said `Look, we are trying to get Mr Hand. He is on the run and has been for a while. We have had him and his Department under attack and this is another tactical advance in the area', that would be one thing. But for heaven's sake, do not let us pretend for one minute that this motion is put forward in any way other than a most political manner.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Baume Sen The Hon P.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —Senator Cooney has just mounted a defence of the Minister for Aboriginal Affairs (Mr Hand) on very spurious grounds. First, he accused us of engaging in a political and not a judicial process. Of course, he was quite correct. I say to my legal colleague that this is not a court and that the processes which he set out as being desirable are processes which would apply in a court action but have never been applied here and are not appropriate in the Senate. This is a political chamber so any decision taken here is political. If that is what Senator Cooney is criticising, what should we conclude from that criticism?

SPEECH.PARA: It is more important that we ask ourselves whether, in exercising that political judgment, we are behaving fairly. Here, I have to say that Senator Cooney did not set out for the Senate the entirety of the argument before us. He did not tell us that several weeks ago, when Mr Hand attacked two Senate committees and the Senate committee system in general, he did not deal with us as Senator Cooney would now have us deal with Mr Hand. Several weeks ago Mr Hand did not give to us any statement of the charge he laid against us. He gave us no chance to hear his evidence. We were not invited to respond in any way. In short, Mr Hand behaved exactly as Senator Cooney would now criticise us for behaving, and there was not a word from Senator Cooney to draw that to our attention.

When Mr Hand made his attack the first question that arose was whether possibly a question of privilege was involved. Of course it was not, for a number of reasons, not least of which was that there is no question of privilege as between members of the different Houses. We did not pursue it on that basis. But why did Mr Hand attack the Senate Select Committee on the Administration of Aboriginal Affairs so vehemently, so unexpectedly, so unreasonably and without any notice to the Committee? Why did he do it as he did and when he did? The reason is that Mr Hand feared the Committee's findings.

TALK.START.PARA: —He was trying to lay the groundwork.

—Senator Crichton-Browne is right. He determined to attack the Committee in an attempt to kill the messenger because he feared the message that was to appear. That is what it was all about. He chose the moment when other people had attacked another Senate committee to launch his attack on the Committee in an attempt to kill the messenger before the message was delivered. It was an attempt to launch a pre-emptive strike. It was based on the weakness of the Minister's position on the merits of the matter that was before the Senate Select Committee, a matter in which the Minister and the Government have made no case for the course they proposed to take. They have not redeemed their pledge of adequate consultation. They have dealt shamefully with a number of Aboriginals who were dismissed arbitrarily as acting commissioners. They have not examined adequately the alternative proposal offered to them by an Aboriginal organisation-by Aboriginal commissioners within the Aboriginal Development Commission-and they have acted in an atmosphere where there have been very serious and difficult allegations.

SPEECH.PARA: However, Mr Hand then went ahead and widened his attack into one on Senate committees in general. He made a personal attack upon senators by trying to talk about the way they worked, saying that he thought the Senate had exceeded its power and its remit. I interpolate that the conclusions which some of us reached and to which Senator Cooney has just referred were based on the evidence before the Select Committee. That is beyond doubt. The evidence is all there in the majority report; it is just that the majority report did not proceed to the conclusions. We based our conclusions on the evidence. We took evidence and listened to people. The hearings were prolonged. They were, if you like, much more judicial and fairer in their way than the attack launched on us by Mr Hand. Not only that, but our report came down after Mr Hand's pre-emptive attack. We waited some weeks after Mr Hand's attack upon the Senate committees so that we could let our anger subside, consider the matter with some care and come up with a considered motion, as we have done today. For the reasons Senator Chaney will set out in closing the debate, I hope that we will support the amendment and also the motion as amended. That is the proper course to take. I remind Senator Cooney that every one of the Senate committees is controlled by the government of the day. The government of the day has the numbers. It can control a committee. It can determine who provides evidence and the form of the final committee report.

Mr Hand's pre-emptive strike on Senate committees in general is not atypical of governments, and it was not directed just at the Senate Select Committee on the Administration of Aboriginal Affairs. I remind honourable senators that when we attempted to set up a committee some 15 or 16 months ago Senator Peter Walsh attacked Senate committees and threatened to withhold funding from a committee if it was not one of which he approved. If he went on with that line-I am glad that he has not done so-it would provoke a constitutional crisis in this country because it would attack the Senate's right to conduct its business. But it is not unusual for government Ministers-I use the term `government' generically here-to attack Senate committees. They resent the power of Senate committees. They resent the expertise which is often available to Senate committees and to which they can turn. They resent the concentration which committees bring on particular issues, they resent the reputation which committees enjoy, and they resent the effectiveness of committees. Committees are a nuisance to governments. They reveal things which governments would rather remain hidden. They bring detailed analysis to matters which governments would rather have accepted without that analysis.

It is quite inappropriate for Mr Hand, with his record of dealing, to try to claim that the Senate Select Committee did not deal fairly with him. Senator Chaney has already drawn attention to that, but I want to make the point again. Mr Hand is the person who dismissed eight acting commissioners of the Aboriginal Development Commission simply because they would not agree with a course he proposed to take. Their crime was that they had asked a court to rule on the validity of the first ever ministerial direction given under the Aboriginal Development Commission Act. So he sacked them. He sacked them within six weeks of the completion of their terms of appointment. All he had to do was wait another six weeks and their terms ran out anyhow. He sacked them in a way which ensured that they would suffer enormous damage within their communities because people in their communities feel they have done something wrong. It is a malevolent and mean-spirited act as well as being unnecessary. It was punishment of those people for taking a course of action in the courts which was proper and well-intentioned. It did very great damage to them as individuals. Why did not Senator Cooney draw our attention to that set of actions and to the lack of justice shown by the Minister in taking that action against those relatively powerless Aboriginal people?

There was also the story in the Sydney Morning Herald, to which Senator Chaney and Senator Coulter have referred. That story was disseminated widely, probably in advance of the availability of the newspaper in which it appeared. That story was wrong, unjustified, further damaged those people, and drew on official records of some kind for its writing. Labor senators should not talk to us about fairness. It is said that one cannot go to equity with dirty hands. One cannot defend the Minister on this matter in view of that recent record. Look at the subsequent treatment of Mrs Shirley McPherson, the harassment and needling that has gone on and the way in which her position has been made impossible.

We have to say that the attack that was made on Senate committees was intemperate, defensive, inappropriate, contemptuous of the Senate and a direct challenge to the committee system. It would have been recreant of the Senate not to have responded in some way, and specifically in the way in which Senator Chaney has responded.

I say in response to Senator Powell that it is quite proper for honourable senators here to question the setting up of a Senate committee at the time it is set up-to question in this chamber in vigorous debate any proposal to set up a committee. That is not what we are arguing about today. We are arguing about the fact that once the Parliament has established a body to do a job for it as servants of the Senate-because that is what we are on committees-it is not proper for people outside to attack committees in the way in which Mr Hand has done. For that reason it is proper that we have the motion before us today that was moved by Senator Chaney. It will be my pleasure to support it, and I understand that we shall be supporting the amendment moved by the Australian Democrats.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Chaney Sen The Hon F.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —The need to respond is much reduced by the excellent speech which has been made by my friend and colleague Senator Peter Baume. I thank him for that contribution to the debate, which has enabled me to be much briefer. I say, however, in addition to his comments, that the contribution from the Government seems to have been, I suppose necessarily, for the purpose of drawing red herrings, setting up straw men and answering arguments which have not been put, because the basis of the resolution is not arguable. Senator Robert Ray, for example, was vigorously arguing that the Senate committee system could not be claimed to be perfect. That is self-evident. The courts are not perfect, the Parliament certainly is not perfect, no government is perfect and there is always room for improvement. When referring in my speech to the efforts made by the Senate as recently as February 1988 to lay down rules governing the protection of witnesses and of those who might be implicated by witnesses, I specifically made the point that this was an example of improvement and that it was open to people to make suggestions for further improvement. That is always possible.

SPEECH.PARA: I believe that Senator Cooney's contribution has been adequately answered. As I listened to him, I was reminded, following his protestation of friendship for the Minister for Aboriginal Affairs (Mr Hand), of the fact that it is a serious mistake to appear in court for a friend. I tried it once and realised that it was a serious mistake. I suspect that Senator Cooney's friendship has overcome his forensic skills.

TALK.START.PARA: —You should not lend them money either.

—Yes, that is probably so. The case put forward by Senator Cooney was sadly flawed. Perhaps it is important to note that Senator Cooney also put a weight on the Senate which in his speech he did not choose to put upon Mr Hand. One of the less creditable aspects of this matter, and a matter to which I referred extensively in my speech, was where the Committee majority made it quite clear that the eight sacked commissioners had been ill-treated-in some ways directly by Mr Hand and if in other ways not by Mr Hand directly, by his Department. No attempt has been made by Mr Hand and his Department to rectify the wrong done to those people.

SPEECH.PARA: The reference to Fitzpatrick and Browne was part of the endless confusion, if I may say so, of the speech. That case involved people being brought to the Bar of the House on a charge of contempt with a view to gaoling them, and indeed they were gaoled. It is extraordinary to suggest that that is in some way analogous to today's proceedings. Indeed, if one were to follow Senator Cooney's advice, it would be impossible to bring a censure motion in this Parliament. Apparently one would issue some sort of notice and commence some sort of quasi-judicial procedure to examine the facts. Clearly, after centuries of parliamentary tradition that is a sorry misreading of the function of this place.

I thank Senator Coulter for his contribution. I simply add a little to what Senator Peter Baume said about the concerns expressed by Senator Janet Powell. It is a pity that Senator Powell had to use the debate to reopen arguments about a matter on which she felt passionately, namely the chemicals inquiry. As Senator Peter Baume pointed out, there was a series of debates prior to the establishment of the Committee in this place as to the wisdom or unwisdom of that inquiry. All honourable senators will understand that there are substantial commercial firms involved, international and competing firms, and there are people who have vested interests outside this country in damaging our major export industries. The sorts of concerns expressed by Opposition senators at that time were in no way analogous to the matters that we have raised in respect to Mr Hand.

TALK.START.PARA: —The terms of reference were the major substance of debate.

—I thank my colleague for that comment. The amendment which has been put forward by Senator Powell on behalf of the Democrats gives the Opposition no difficulty at all. It is, in its turn, a condemnation of statements in similar terms made by any member of the Senate or House of Representatives criticising the Senate committee system. If any persons were to conduct themselves, whether from this or the other chamber, in the way Mr Hand has done, I think they should be roundly condemned.

SPEECH.PARA: This motion is not a motion of censure; it falls short of that. Had we moved a formal motion of censure, there would be no question but that Mr Hand would have been given a right of reply through his representative in this place. But Mr Hand has-this is uncontested-made intemperate criticisms of the Senate committee system and has been condemned in the news media. I refer to editorial comments in the Canberra Times and the Sydney Morning Herald relating to his comments. To suggest that no judgment can be passed in this chamber is on the face of it ludicrous.

I close by saying that there is one substantial reason why this motion should be passed and why it is important that it should have been brought forward. Mr Hand chose to attack the Committee at a time before it had completed its deliberations. No-one would be in any doubt that political pressures are involved in participation in committees. For supporters of the Government who are members of a committee it is a serious matter to be considering the sorts of criticisms which have been made of this Government and its administration in Aboriginal affairs. For that difficulty to be compounded by intimidatory statements by the Minister is a serious matter indeed. We will have a vigorous debate in this place about the report. The debate started yesterday; it is not to be part of this debate today. But no-one who listened to Senator Peter Baume's speech last night could fail to be impressed by the strength of his criticisms of the findings of the majority. For the argument to be further complicated by the Minister's attitude prior to the conclusion of the Committee's deliberations is extremely unfortunate. It simply highlights the difficulty of committees dealing with current political events or issues in a way which is fearless and without regard to the short term political consequences.

The ATSIC Committee was dealing with a major administrative reorganisation which will go to the future welfare of several hundred thousand Australians. It is not for me to lecture in this place. People like Senator Collins, who has a close personal knowledge of and a working relationship with the Aboriginal community in his electorate, understand, probably better than I, the impact that ATSIC will have, if it gets into place, on the Aboriginal people of this country. For the exhaustive attempts that have been made by this Parliament to subject this proposal to proper scrutiny to be subjected to the bully boy rubbish that we copped from the friend of Senator Cooney, Mr Hand, is to me totally objectionable and quite intolerable.

I am quite contemptuous of Mr Hand's attitude to this matter. Mr Hand has been shown not to have been prepared to accept the broad gathering of opinions and contributions as to how the administration of Aboriginal affairs should be shaped. That he is not prepared to use these processes, but blindly pushes on down his own track, reflects very badly on him indeed. However, I do not wish to get into that area. I simply commend this motion to the Senate and I trust that in future we will not have Government Ministers behaving in this disgraceful way.
Amendment agreed to.
Question put:
That the motion (Senator Chaney's), as amended, be agreed to.

ROW.ENTRY: (Senator Lewis did not vote, to compensate for the vacancy caused by the resignation of Senator Gietzelt.)

DIVISION.RESULT.PARA: Question so resolved in the affirmative.

DEBATE.TITLE: NATIONAL OCCUPATIONAL HEALTH AND SAFETY COMMISSION AMENDMENT BILL 1988

PROCTEXT.PARA: Debate resumed from 24 November 1988, on motion by Senator Bolkus:
That the Bill be now read a second time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Patterson Sen K.C.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —The National Occupational Health and Safety Commission Amendment Bill deals with amendments to the structure of the National Occupational Health and Safety Commission (NOHSC). Amendments are certainly necessary, given the saga of mismanagement that has been revealed in the McKay report. The Opposition supports this Bill, but I propose to move a second reading amendment at the conclusion of my remarks. I would like to give honourable senators a potted history of the National Occupational Health and Safety Commission. The NOHSC was established by the Hawke Government under the National Occupational Health and Safety Commission Act 1985. It is a tripartite body comprising representatives of Commonwealth, State and Territory governments, employers and trade unions.

SPEECH.PARA: Under section 7 of the Act, the Commission is, first, to develop among the members of the community an awareness of issues relevant to occupational health and safety matters and facilitate public debate and discussion on such issues; secondly, to provide, in the public interest, a forum by which representatives of the Government of the Commonwealth, the governments of the States, and of employers and employees may consult together in, and participate in, the development and formulation of policies and strategies relating to occupational health and safety matters; and, thirdly, to provide a national focus for activities relating to occupational health and safety matters.

The specific functions performed by the Commission are set out in section 8 of the Act. The Act currently provides for a Commission consisting of 17 members. The Chairman is a full time appointee and is the chief executive officer of the Commission. The remaining 16 part time members represent the Australian trade unions, the Confederation of Australian Industry and the Commonwealth, State and Territory governments.

The chief purpose of the Bill we are currently debating is to separate the functions of the chairperson of the Commission and the chief executive officer, for reasons I shall come to later. Additionally, the Bill provides the Commission with a new function in relation to the evaluation of occupational hazards in work places and enables the Commission to constitute committees comprising persons other than its members. The NOHSC or Worksafe Australia, as it is commonly known, is divided into two operational arms. The first is the National Health and Occupational Safety Office (NHOSO), which is responsible for policy development and administrative support. The second arm is the National Institute of Occupational Health and Safety, which is responsible for the Commission's scientific and technical research functions.

The Hawke Government has proudly boasted that the establishment of the NOHSC was historic and that it was born of the accord with the trade unions. NOHSC clearly owes its genesis not so much to the fertile imagination of the accord partners but to the authors of the Robens report published in the United Kingdom in 1972 and the subsequent legislation enacted by the Conservative Heath Government. Robens recommended statute law spelling out general duties of employers which in turn would be supported or fleshed out by a system of regulations and non-statutory codes of practice. The report also recommended that various health and safety agencies be unified into a single autonomous administrative organisation with a comprehensive range of powers and functions.

Occupational health and safety legislation enacted by the States and the Commonwealth in the last decade and a half has clearly been modelled on the Robens concept of industrial self-regulation with, as one commentator suggests, `a few antipodean adaptations to take account of federalism'. So much of the accord has now been shown as myth that we need hardly be surprised that one more aspect of it is now debunked. Clearly, there has been a huge need for a thorough overhaul of occupational health and safety practice.

Only this month we have had a statement from the Minister for Industrial Relations (Mr Peter Morris) about the appallingly high rate of workplace deaths in Australia. The Minister has told us that each week, on average, eight Australians are fatally injured at work and 6,000 suffer injuries for which they are compensated. Overall, the annual cost of workplace deaths and injuries, including compensation, lost production, retraining and welfare, is about $9,600m.

Mining and quarry workers are nearly nine times more likely to be killed at work than the average Australian worker. Transport and rural occupations are also among the most dangerous jobs. Figures cited by the Minister last year put the fatal injury rate at work in Australia at about 77 deaths per million workers. That compares with a rate in Sweden of 22; in Japan of 20; and in the United States of America of 37. While the rate seems to have dropped back, on the latest figures, to about 61 deaths per million workers, it is still far above the rate for comparable countries.

While I am on the topic of deaths and injuries of workers, I am conscious of the fact that workers usually referred to in this context are those in the paid work force who are covered by compulsory insurance schemes. Seeing that the Government is now addressing women's issues, at this hour, when it realises that it has not got the women's vote, I ask: What attention is being paid to the many unpaid workers who labour in their homes for the benefit not just of their families but also of the nation? What advice are they being given about safe manual handling practices or about the proper use and storage of hazardous chemicals? The Insurance Council of Australia in its February 1989 bulletin has issued a warning about homemade chemical cocktails. The title of that article is `They can kill'. It refers to typical items such as chlorine for pools and its volatility, solvents in the home and other substances that can place women who work in the home at great risk. This includes not only women but also their families. How effective is the NOHSC in fulfilling its charter to promote an awareness of issues relevant to occupational health and safety among the women-for by and large they are women-who work without wages and workers compensation in their own homes? I hope that we will see the Commission in its new form addressing that issue.

It is beyond doubt, from the statistics cited above, that occupational health and safety has been an area overdue for reform. In October 1984 the Government established a tripartite National Occupational Health and Safety Commission on a non-statutory basis, pending legislation for its creation as a statutory authority. The required legislation was introduced into the Parliament by Minister Willis on 23 April 1985 and, despite Opposition objections, passed the Senate on 16 May. Royal assent was received on 27 May. However-honourable senators might just note this, given the importance of occupational health and safety-the Act was not proclaimed until 20 December 1985.

When the establishing legislation for the NOHSC was introduced, the Opposition took exception to the unwieldy nature of the bureaucracy surrounding this reform and the duplication of State instrumentalities and commented on the singular lack of success of previous initiatives in this area. As my colleague Senator MacGibbon noted at the time:
We are dealing with human relations. Human nature simply cannot be confined or controlled by legislation. It does not matter how draconian the legislation is.

On 17 April 1986 the national Commission was launched officially by the Minister at a ceremony in Canberra when it was announced that it would be adopting the name Worksafe Australia. By late 1987 earlier criticisms made in anticipation of the Commission being given statutory backing were being amplified and echoed by a number of commentators. Jack Waterford writing in the Canberra Times began a detailed piece on NOHSC with the following remarks:
Worksafe Australia-supposed custodian of Australian occupational health and safety-is by some accounts in total crisis.

Three years after its establishment, it is said not only to have failed to meet its objectives of developing a national strategy for improving occupational health and safety, but to have become a floundering bureaucracy four times as large as it was ever intended, with appalling staff morale, high rates of absenteeism, sick leave and staff turnover, and with a very poor reputation out in the workplace.

I wonder about the occupational health of the staff working for the Commission. In the Age newspaper today there were details about mergers being imposed on universities in Victoria. I wonder what will happen to the health of academics and administrators within our Australian universities as a result of their occupations. Perhaps the Commission needs to address that problem. We talk about occupational health in industries in which people lift and handle things. We ought to talk also about stress brought on by this Government in certain occupations and the effects on health.

Mr Waterford added that the bureaucratisation of the Commission had meant that its scientific and technical areas had been starved of resources whilst tripartite control led to a lack of accountability. Another commentator, David Biggins, writing in the Current Affairs Bulletin of August 1987 argued:

All the appointees to the Commission are `peak council' nominees, their accountability to the grass roots remote. Clear lines of communication-in both directions-have not been set up. The Commission's structure is unlikely to encourage worker participation.
Speaking of the Commission he said:
. . . has not indicated how information will be disseminated to the shop floor. What should be a major priority appears to be slipping away.
Similarly, the US practice of using the law to bring government instrumentalities under critical public scrutiny has not been much used in Australia.
His argument continued:

. . . the National Institute of Occupational Health and Safety . . . appears to be falling into the pattern of a typical research institute with little regard to workplace origins of occupational health issues. The emphasis is shifting to research rather than the provision of information.

On the practical point, the Commission draft code on Safe Manual Handling released in 1987-which many Government members would wish to forget-was criticised heavily by industry, Senator Button, Senator Walsh and the Government's Business Regulation Review Unit. The code suggested that manual handling of 16 kilogram weights be restricted and that any item weighing more than 34 kilograms be banned from being lifted by any person-male or female. Taken to its absurd limits this would have prevented Australia's 164 million sheep from being shorn, or indeed many sick Australians from being nursed. That brings us back to the Bill we are debating today.

The then Minister for Industrial Relations, Ralph Willis, when introducing this Bill in the other place mentioned that the 1984 interim Commission had recommended to the Government that the work of the Commission should be reviewed after four years to ensure that its operations were in accord with its legislative brief. I note that this, and much of that speech, was omitted when Senator Bolkus was obliged to read the second reading speech on introducing the Bill into this chamber, as he was refused leave to incorporate the speech in Hansard. So much for Senator Bolkus reading the second reading speech! Mr Willis put a fine gloss on the real state of affairs when he said:
Accordingly in September last year I decided to bring forward the review by one year and appointed a former secretary of the Commonwealth Department of Health, Mr Bernie McKay, to conduct it.

Mr McKay's report findings were released by the Minister on 3 March 1988. The report was critical of most aspects of Worksafe's activities and recommended 34 ways in which NOHSC could be improved. The report's findings may have also prompted the resignation of Mr Brassil, the Commission's first Chairman. To quote Rod Campbell in the Canberra Times:

Mr McKay's report was considered by the Commission on Monday. Mr Brassil, its Chairman and Chief Executive Officer of Worksafe, resigned the same day. Mr Brassil said yesterday he was retiring from both positions in the next few days for health reasons-
it seems rather ironical that he was retiring for health reasons from the National Occupational Health and Safety Commission-
but hoped to be able to take up a part time government appointment.

According to Mr Rod Campbell, Mr Brassil agreed with the main thrust of Mr McKay's report and said that many of its proposals were the same as those he had been promoting. The Campbell article continues:

He said he did not want to make adverse comments on the report but felt it contained some inconsistencies and mistakes, particularly relating to claims that Worksafe had failed to properly develop a program of strategies and priorities.
Among the most significant criticisms of Worksafe made by Mr McKay were:
An overall lack of progress in its first two years of operation, requiring immediate structural and organisational changes.
Inadequate progress in heightening public awareness of occupational health and safety matters and developing strategies and priorities.
Inadequate co-ordination of occupational health and safety, particularly between the States and Commonwealth departments.
Inadequate development of standards, information and education programs and research activities, and of the National Institute of Occupational Health and Safety.
Inadequate representation of women on the Commission and its committees.
That is an indictment which I think Senator Reynolds should be here to hear. The criticisms continued:
Communications problems between Worksafe and Mr Willis and his Department-
although some of the blame was levelled at the latter two-
A rigid adherence to tripartite principles at all levels of activity.
The negative impact of a public service model organisation on its activities.

That is a litany of criticisms, a list of problems that the Government ought to have been able to pick up well before we got so far into the business of this very vital Commission. As I outlined earlier, the Bill presently before the Senate reflects some but not all of the recommendations of the McKay report. Additionally, these structural changes are to be backed by changed administrative procedures within NOHSC. Opposition senators, through Estimates Committee A, will certainly pay close attention to progress on implementing the following recommendations of the McKay report. The ones on which we will concentrate in detail are:
That a review of the corporate services and support functions of the Commission should be undertaken with a view to possible rationalisation of some of these with those of the Department-
that was recommendation 5-
That expertise rather than tripartism should be the principal criterion by which membership of committees and working parties is derived-
that was recommendation 7-
That the Commission gave high priority to its co-ordination role and in this respect prepare an inventory of activities in each State which relate to its priorities and strategies-
recommendation 10-
That all existing committees and working parties be critically reviewed with a view to their abolition and only retained where no alternative arrangement is possible-
recommendation 21-
That the Commission undertake the changed role proposed in the McKay report within existing resources-
recommendation 24-
That grants made to the ACTU and CAI for training purposes should be made by the Minister and such grants should be administered by the Department rather than the Commission-
recommendation 30-
That an independent review of basic training needs in occupational health and safety be undertaken to determine future requirements and prepare delivery arrangements-
that was recommendation 32.

I emphasise again that Opposition senators will address those issues and ask questions in the Senate Estimates committees to ensure that the McKay report is not yet another report that is just shelved. Despite claims that progress is being made, as recently as November 1988 the Commission was criticised in the report of Senate Estimates Committee A for allowing an officer domiciled in Canberra to commute each week to Sydney at public expense for 21 months even though the officer had been given compulsory notice of transfer.

During 1987-88 the Commission operated under the four programs of prevention, standards, human resource development and corporate services. The experience gained during that year has made the Commission decide to operate under just two programs in 1988-89-knowledge and prevention and corporate services. While it is pleasing to note that the proportions of staff between the two programs have changed since last year when there were 70 staff in corporate services to the 159 in knowledge and prevention, the ratio still seems to be too high at the 1988-89 estimate of 59 staff in corporate services to 170 in knowledge and prevention. Although the Opposition supports the National Occupational Health and Safety Commission Bill 1988, the Government can be sure that Opposition senators--
Debate interrupted.
Sitting suspended from 12.45 p.m. to 2 p.m.

TALK.START.PARA: —I direct my question to the Leader of the Government in the Senate and refer to the fact that recent interest rate rises have added about $80 a month to the average mortgage. I ask the Minister: Is that the financial equivalent of a tax increase of about $18 a week? Does the Minister agree that this result of the Government's high interest rate policy has robbed hundreds of thousands of home buyers of any benefit from the promised tax cuts months before they are delivered?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Button Sen The Hon J.N.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am not in a position to confirm or deny the figures Senator Chaney has put to me; whether that is the financial equivalent of an $18 a week tax cut I am unable to say.
—How is your arithmetic?
—No, I am not good at arithmetic.
—Nor is your Government.

—It is something which is shared on both sides of this chamber. Senator Messner laughs. He asked me yesterday about a 30 per cent wage increase and a 20 per cent tax cut-I am not sure-which does not indicate a high degree of numeracy on the Opposition side.

ANSWER.PARA: The Government has made no secret of the fact that it has been running a tight monetary policy, which will have an impact on sectors of Australian industry, particularly the housing industry. Those consequences may have followed. I do not necessarily agree with the figures the honourable senator referred to. I guess the Opposition has to make up its mind what its view is about tax cuts. Sometimes Opposition spokesmen have said there should not be any, which would be an infinitely worse situation than the one suggested in Senator Chaney's scenario.

TALK.START.PARA: —What we have been saying is that with your record we cannot afford them.
—You ought not talk about records here.

—My question is directed to the Minister representing the Minister for Telecommunications and Aviation Support. In view of reported action by Qantas Airways Ltd, to increase its vigilance in the maintenance of its Boeing fleet, I ask the Minister whether similar measures have been taken by Australian domestic airlines in relation to the safety of their Boeing planes. In view of the fact that identified or suspected faults following the tragic spate of international disasters involving Boeings have mainly concerned aircraft aged between 15 and 20 years, how many aircraft flown within Australia by Australian Airlines and Ansett Airlines of Australia fall into that age group? Is the Australian Government satisfied that all maintenance and safety measures carried out by Qantas, Australian, Ansett and the smaller commercial airline companies are adequate, given the recent happenings overseas?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Evans Sen The Hon G.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am advised that Qantas, on its own initiative and with the full support of the Civil Aviation Authority (CAA), has taken increased steps to check and maintain the cargo doors on its Boeing fleet because of the suspected involvement of the cargo door in the United Airlines Honolulu accident. The maintenance procedures required by the CAA in regard to aircraft operated by Qantas and the domestic airlines are directly related to the age of the individual aircraft concerned. I am advised that airlines are maintaining the current required level of vigilance.

ANSWER.PARA: As to the numbers of aircraft in the category to which Senator Jones referred, there are three Qantas, seven Australian Airlines and seven Airlines of Western Australia aircraft in service that were manufactured prior to 1974. I am advised that the CAA is satisfied that all Australian airlines follow the necessary maintenance procedures. Any additional action identified as necessary will be taken following investigation of recent happenings overseas.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Leader of the Government in the Senate. Does the Minister agree with the Treasurer's assessment, conveyed to the Caucus economic committee, that suggestions of exempting interest on savings from tax to encourage Australians to save more are `quick fix' and `highly suspect'? Does the Minister believe it is worth pursuing options to address the problem of Australia's low savings ratio, to which he referred on the Face to Face program on 19 February, or has the strength of the Treasurer's opposition put an end to any consideration of ways of tackling that problem?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Button Sen The Hon J.N.

TALK.START.PARA: —Let me quote what I said in the Face to Face interview on 19 February. These were the words I used:

ANSWER.PARA: People aren't saving enough. Now if you're saying that is an issue which requires addressing, I think it's something we have to look at.

By the evening of that program, the Australian Broadcasting Corporation was running a story which said that I had suggested that between $2,000 and $5,000 invested in savings bank accounts, or in bank accounts, ought to be exempt from tax.

TALK.START.PARA: —We have all suffered at their hands.
—I am not complaining at all, I am just saying how these things develop. I am really not complaining. That all this wisdom should be attributed to me is rather gratifying.
—Are you making a personal explanation?

—No, I am not making a personal explanation at all. I do not feel the need to do that, as do some Opposition senators from time to time-like every day. Let me make it clear from the outset that the Treasurer's criticisms have been made in response to some of the more fanciful proposals put forward to increase private savings, including some of those put forward by the Opposition. I certainly agree with the Treasurer that there are no quick fix proposals that will merely create avenues for tax minimisation and undermine public savings. I have never said anything which could be construed as support for those quick fix proposals.

ANSWER.PARA: There are three components of aggregate savings-household, government and gross business savings. The Government has directly sought to increase aggregate savings by increasing the level of public savings to historically high levels. Regardless of whether Senator Stone agrees with the adjective or not, responsible fiscal policy on our part has meant that the total net public sector borrowing requirement is now zero. This financial year's Commonwealth Budget will have a surplus approaching 2 per cent of gross domestic product (GDP). Gross business savings as a proportion of GDP remain at a healthy level. Household savings have declined in recent years, and this was a concern I raised recently. Any proposals to increase household savings would need to be on a revenue-neutral basis, as far as the Government is concerned, because of the effects on the other elements of aggregate savings.

TALK.START.PARA: —I ask a supplementary question, Mr President. I commend the Minister for his latter-day recognition of the low savings ratio and ask him: In floating the idea-to use his words-`that that is something we have to look at', was he inspired because of delayed recognition of a tax bias against personal savings within the taxation system?
—It was a remark in response to a particular question. I was not inspired at all.

—My question is directed to the Minister for Immigration, Local Government and Ethnic Affairs. I refer the Minister to statements he made on a recent visit to Hong Kong regarding the effect of the immigration debate on Australia's business migration program. Can the Minister advise the Senate of the current situation with regard to business migration applications? Do the statements he made in Hong Kong in any way conflict with the statements made late last year by the Prime Minister?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Ray Sen The Hon R.F.
ANSWER.MINISTERIAL: IMMIGRATION, LOCAL GOVERNMENT AND ETHNIC AFFAIRS

TALK.START.PARA: —I think part of the question was left out: `or the Minister for Foreign Affairs'. This is not going to turn Question Time into a personal explanation period. However, given the opportunism of yesterday's motion by Senator Puplick and the actions of the shadow Minister, it is a classic example of where one erroneous press report is latched onto by members of the Opposition, no transcript is checked, and then extended into a straw man that they subsequently knock down. This is why this Opposition, with its shallowness, is not going to win future elections, because it is just a pathetic approach. I was asked a specific question in Hong Kong alone: Had this year's application rate shown a decline over the previous year? I said no, it had not. That is a fact. What people overlook, of course, is that year by year our application rate from Hong Kong had been doubling and certainly in this year's program that anticipation existed. Anyone who visits Hong Kong would clearly know that one of the major issues running there is whether Australia in future will discriminate against immigrants from Hong Kong.
—What rubbish! Absolute rubbish!
—I do not know how many Opposition senators have visited Hong Kong and read daily the reports in the South China Morning Post or heard the various talk-back programs.
—You are pushing it.

—I have not. What I had to do in Hong Kong was try to defend you, members of the Opposition. I had to do it in such a way as to try to assure the people of Hong Kong that the members of the Australian Opposition are typical Opposition members, making promises that they would never keep in government. What the Prime Minister in his statement last year was alluding to was forgone opportunity. It is quite clear that the business migration program this year is going to run 2,000 under target. Of those, 700 would have been business migrants, the rest their families. As the required amount to bring into this country is $675,000, that is $500,000, plus settlement costs--
—Why would they want to bring $675,000 into this country, the way you are running the economy?

—Senator Lewis wants to talk down the program. Mr Sinclair at least in Hong Kong tried to promote it. But that would easily meet the threat to the program that the Prime Minister alluded to of $350m. The program does have difficulties, but I want to stress too in fairness that the Asian migration debate is one of the factors operating in the business migration area. A second factor is competition from New Zealand and Canada, which have far less rigorous requirements, not only in monetary amounts but in character checks, et cetera. A third factor-maybe only until last week, not this week-was the fact that an appreciating dollar in Australia made it harder for people to meet the requirements. So there are three elements running through this that all have to be addressed. Those opposite can make as much noise as they like. If they think that this debate has not affected our image and our reputation in places such as Hong Kong, they just happen to be wrong; it has.
—No wonder, given the manner in which the Ministers have been fuelling it.

—Senator Stone does not know what I said in Hong Kong. I did nothing to fuel the debate. I did everything possible to dampen that debate and said that I did not think that any Australian government in the future would pursue discriminatory policies.

ANSWER.PARA: The business migration program this year has suffered, and I believe that the program next year will suffer. There are other things we can do. We can tinker around the edges with the requirements to ease them slightly-not ever to get to the level of New Zealand and Canada, because I think that they are economy class schemes and we are running a first class scheme. But to have that statement that I made in Hong Kong, that there had not been a decline from one year to another, interpreted as being in conflict with the Prime Minister's views is totally and absolutely wrong. As I say, we anticipated, and no-one challenged the figures. We have been doubling the business migration program year on year. That has flattened out to nothing.

I also went on to say in Hong Kong-it was not reported here-that the gap between the first approach and development of business migration applications by business migration agents and their lodging in our office is quite often 10 to 12 months. So we still have not seen the evidence as to whether, in fact, we are going to go into a decline, let alone a failure to increase. That particular piece of journalism was shabby. The response by Mr Cadman was equally shabby because he checked none of the facts.

The final point I want to make is that if there is one saving grace in all this it has been the statements made in his visits throughout Asia by the Prime Minister and by his Foreign Minister that have done much to repair the damage done by some irresponsible people opposite.

TALK.START.PARA: —I refer the Minister representing the Minister for Community Services and Health to a decision made by the Government in September 1987 to end the monopoly production of certain drugs when they had come to the end of their patent life. This decision involved a requirement that the original sole manufacturer set a price for the drug that was within 20c of the price charged by new manufacturers of a similar drug, or face the delisting of their product from 1 April this year. I ask the Minister why the Government is refusing to immediately relist those pharmaceutical products made by drug companies which first refused, but have now agreed, to the pricing requirement? Is the Government aware that its plan to punish those nine companies for not agreeing immediately to the 20c differential by delaying the relisting to 1 August 1989 could have severe repercussions on consumers? Is the Government aware of the problems facing patients and their doctors if, for that four-month period-that is, between the delisting time of 1 April 1989 and the relisting schedule time of 1 August 1989-patients are taken off the drug or provided with excessive quantities of or repeat prescriptions for the drug, or changed to a generically similar but possibly not identical drug? Finally, in the interests of consumers, their medical practitioners and pharmacists, will the Government abandon its plan to hold off the relisting of the currently delisted drugs until 1 August 1989 and relist the relevant drugs immediately?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Cook Sen The Hon P.F.S.

TALK.START.PARA: —I think that that question had about two `am I awares'-am I aware that we may have punished pharmaceutical companies, and am I aware that we may have done something to injure patients? I am not aware of those things because, if the brief which I just happen to have about me is correct, then those things will not occur.

ANSWER.PARA: Let me just go to the details that I can advise the honourable senator of in respect of this question she has raised. The Government asked pharmaceutical companies to lower prices on some drugs where there were cheaper alternative brands available under the pharmaceutical benefits scheme (PBS). The generic drug initiative is part of an industry package aimed at boosting the overall growth of Australia's pharmaceutical drug industry. The package includes longer patient terms for new drugs and price increases for drug companies prepared to invest in Australian manufacturing, drug research and export. To partly offset the cost of the package the generic drug initiative was introduced. Most companies agreed to lower their prices, but a few declined, preferring to withdraw their brands from the pharmaceutical benefits scheme. As a consequence of that action of the drug companies 12 brands were withdrawn from the PBS and that will take effect from 1 April this year, as Senator Haines has said. It must be stressed that in every case alternative brands which have identical active ingredients to the deleted brands will continue to be available through the PBS and there is no reason why patients should therefore be disadvantaged. Patients will have to ask their doctors, however, to prescribe the equivalent drug brand remaining on the pharmaceutical benefits schedule if they wish to obtain subsidised medication from 1 April. Alternative suppliers were advised in September 1988 that it would be necessary for them to supply the full PBS demand from 1 April 1989. These suppliers required a lead time of approximately six months to arrange material supplies, equipment and storage to be able to fulfil the commitment to supply the full demand. So they had notice of about seven or so months and they required a lead time of six months.

In some cases manufacturers of the delisted brands-this is the first `am I aware' I think the honourable senator has referred to me-have now changed their minds and want to reduce their prices and stay on the list. Unfortunately for them it is too late. The alternative suppliers have already manufactured large stocks of these drugs and would be severely disadvantaged if the Government agreed to relist the originator brands earlier than August of 1989. So if we are talking about punishing people that is a totally unfair complexion to cast on this. If we were to punish anyone by changing direction it would be those who agreed to manufacture drugs to replace those drugs that have been de-listed. In order to ensure a reliable supply of these important drugs, especially in the face of vacillation by the major companies, the Government had to give a commitment to the alternative suppliers that the de-listed brands would not be re-listed for at least four months. So I think the honourable senator's two `am I aware' questions are not fair. They cast a wrong complexion. Patients' interests are protected as are the interests of the companies that have cooperated in this scheme.

TALK.START.PARA: —Can the Minister for the Arts, Sport, the Environment, Tourism and Territories advise the Senate of what progress has been made by the joint task force on intractable wastes to solve the problem of disposal of these wastes?
