Will a high temperature incinerator be established to resolve the problem in the foreseeable future?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Richardson Sen The Hon G.F.
ANSWER.MINISTERIAL: ARTS, SPORT, THE ENVIRONMENT, TOURISM AND TERRITORIES

TALK.START.PARA: —As honourable senators would be aware, intractable wastes are a very serious problem in this country.
—You are one of them.

—I am not an intractable waste. However, there is 11,000 tonnes of this stuff in Australia and, unfortunately, 8,000 tonnes of that is stored at Botany in the heart of the Sydney metropolitan area. The polychlorinated biphenyls and the hexachlorobenzenes are pretty awful so we have to do something about them. Unfortunately, for too long governments have run away from the problem, given that it is unlikely that too many communities would welcome any high temperature facility. However, the Victorian and New South Wales governments agreed with the Commonwealth on the need to establish a task force to try to come to grips with the problem. The task force reported in the middle of last year. It made a number of recommendations which have been accepted by the Ministers from the three States. I think the most important of the recommendations was that, quite apart from building a facility, whatever we were to do in the future the main priority had to be to minimise the waste that we produce. We are now looking at ways and means of doing that.

ANSWER.PARA: A facility will be built to destroy and dispose of all the intractable wastes that are stored and that are being produced in south-eastern Australia; the facility will be government-owned and I think that, too, is important; and a community based committee will be established to monitor the performance of the facility. Obviously, given the problems that such a facility could possibly bring, that is important. There is a commitment on the part of the three governments to ensure that only the most advanced technology is used in such a facility.

Late last year I had a further discussion with Mr Moore, the New South Wales Minister for Environment. It was his attitude and that of his Government that, if such a facility were to be built, given that most of these intractable wastes are produced and stored in New South Wales, the facility should also be there. That is a position with which I wholeheartedly agree. The task force is currently working on sites in New South Wales alone and a report on a preferred site will be available later in the year. I shall inform Senator Zakharov and the Senate as soon as that announcement has been made.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! I draw the attention of honourable senators to the presence in my gallery of a delegation from Italy led by the Minister for Foreign Trade, Ambassador Renato Ruggiero. On behalf of all honourable senators I welcome the delegation to the Senate and trust that your visit to Australia will be both informative and enjoyable.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Watson Sen J.O.W.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister for Industry, Technology and Commerce. On 17 October last year, in a joint statement by the Minister and the Prime Minister, full support was given to the development of a world scale pulp mill at Wesley Vale in northern Tasmania. I remind the Senate of part of that release:

QUESTION.PARA: The participation of Noranda Forest in this project is particularly welcome. With its extensive forest products interests and market network around the world, Noranda Forest brings significant expertise to the project.

I further remind the Minister that he said that the Government had worked closely with the companies and the Tasmanian Government to ensure that the project went ahead. Does the Minister now retract any part of that full statement? Is the Government weakening in its support for the mill? What effort is the Government now making to ensure a reasonably expedient resolution to its responsibility in this matter?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Button Sen The Hon J.N.

TALK.START.PARA: —An expedient timetable has been agreed to by my colleague Senator Richardson, by me, in so far as I have been involved, by the Tasmanian Government and by the company, Noranda. That solution will be reasonably expedient. I think the expression I used in my statement was that I welcomed the announcement by the joint venturers. I certainly did because it is a very large investment in a resource processing industry which is very important to Australia and which involves a high level of value added to raw materials which are currently being exported from Australia as woodchips.

ANSWER.PARA: The project will go ahead provided it reaches satisfactory environmental guidelines which are the subject of negotiation between the Tasmanian Government and the Federal Government. I think that is understood by the joint venturers. They may not like it, but I think it is understood by them that appropriate environmental guidelines have to be put in place for a mill of this kind. But I assure honourable senators that a lot of effort has been expended in seeing that that is so and I believe that we will be able to achieve a satisfactory result on those issues.

QUESTION.BLOCK.TITLE: YEAR OF CITIZENSHIP: ROLE OF LOCAL GOVERNMENT

TALK.START.PARA: —I ask the Minister for Local Government what part she sees local government playing in the Year of Citizenship announced by the Government last September?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Reynolds Sen The Hon M.

TALK.START.PARA: —Local government is very much involved in citizenship. In fact, our citizenship ceremonies could not take place without the broad support of local government around the country. This year, over the Australia Day weekend, some 7,000 residents took up citizenship. Two hundred local councils were involved in that ceremony. Obviously, throughout the country local government-mayors, aldermen and staff-is putting a great deal of effort into citizenship ceremonies and giving great support to the Federal Government in this regard. Clearly, in the Year of Citizenship, as declared by the Prime Minister last year, it is important that local government receive some recognition and support for the very important role that it plays.

ANSWER.PARA: I take this opportunity to announce that we will be undertaking a number of special projects with a number of local councils throughout the country to enhance and to recognise the work that has been done in relation to citizenship ceremonies. I will run through the councils that have been selected by virtue of their percentages of non-citizens. In New South Wales, Fairfield Council has 21.5 per cent of non-citizens; Randwick Council has 19.4 per cent; Wollongong Council has 15.8 per cent; and Warringah Council has 14.8 per cent. In Victoria, we selected Sunshine, Springvale and Broadmeadows; in Queensland, Brisbane and Mount Isa; in South Australia, Salisbury; in Western Australia, Wanneroo; in Tasmania, Hobart, Glenorchy, Clarence and Kingborough; and in the Northern Territory, Darwin and Palmerston. I would be happy to table this list for the benefit of honourable senators. In focusing on a number of important projects among these councils, we are trying to say to the councils, `We appreciate what you do in sponsoring citizenship ceremonies, but we also recognise that there are new ways in which you can take up the question of citizenship to encourage more people to come forward'. As Senator Ray has said on a number of occasions, that is the primary focus of the Year of Citizenship-to try to encourage more and more people to give that fundamental commitment to Australia.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is addressed to the Minister representing the Minister for Social Security. How many parents whose children are living on the streets are receiving the family allowances and, in some cases, the family income supplement?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Bolkus Sen The Hon N.

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank Senator MacGibbon for his question and at the outset--
—Why do you thank him? It is a silly question.

—I thank him because his question exposes the degree of ignorance on the other side of the chamber about this very basic, important and grave issue. It reflects the ignorance that directed the Opposition's policy during its seven years in government, a policy which delivered benefits to children of low income earners-indeed, to children at all-only once in seven years. One increase in seven years was the record of the Opposition. The question also indicates the degree of ignorance of the current problems as reflected in the Opposition's current policy projections. As I said to Senator Chaney yesterday, and I do not want to go through that answer again, this Government has a commitment, as spelt out by the Prime Minister, that by 1990 child poverty will be addressed.

—I rise on a point of order, Mr President. The Minister is clearly debating the question. He has not addressed the question that was put to him which was a simple request for the number of street children whose parents are in receipt of either family allowance or family allowance supplement. That is a straightforward question. The Minister has clearly entered into a debate on the matter and I ask you to call him to order.
—The Minister must not debate the matter and I ask him to answer Senator MacGibbon's question.

—I will ensure that the Opposition gets a full answer to the question. I made that basic preamble because I think there is an elementary contextual point here. Commissioner Burdekin pointed out in his report:

ANSWER.PARA: It is impossible to state precisely how many homeless children and young people there are in Australia.

That is a very basic point. As I said yesterday and repeat today, this Government has acted to ensure that a number of children have been lifted out of poverty areas. What the Government knows and what Senator Chaney should know as a previous Minister in this area is that measures of poverty and poverty lines should be used very carefully, if at all.

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise on a point of order which is one of relevance. The Minister is now talking about poverty lines which were not mentioned in the question and which are totally irrelevant to the issue. The question referred to the number of children who are not living at home, who are on the streets, but whose parents are receiving family allowances.
—Order! I have no power over the way in which the Minister answers a question, but I do think that his answer was relevant to the subject.

—As I was saying, the inadequacy of poverty lines is something that this Government has recognised. Senator Chaney also recognised it when he was Minister for Social Security because neither this Government nor the previous Government has endorsed the concept of poverty lines as an indicator. In government we are addressing two basic issues in this area. The first is to ascertain where child poverty exists, not by some arbitrary total figure or some value-ridden dollar measure of poverty, but to locate the real areas of hardship for children so that programs can be directed to those children. That is what we have done with family allowance supplement, the child support scheme and so on. In fact, it should be noted-and this goes very much to the point of Senator MacGibbon's question-that at the end of January 1989 almost 300,000 children were benefiting from this Government's programs under the family allowance supplement scheme.

ANSWER.PARA: The second question for governments to answer is where the areas of need are and how to address them with the adequate degree of support. In this respect I should point out that the Government has used as the most appropriate response to this problem the establishment of benchmarks for adequacy of 15 per cent and 20 per cent of married rate pensions. Those are the bench-marks mentioned by the Prime Minister in 1987 and they are the same benchmarks that we have repeated we will achieve by 1990.

In conclusion, I mention the fact that we have benefited almost 300,000 children-at least 125,000 families-by measures addressed specifically to those areas of need. I should also point out that in our six years of government we have addressed the problem by increasing payments in every year of that period. I ask the Senate and the Australian public to compare our record with one measly increase in seven years by the Opposition when it was in government.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President, I ask a supplementary question. The Senate has infinite compassion for Senator Bolkus's intellectual shortcomings, but the question I asked him was how many parents were receiving entitlements who were not entitled to them, given the fact that the homeless children of this country are the one flourishing subculture that is being promoted by the Hawke Government.
—I do not think that that sort of logic even deserves to be recognised.

—My question is directed to the Minister representing the Minister for Administrative Services. Is he aware of reports concerning continuing allegations of electoral malpractice being made by Mrs Joan Chambers, a former Liberal Party member of the Victorian Parliament? Can the Minister inform the Senate of the steps taken by the Australian Electoral Commission to check the integrity of the joint Commonwealth-Victoria electoral roll, following Mrs Chambers's petition to the Victorian Court of Disputed Returns last November? In light of the fact that Mrs Chambers has withdrawn the petition and has had costs awarded against her, what means are available to the Electoral Commissioner to respond to her continuing innuendo?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Ray Sen The Hon R.F.
ANSWER.MINISTERIAL: IMMIGRATION, LOCAL GOVERNMENT AND ETHNIC AFFAIRS

TALK.START.PARA: —Normally matters concerning the Court of Disputed Returns arising out of a Victorian election would not come within the ambit of the Commonwealth. On this occasion Mrs Chambers objected to the election result in Ballarat South, where she lost by 102 votes. She followed the normal Liberal Party modus operandi and lodged some generalised objections, none of which had substance, then submitted to the court that it should go on a `fishing expedition' all the way through the records to try to find the evidence. That was never the original intent of the Victorian Act nor would it be the intention of the Federal Act. Not that that process should be condemned-I think that in the long term it might be desirable provided that other parts of the Electoral Act are amended to allow disputed votes to be counted. That would achieve some balance. I suspect that at both Federal and State levels, through judgments and judges, one area has been liberalised and the other has not. On this occasion that did not prove to be a fruitful course for Mrs Chambers and she had to withdraw her challenge. As the Act anticipated, she had costs awarded against her.
—You did not have to seek them.

—Senator Alston says that I did not have to seek them. The Liberal Party has just sold a building for $12m. I do not know why those miserable creeps over there do not fix her up. Why do they not kick in? Why do they leave it to the poor candidate to find the $27,000? The Liberal Party has $12m from a property that was originally sold by a Victorian Liberal Government at an undervalued price. I do not know why those blokes opposite do not kick in as they keep whingeing about costs. There are costs involved in the Court of Disputed Returns in order to stop stupid and frivolous appeals to that court.

ANSWER.PARA: Let us get to the substance of the matter. Mrs Chambers, with the Liberal Party and probably at least one person in this chamber backing her up, challenged the validity of the roll. I suggest that Mrs Chambers go back and read the Victorian legislation which is the same as the Federal legislation. Challenging the validity of the roll is not a ground for challenging the election. It is explicitly written in the legislation.

After these events Mrs Chambers went off on a big burst in the Melbourne Age and the Ballarat Courier attacking the Australian Electoral Commission. The reality is that Mrs Chambers and the Liberal Party lodged a variety of objections to people on the roll. We know that because the cheque drawn on the challengers was a Liberal Party cheque, not Mrs Chambers's cheque. Her criticism is that the Electoral Commission did not respond quickly enough. I argue, having now read the facts, that the Electoral Commission responded very quickly. It needed to delay for eight days to take legal advice on some cases. It had to check that the challenges by Mrs Chambers and the Liberal Party were not duplicating existing challenges. In fact, it put on two extra staff in Ballarat, which is a Federal electorate, and one person in Burke, to resolve these matters.

We were all party to the legislation. We all voted unanimously to go through proper procedures to take objections on the roll and not just, on the first rumour, rip someone's name off the roll. Letters have to be written and objection notices and final notices have to be sent out. All of that is under way. Even if the Electoral Commission, by some fluke, could have completed this process between 18 December and 3 February, none of it would have been relevant to Mrs Chambers's appeal to the Court of Disputed Returns, which says explicitly that one cannot challenge the roll. It is yet another case of the loser whingeing. It is part of Opposition mentality that if it loses an election it cannot be because of the merits of the candidate or deficient policies; it must be because there is something wrong with the electoral system. We have been there and done that. The Opposition is there and is doing that. As long as it does it, it has an Opposition mentality. Why does it not try to get out of it and start looking towards government?

TALK.START.PARA: —We are.
—There is no sign of it.

—Is the Minister representing the Minister for Employment, Education and Training aware of the inability of many rural families to qualify for isolated children's assistance under the assets test guidelines? In view of the fact that the great majority of Australians already have the opportunity to send their children to conveniently located neighbourhood schools, enjoy good roads and have access to modern conveniences that are not provided to isolated families, when will this Government recognise that, by the very nature of farming, liquidity is a major problem and many farmers do not have the means to afford the cost of schooling? Is there any possibility of the Government reviewing the assets test guidelines to enable more rural families to qualify for isolated children's assistance?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Walsh Sen The Hon P.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —This is another free kick in the square. As to the additional allowance for isolated children, everybody gets $1,000, in round figures, and, again in round figures, about $2,000 is available subject to an income test which has always been there and is now subject to an assets test. The people on whose behalf Senator Bjelke-Petersen is asking the question, whom she depicts as disadvantaged people, are by definition people who have net assets in excess of $600,000 in addition to the house and curtilage. The National Party's definition of a disadvantaged person is somebody who has net assets in excess of $600,000 plus the house in which he lives. I suppose somebody from the National Party who has been dipping his fist into the public till for the past decade or so might have a different perception from that of the great majority of Australians of what is disadvantaged. If one had access to the public till through one's association with the Queensland National Party, one would probably think $600,000 was not very much. However, I can assure Senator Bjelke-Petersen that the great majority of Australians have no aspirations, no belief, no expectation that they will ever accumulate assets of that size as well as the house they own. Most Australians never accumulate anything significant beyond the house they own. So the people about whom she speaks are not disadvantaged.

ANSWER.PARA: Senator Bjelke-Petersen says also that every Queensland country school teacher, every Queensland country police officer-even if he or she does not have a second income in the household-every household in the country in Queensland which has two persons employed, as well as just about every tradesman, should be denied the additional allowance because of the income test, but that people who have assets in excess of $600,000 should continue to get it. That is not a proposition which this Government will pick up. If there is scope for any additional money to be paid under this program, I can confidently assure the Senate that it will be devoted towards either increasing the basic allowances or easing the quite stringent income test which applies to this program. It will not be shunted off in the way the Queensland National Party would have it shunted off; that is, into providing extra hand-outs for people with net assets in excess of $600,000 as well as the house that they own while households on an income of $24,000, which is less than average male adult male weekly earnings, are not entitled to it because of an income test.

TALK.START.PARA: —Is the Minister for Finance aware of allegations reported in this morning's Brisbane Courier-Mail that Commonwealth funds provided under the natural disaster relief arrangements (NDRA) had not been used for disaster relief but to purchase additional cane and milk quotas as well as additional land? Will the Government be taking any action in relation to this allegation about the misuse of taxpayers' money?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Walsh Sen The Hon P.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —It has been apparent for some time that the administration of natural disaster relief arrangements and probably the rural adjustment scheme in Queensland is like the administration of just about everything else in Queensland. From time to time they have been administered in ways that have a familiar ring about them, such as when the Fitzgerald Commission of Inquiry into Possible Illegal Activities and Associated Police Misconduct started delving into Queensland administration. Indeed, there have been cases in the past when natural disaster relief funds were regarded by the people who administered them and the government which oversaw them, and sometimes issued directions to them, as a sort of National Party slush fund to be distributed to National Party toadies and apparatchiks whenever the people who controlled the fund or controlled the controllers of the fund felt like doing so.

ANSWER.PARA: I have seen the report in the Brisbane Courier-Mail. The report says that one farmer received NDRA funds following Cyclone Winifred and used them to extend the farm size and purchase a cane quota, and that a dairy farmer used the funds allegedly given for drought relief to purchase an increased milk quota. Leaving aside the question of whether a milk quota ought to have a market value per se-I would be interested to hear Senator Stone's views on that at some time-if the reports are correct there is absolutely no doubt that NDRA funds have been misused. Under the rural adjustment scheme, in certain circumstances funds could be used for such purposes, but there is no way that NDRA funds could be used for that purpose within the guidelines.

I will ask the Department of Finance to endeavour to check out the facts behind these reports. Prima facie, there is a case because we know that in the past there have been similar misallocations of public money by Queensland authorities. We have sought assurances from the Queensland Government that it will clean up its act. If this latest report is verified by the subsequent inquiry, the time has come to consider suspending NDRA funding payments to Queensland. If the Commonwealth is put in a position where it takes that fairly drastic step, that is an action which is attributable, should be attributed and will be attributed to the maladministration of the Queensland authorities which has been going on over many years and upon which it would appear they have taken no effective action. I suggest that if Mr Ahern is committed to ending corruption, he should take some effective steps to clear up this matter.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister representing the Minister for Aboriginal Affairs. I refer to the Royal Commission into Aboriginal Deaths in Custody, which used to be known as the Muirhead inquiry. Has the Minister seen research from the staff of this inquiry which establishes that the rate of Aboriginal deaths in custody is in fact lower than the average for all people in custody? Does this not undermine the basis for this special, racially based inquiry? How much has this inquiry cost so far? If it is to continue, should it not deal with the death rate, and the reasons for the deaths for all detainees, not just one racial group? Or, if such an inquiry is not thought necessary or appropriate, and there is some special and understandable concern about the number of Aborigines in custody, should not the inquiry concentrate on why so many Aborigines are in custody, and the extent to which government programs are contributing to these very high numbers?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Tate Sen The Hon M.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —It is a fact that when I made available to the Australian community the interim report of Mr Justice Muirhead resulting from his inquiry to the stage it had reached at the end of 1988 into Aboriginal deaths in custody, as requested by Federal and State governments and the Territory Government-in other words, supported by all jurisdictions-some very interesting figures were to be found in the appendices. In summary, as I recall, it appeared that even in police custody Aborigines are no more likely to die than are non-Aboriginals. The real problem lies in the fact that far more Aborigines are taken into custody than should be the case. That is the real point which needs to be tackled as a policy matter.

ANSWER.PARA: On the question of the numbers of Aboriginals in custody, I am told that an Aboriginal is 20 times more likely to be arrested than is a non-Aboriginal-and that leads to being put into a police lock-up and then perhaps followed by further detention. The Australian Police Ministers Council has been considering that problem since this matter erupted into public prominence in late 1987. As a result of the Muirhead Royal Commission's interim report, we now have available to us many recommendations, which in large measure coincide with the thoughts of the Police Ministers, as to how, firstly, one might avoid the taking of Aboriginal persons into custody in the great numbers in which they are. That would also involve the Attorneys-General of the various jurisdictions agreeing to a program of, for example, decriminalising simple drunkenness. Other measures that need to be taken into account are as to how police lock-ups are set up and conducted, and as to how supervision of those within them is conducted. All these matters will be the subject of an interdisciplinary discussion between Police Ministers, Aboriginal Ministers, Health Ministers and Corrective Service Ministers in Burnie, in the north-west of Tasmania, in a meeting convened by the Hon. Roger Groom and to be held in the week before Easter. On that occasion, spread over 2 1/2 days, various matters will be discussed, and we will take the opportunity in a comprehensive way to look at various social issues to which Senator Hamer rightly alluded in his question. Those issues need to be addressed if we are to prevent great numbers of Aboriginals being taken into custody and the subsequent deaths that do occur.

It is also important to recognise that the Muirhead Royal Commission, although focused on and inquiring into Aboriginal deaths in custody, will in its recommendations, if implemented, have great beneficial effects for non-Aboriginal Australians who also find themselves being taken into custody. I believe that point needs to be emphasised. The whole Australian community will benefit from the recommendations of Mr Justice Muirhead. I refer, for example, to the conduct of coronial inquiries, the way in which certain offences should be taken off the statute books, the way in which police cells and lock-ups should be constructed, the way in which police themselves should be trained and made more sensitive to the possibility of depression induced by overconsumption of alcohol, and all these things. I believe that many Australians will benefit from this series of recommendations. That is not to say that as a nation we should not continue to undertake an investigation into the particular phenomenon of Aboriginal deaths in custody which came into special prominence in late 1987.

TALK.START.PARA: —I ask a supplementary question. I thought that the Minister was doing all right up to his concluding remarks. He dealt with some other activities which are very relevant about the number of Aborigines who are taken into custody, but he finished up by saying that he thought there was a reason, when I thought that all the evidence was against it, why there would be a special inquiry into Aboriginal deaths in custody. I ask the Minister two questions which I asked him earlier and which he has not answered. First, how much has the so-called Muirhead inquiry cost so far? Secondly, why will it continue at very great expense when its terms of reference are clearly inappropriate?

—I will undertake to provide the exact sum that has been spent to this stage. I do not have it immediately in front of me. I still believe that this nation-and I believe that this is recognised in the community-has a special concern and interest in those descendants of the indigenous inhabitants of this country who come into conflict with the penal system and find themselves in custody. What is revealed by this set of statistics and what makes the plight of Aboriginal persons different from that of non-Aboriginal Australians is the rate at which they are taken into custody-the alarming and shocking disproportion as to the number of Aborigines who find themselves in custody. In exposing that matter this inquiry would be well justified.

Is it a fact that the Canberra Consumer Affairs Council has not been reappointed and that the Consumer Affairs Bureau is therefore unable to withdraw unsafe products from the market, including children's mirror glasses which shatter and a children's gun using caustic disappearing ink, and that several such products are currently on sale in Canberra? Is it also the case that this situation has existed since 7 September last and is likely to continue until a new council is appointed by the Australian Capital Territories Legislative Assembly-which could take until September when the Assembly sits? Is the Minister concerned about this situation, and will he seek the immediate reappointment of the Consumer Council until new structures are in place, or is his Party prepared to go to the people on Saturday leaving the Australian Capital Territory as a dumping ground for unsafe products?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Richardson Sen The Hon G.F.
ANSWER.MINISTERIAL: ARTS, SPORT, THE ENVIRONMENT, TOURISM AND TERRITORIES

—Did you get your belt and your tie mixed up?

—I would ask Senator Crichton-Browne to restrain his enthusiasm for my attire. He must keep his hands off me after Question Time, please. TALK.START.PARA: —Yesterday I undertook to seek further information from Senator Chaney regarding his question on child poverty. Senator Chaney referred to one of the sources and measures of poverty quoted by Commissioner Burdekin. It should be noted that the Commissioner quoted many others. He did so without endorsing any particular one because all of them are, to a greater or lesser extent, imprecise, value ridden and arbitrary. Commissioner Burdekin points out regarding measures of homelessness:

ANSWER.PARA: It is impossible to state precisely how many homeless children and young people there are in Australia.

Yesterday I said that 400,000 children had been lifted out of poverty under this Government. I wrongly ascribed this view to Commissioner Burdekin. If Senator Chaney's logic is used, he would conclude that this Labor Government has, in fact, lifted 400,000 children out of poverty since 1983 and 200,000 of them since December 1987. The Government knows that such measures of poverty and poverty lines should be used very carefully, if at all. Poverty lines and measures of poverty are always both arbitrary and imprecise. The Henderson poverty line, the most widely known in Australia, has never been endorsed by any government, neither this one nor the previous one. It suffers from a number of problems. Firstly, it is based on household expenditure data derived from a survey completed in New York in the 1950s. Secondly, it suffers from significant delays in updating and constant revisions resulting from national account figures. Thirdly, it suffers from being inevitably arbitrary. For these reasons measures of poverty have always been used with caution in whatever circumstances they may have been used.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Chaney Sen The Hon F.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave-I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Senate take note of the answer given by the Minister for Consumer Affairs (Senator Bolkus) to a Question without Notice asked by Senator Chaney on 28 February 1989, relating to child poverty.

I do not wish to address it at length now, but I say to the Minister for Consumer Affairs (Senator Bolkus) that, having sat in the Senate on many occasions when Australian Labor Party Opposition members interminably went on about the Henderson poverty line, in one sense I welcome the Minister's clear statement that the Government does not accept those lines. There are very many poverty measures. They are not, of themselves, very effective. One of my main reasons for rising to speak now is that I want to give the Minister notice that he can expect further questions on this subject. Whilst it is convenient for the Government in 1989, when it is suddenly faced with the impossibility of meeting the promise made by the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) in 1987 to adopt at last a rational approach to the vexed question of the measurement of poverty and the issue of who in the community is in poverty, how does it, therefore, intend to make judgments about the meeting of the Prime Minister's promise?

I do not think that the Government is in any doubt, any more than the Burdekin inquiry is in any doubt, that there is a very substantial number of children-tens of thousands, if not hundreds of thousands-who are living in hardship and who, on any fair use of the term, could be said to be living in poverty. Those children, children of tender years, who are living on the fringes of our cities without parental care or any other supervision, who are forced to steal, to beg and to prostitute themselves to live, are, on any definition that I would accept, living in poverty. I say to the Minister that it is all very well to throw up these glib statements in an election campaign, but the Opposition expects some clear answers from the Government on how it will measure its performance in this area. We expect something more than the shillyshallying we have had from the Minister over the last two days. We are to debate other matters which go to the problems and concerns of the people of Australia. Therefore, I seek leave to continue my remarks later.
Leave granted; debate adjourned.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Evans Sen The Hon G.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —On 21 December Senator Lewis asked me a question regarding telephone subscribers being charged for international telephone calls which are not being answered and what measures are being taken to overcome the problem. I have a detailed answer for him which I seek leave to incorporate in Hansard.

ANSWER.PARA: Leave granted.
The answer read as follows-

Charging for international Direct Dial (IDD) calls is initiated upon receipt of an answer signal from equipment controlled by the overseas telephone carrier in the destination country. OTC applies tests in its telephone exchanges to confirm that answer signals received from overseas meet stringent technical specifications before being accepted as valid and passed to the calling party's charging equipment in the Telecom network.

However, when such equipment in an overseas country is faulty, a technically valid answer signal may be generated erroneously where a called party has not answered. The incidence of such false answer signals, as revealed through customer enquiry and quality of service testing, is low, and usually associated with those overseas networks which are relatively unsophisticated or poorly maintained. When detected, OTC technical staff investigate and seek to eliminate the fault in cooperation with Telecom and the overseas carrier responsible.

OTC applies comprehensive maintenance procedures in cooperation with overseas carriers and with Telecom to ensure that international signalling systems and switching equipment are functioning correctly. These tests show no evidence of any improper generation of false answer signals from within the OTC or Telecom networks.

While the technical problems are located outside Australia, OTC will investigate complaints and will give consideration to customer's call charge records which indicate suspect charging. It is not the policy of either OTC or Telecom to charge for unsuccessful calls.

INTERJECT.SPEAKER: The PRESIDENT

TALK.START.PARA: —I inform the Senate that I have received the following letter, dated 1 March, from Senator Chaney:

INTERJECT.PARA: Pursuant to Standing Order 64, I give notice that today I propose to move-
``That, in the opinion of the Senate, the following is a matter of urgency:

The suffering of Australian families because of the Government's high taxes and the failure of its economic policies evident in soaring interest rates, rising inflation, the balance of payments crisis and massive and still rising foreign debt and the need for a Mini Budget to address these issues and lay the basis for a more productive society in which effort and enterprise is rewarded.''.
Senator for the State of Western Australia
More than the number of senators required by the Standing Orders having risen in their places-

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Chaney Sen The Hon F.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That, in the opinion of the Senate, the following is a matter of urgency:

The suffering of Australian families because of the Government's high taxes and the failure of its economic policies evident in soaring interest rates, rising inflation, the balance of payments crisis and massive and still rising foreign debt and the need for a Mini Budget to address these issues and lay the basis for a more productive society in which effort and enterprise is rewarded.

In calling for a mini-Budget and for policy change from this Government, the motion reflects the very real desires in the Australian community for change. The desire for a change of policy from this Government is rooted in the simple fact that Australian families are suffering, that they are feeling a great deal of pressure. That pressure flows directly from the outcome of this Government's policies. The pressures flow from high taxes, extremely high interest rates and inflation; for some, a lower real wage than they were getting five years ago; and, for many, a lower real wage after taxes than they were getting five years ago. There is clear evidence of the failure of the Government's economic policies. It goes beyond the impact on individuals. The country can be seen clearly to be living beyond its means in the massive rise in foreign debt, a rise in foreign debt at a time of high commodity prices, and a clear indication that the present policy settings for Australia are unsustainable.

We say, therefore, that there is a need for a mini-Budget. By that we mean not just a change in the financial measures that affect our economy, but a change in all of those policies which hinder the creation of a more productive society. The truth is that we can get out of the difficulties we have as a country, the difficulties that face many Australian individuals, only if we become a more productive and wealthier country. The frightening thing about what is happening to Australia today is that we are seeing declining living standards at a time of increasing debt. Everybody knows that when they are borrowing they can temporarily increase their living standards, but we, when our debt gets higher month by month, are seeing our living standards decline.

I suppose the fact that the Caucus met here on Sunday is an indication of some realisation on the part of the Government that there is concern right around Australia about the policies which are being followed by the Government. The pressure which is out in the electorate and which I referred to is, I suppose, most directly caused by high interest rates over recent months. This is the most obvious symptom. It has the harshest impact on people of the Government's economic policies. When one sees that the prime business lending rate in Australia is now around 17 per cent and compares it with the rates of our competitor countries, one can see how relevant the issue is both to the broad economic health of the country and to what is happening to the people in the cities and suburbs and on the farms of Australia.

New home buyers now face interest rates of 16 per cent. We have had a rapid growth in house prices over the last 12 months. For many young couples who are contemplating the essential activities of forming a family-having children and so on-a normal part of that activity, the owning of a house, is becoming out of their reach. Home loan repayments have risen dramatically over the course of this Government. We are told that the strategy of this Government is to tell us that things might be tough under Hawke but they were worse under Fraser.

When Mr Fraser lost government it took about 19 per cent or so of one's earnings to pay one's mortgage. It is now something like 30 per cent. Average home loan repayments have doubled since 1983. This is one example where the people of Australia can look back, just as they can look back at employment and unemployment, and say that things were a lot better under Mr Fraser for virtually the whole of his Government than they have been for the whole period of the Hawke Government.

On the question of interest rates-this matter impacts most directly on the living standards of all the people of Australia who are at the stage of their life when they are buying a house-one finds this enormous increase in the amount of their disposable income which is required to service the mortgage. As far as taxation is concerned, we have in the broad sense yet another year of record taxation and a record amount of what Australia is producing being taken as tax. To come back to the situation of the average earner, we find that his tax has increased by about 90 per cent to over $126 per week during the period of the Hawke Government. We find that the marginal tax rate-the tax rate that he pays on every extra dollar he earns-has gone from 30c to 40c in the dollar. This year the Federal Government will collect about $82 billion in taxes compared with $41 billion in 1982-83.

The other reason why there is hardship throughout Australia is that the tax system is not only collecting more, it is also collecting it, in many respects, more unfairly, particularly with respect to those people who have dependants. This Government has failed to adjust, at all, the concessions which are contained in the tax and social security systems for those people who have the additional cost of looking after dependants. That has been measured by the Institute of Family Studies, which has said that a couple with three children and on an income of more than $40,000 a year has no more disposable income than a single person on an income of about $24,000 a year. The fact is that the failure to adjust family allowance for all but the poorest families and the failure to adjust the dependent spouse rebate have meant that the limited tax concessions which applied and which gave some relief to people who are looking after dependants have been whittled away in value under the Hawke Government.

We have had a period of high inflation. Compared with other countries, our inflation rate is about twice the average rate. When one looks at the price of basic commodities for Australia such as cars, one finds they have gone up by far more than the inflation rate generally. Since May 1984 the price of a Ford Laser and a Holden Commodore has gone up by more than 70 per cent. It is no wonder that so many people feel that it is beyond their capacity to buy a car. We have had a real disposable income reduction under this Government, which has been measured and talked about a great deal by the Opposition. We have had a reduction of something like $58 a week since Labor took office. It is a figure which has never been successfully or sensibly challenged in this place or anywhere else.

One can sum up the sense of pressure that one gets when one is out in the suburbs by remembering the choices that now face Australians. Does one have children or does one buy a house? The reports that people are postponing having children for up to 10 years in the hope that they will be able to afford to buy a house show an extraordinary change in the structure of Australian society. Let us see what Labor members of Parliament think about it. Mr Ronald Edwards, a very energetic Australian Labor Party member of Parliament, represents the seat of Stirling in Western Australia. Just a few weeks ago he put his views down in a submission to the Australian Electoral Commission as to the redistribution of his electoral boundaries. I got that submission because it makes excellent reading and gives Mr Edwards's assessment of what is happening to the people in the suburbs in his electorate. He is talking in the submission about the estimates of population growth in different areas. He says:

In the light of recent interest rate and housing price rises it is likely that the growth in Mirrabooka will reach the projected figure whilst the growth in Woodvale and Kingsley may fall short of the target. This will be due to the reduction in demand that will occur at the upper end of the market.
He attaches figures to show that some areas have more expensive houses and others have less expensive houses. He says:

The point can be clearly made. If capacity to pay is reduced by reductions in real disposable income and this is coupled with rising prices and rising interests rates then the take-up rate will be lower in general. What will also happen is that demand will increase for cheaper land and houses at the expense of dearer properties. This is an economic reality that must be addressed.

That is Mr Edwards's view of economic reality. People will have to move to cheaper houses in his electorate of Stirling because they face rising interest rates and reductions in real disposable income. He goes on to say:
. . . the market also skew more towards rental propositions and the Mirrabooka Homeswest rental market will play a part here.

In other words, what Mr Edwards, the honourable member for Stirling, is saying is that the people will face declining real income and higher interest rates; and more and more of them will have to throw themselves on the mercy of Homeswest, the State Housing Commission of Western Australia, if they are to have anywhere to live.

It is not surprising that people think something is wrong. They see these changes occurring to their detriment. They see them occurring at a time when the country as a whole is getting steadily more deeply into debt. Gross external debt now exceeds $121 billion, that is, more than $7,000 for every man, woman and child at a time when living standards are declining. We are borrowing more just to service existing debt. Sixty-three cents of every dollar of export income is required to service the debt and to compensate for our deteriorating competitiveness. We have a double whammy. We are getting poorer in terms of our living standards and we are amassing huge debts at the same time.

It is quite clear in those circumstances that the status quo is not good enough. We seek the passage of this motion of urgency this afternoon because we believe it is incumbent on the Government and is utterly necessary for Australia that there be changes of policy. When one looks at the ambitions that the Minister at the table, the Minister for Industry, Technology and Commerce (Senator Button), had for Australia when he set off five or six years ago to change the face of Australia, when one looks at what has happened to productivity in this country and when one compares what is happening with respect to the productivity of Australia and what is happening with respect to the productivity of the rest of the world, one sees nothing but failure. Let me quote from Syntec. Syntec said in a very recent edition:

We deserve a better explanation than we have been getting from the Hawke Government on the series of shocks being received on a fairly regular basis about our external accounts position . . . It is due at least as much to the fact that Australia's unit cost of production is deteriorating so rapidly compared to our trading partners that, increasingly, it is a simple commercial proposition to get supplies from overseas.

No comment could reflect more obviously on the areas to which the Minister at the table, the Minister for Industry, Technology and Commerce, is responsible. We have a situation in which he has done some excellent jaw-boning. He has lectured the people of Australia about the reality of the economy. He has lectured his own Government on the realities of the Australian economy but he has not achieved the policy changes which are necessary to get us out of this stagnant productivity which underlies our increasing debt and our declining living standards.
Put at its most simple, Australia is still living beyond its means. We have to become more productive to reverse that.

TALK.START.PARA: —So you would increase living standards.

—To increase living standards we have to become more productive. What we have to do is to make changes from the approaches that have been adopted by this Government if we are to become competitive enough. What we have is this Government pursuing policies which will not assist us to get out of this bind because they will not make us more competitive. This Minister at the table has got us relying on an interest rate policy that has Australian industry paying 17 per cent interest rates when our Japanese competitors are paying under 4 per cent. He knows that the countries with which he is asking Australian industry to compete do not have to tolerate the high interest rate regime that has been imposed by the Hawke Government. The accord has consistently delivered poor labour productivity and unit labour cost figures. They are poor in that they have been in excess of those of our trading partners. We do not want low wages for the people of Australia. The mixture of government policies has to produce productivity rises which will reduce our unit labour costs, instead of increasing them. That is what our competitors are doing. Australia is not doing it under the arrangements which have the support of this Government. On that score, the accord has failed. As I said before, we are continuing to tax at a record national level.

SPEECH.PARA: Many things need to be done if we are to have a more productive society, if we are to change the culture-to use the Minister's words-if we are to do something about the paralysis that seems to afflict us. We have been assured by the Minister for Finance (Senator Walsh) that there is room for some further reductions in government expenditure. There has to be a continuing effort by government to trim expenditure wherever possible, thus reducing the burden and the cost of government. That must be done to assist in giving responsible tax cuts. It will also reduce the public sector's call on resources and make room for further private sector activity. Fundamental to the changes that we believe are necessary are changes to the labour market, to encourage employers and employees to agree on measures to increase productivity and output and thereby achieve the capacity to pay more realistic higher wages and at the same time to produce greater profits and encourage investment. That is not impossible.

The Minister at the table knows that well-managed enterprises working in close tandem with the work force can achieve great productivity improvement and can break out of the economic bind which generally afflicts us. We have to have an industrial relations system which encourages rather than discourages that. We have to have an industrial relations system which at the same time ensures that the rule of law applies to the trade unions as it applies to the rest of the community. It is now time for taxation reform to reduce the overall tax burden and to provide more incentive for people to work hard and to lift the burden on families. It is central to our approach to the tax system that it is not just a matter of the gross amount of taxes that are collected. Important questions of fairness and equity need to be addressed. I have already said in this speech that under this Government the tax burden on people with dependants has increased in relative terms to the rest of the community. It cannot be fair that those Australians who are supporting a spouse and children or where the two spouses are working and supporting children have seen the terms of trade move against them as severely as they have under this Government. The total failure of the Government to acknowledge the cost of family responsibilities for all but the bottom 15 per cent of families-in income terms-is a national disgrace and something that should be addressed for social and economic reasons.

The Minister at the table knows that there is enormous room for gain through privatisation and deregulation to increase competition. He knows that the rate of loading and unloading containers in Australia is a disgrace, compared with the rate in the rest of the world. He knows that the rate of packing and unpacking containers is a disgrace compared with the rate in the rest of the world. He knows that the cost to Australian industry of coastal shipping is a disgrace, as are numerous other areas. For example, the transport of grain is another such area. It was identified by an independent inquiry put in place by his own Government. There are gains to be made in that area. He knows that increased competition in telecommunications and in transport generally can be used to break us out of the economic bind in which we find ourselves. All these changes are practical and feasible and the only thing stopping the Government from implementing them is lack of political will. It is time that we ceased hearing from Mr Keating the reasons why things cannot be done and started hearing about the things that can and will be done to change the position.

I conclude by referring to a speech made by Sir Arvi Parbo just last weekend. Sir Arvi Parbo is the head of major corporations in this country, but he started life as a migrant. He gained his education and worked through the mining industry to attain the position of great influence he holds today. Few businessmen give better advice to all of us and to the country in general than Sir Arvi Parbo. He made the point in his speech that we start with the proposition that it is hard to imagine a country with more advantageous circumstances than we have. We have the ability to produce food and fibres and every mineral. We have more than adequate land, an excellent climate, no pollution problems worth speaking about, few natural disasters, no real racial problems, a literate population, freedom from terrorism, and a position as part of the fastest growing economic area in the world. Nobody can gainsay the advantages we have in Australia. The truth is that we have failed to take advantage of them; instead we stagnate as our productivity figures demonstrate. Our economy is indeed troubled, as the debt figures indicate. Last Saturday, Sir Arvi Parbo said:

Our basic need is for better performance. This includes working harder, but it means much more than that. It means improving our skills, removing artificial obstacles to the efficient functioning of the economy and, above all, developing a community attitude which supports and applauds achievement. It means encouraging, not discouraging, the natural desire of individuals to improve themselves.

In far too many areas, the policies of this Government fail to meet the simple prescription Sir Arvi Parbo gave us last weekend. We believe that changes need to be made now. We call for a mini-Budget and the accompanying policy changes which will break us out of a cycle of stagnation.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Button Sen The Hon J.N.

TALKER.NAME: Senator BUTTON
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Industry, Technology and Commerce)

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Deputy President, a week or so ago--
—Where is your team?

—In respect of what I have to say I do not need the degree of support which Senator Chaney needs. I understand he needs psyching up when he makes a speech of that kind. A week ago I had the chance to watch television and I saw a film which I had not seen before called Out of Africa. I was reminded of the film as Senator Chaney spoke.
—Perhaps if you spent less time watching television and did a bit of work you would get somewhere.

—Senator Chaney is getting very personal. He is attacking my productivity now. He said that I am not allowed to watch films. I saw the film called Out of Africa and I was reminded of it when Senator Chaney was speaking, because Senator Chaney is a refugee from the Fraser Government years, the darkest period in Australian economic history.
—Ha, ha!

—Senator Stone has to laugh, because most of the remedies prescribed were devised by him in that period. In that dark period, what progress was made in terms of restructuring Australian industry, opening up the Australian economy, productivity, or any of the other things mentioned by Senator Chaney which he sees as being very important? Senator Chaney finished his speech with a quote from that great sage of Australian industry, Arvi Parbo.
—That is right. Kick him in the guts too.

—I am not going to do that. Senator Hill should not anticipate. Senator Chaney finished his speech with a quotation from Arvi Parbo. I remember Arvi Parbo walking out of a Business Council meeting in September last year and, when asked about the Australian economy and industry, saying, `I am very happy'.
—What was the price of nickel and gold then?

—It had nothing to do with the prices of nickel and gold. He was talking about the sorts of issues which Senator Chaney raised today. I do not point an accusing finger at Senator Stone in relation to this, but Arvi Parbo was in the same state of mind in September last year as most of the other economic commentators, members of the Government and members of the Opposition were on the very important issue of the current account. He was in the same state of mind as everybody else.
—Are you happy about it?

—I am not happy about anything. I am by nature a sombre sort of person. One cannot be happy about these things. The essence of Senator Chaney's argument-just to simplify it before dealing with it in any detail-is to say that the community has felt a bit of a squeeze lately and many people are experiencing difficulties because of low disposable household incomes, interest rates and the like. That is, of course, true. Every year since we have been in government Senator Chaney and his mates have been up on their feet objecting to any wage increase in this country. That is disposable income for the average Australian household. The Opposition has objected to every wage increase since this Government came to office.
—You know this is a specious argument.

—It is not a specious argument at all. It is absolutely true and the honourable senator does not like it. Senator Messner asked me a question yesterday. I think it was a very good question: Can this economy afford a wage increase and a tax cut? That is a very good and legitimate question-which has to be asked.
—Without any productivity increase.

—Senator Stone, as is his habit, has interjected again-he cannot resist it-about productivity. I was going to come to that a little later. Of course, there is a lot of concern about productivity. I just remind Senator Stone that, in a discussion of productivity issues, it is very difficult to measure productivity in the aggregate. This country has had the highest employment growth rate in the Organisation for Economic Cooperation and Development (OECD), which goes right to the question of how one measures productivity in a growing work force. When we came into government there were 250,000 people that the Liberal Party had flung out of work in a couple of years.
—No, that was your trade union mates who flung them out of work as the Treasurer said at the Labor Party conference in Hobart 18 months ago.

—Senator Stone has time to make a speech later. Senator Stone would like to think it was our trade union mates. It was his Prime Minister who walked away from the wages issue. Those opposite walked away from the wages issue-all of them over there-and what did they get? They got a 16 per cent increase in wages in one year, 17 per cent the next. That is what they got, and Senator Stone blames the trade unions for that. The Fraser Government was incapable of handling the trade unions. That is why it got those results. It was incapable of handling trade unions, because the royal wedding was more important to the Prime Minister than the economy of Australia. That was the truth of it in those dark out-of-Africa days, where members of the Opposition all belong. That was the truth of it. It suits Senator Stone now to blame the trade union movement for that. It was a crisis of Government policy from which the Government of the day walked away.

SPEECH.PARA: As I said, it is very difficult to make these glib judgments about productivity in Australia when one has the enormous employment growth which we have seen-1.3 million jobs in the period of this Government. That issue alone goes to the question of the living standards of many Australians. If people are concerned about living standards, let them think about 1982. The people who in 1982 were walking the streets looking for jobs knew something about declining living standards. This Government has seen and presided over an employment growth--

TALK.START.PARA: —Nothing to do with the national recession? Nothing to do with the drought?
—An awful lot to do with what Senator Stone interjected about a minute ago.
—Nothing to do with those factors?

—An awful lot to do with that. Sixteen per cent and 17 per cent wage increases. That is what it had to do with. That was the problem which caused the recession, amongst everything else, in 1982. If I might come back to one or two of Senator Chaney's major points, he said people are feeling the squeeze. We concede that. That is why in April of this year we will be making an important announcement about tax cuts.
—When do they come through?

—Senator Walters interjects `if they come through'. The only tax cuts in my memory that have not come through were offered by her Government in December 1977-the `fistful of dollars' offered by the Liberal Government, taken away five months later. That was an election bribe in order to win an election. They are the only tax cuts that I remember which have not come through. Every tax cut offered by this Government has come through. Every wage increase negotiated by this Government has come through, and Senator Walters should not get herself into silly interjections like that.
—What about a capital gains tax? Did that come through?
—Order! The Chair would like to hear Senator Button's speech.
—Thank you, Mr Acting Deputy President. It is an enormous tribute to what I am saying.
—There will be no capital gains tax.
—What about the wine tax?
—Gold tax?
—A sales tax on the kids' icecream?

—The burden of Senator Chaney's speech is that we should bring in a mini-Budget and cut government expenditure. The Budget has two sides: revenue and expenditure. I have had five interjections in the last minute which suggest that the Liberal Party, if it ever got into government, would abolish all of those taxes. Is that correct?
—We did not say that. We were naming your promises.

—This is where the great weakness lies in Senator Chaney's argument, which I must say was very well put in terms of a mixture of economic irrationality, no substance in fundamental economic terms and a lot of emotive considerations which he hopes will appeal to the electorate. I want to come to the `what needs to be done' sections of Senator Chaney's speech in a moment.

SPEECH.PARA: I was trying to make the point that Senator Chaney said that some people in the community have suffered as a result of the economic changes which have taken place and the need to reduce the Australian standard of living in the period we have just been through. We have never run away from that issue. Senator Chaney listed a whole range of consequences of that. Then he said that we should cut government expenditure further. Where is that going to be done? The Liberal Party is peculiarly hesitant about telling us where that is going to be done. I will tell the Senate where it would be done, if the Liberal Party ever get a chance at it. It would be done in terms of social welfare benefits and things of that kind. Senator Chaney said, `These are the people who have suffered most, but we have to cut government expenditure further'.

He said in the course of his remarks that there should be further reductions in government expenditure but he was very coy about telling us where. He then went on to a number of other things such as needing to reduce the tax burden. As I have said, Government will be addressing this issue of the tax burden in April, not just as it relates to salary and wage earners but as it affects other people in the community. Senator Chaney went on to talk about changes to the labour market. He knows full well that these things are not achievable overnight with the wave of some sort of magic wand from governments.

TALK.START.PARA: —Look at our amendments to the Industrial Relations Bill. We gave you a perfect chance.

—We had a good debate about that at the time, which I think went for 21 hours in the Senate. Senator Crichton-Browne took about 19 of them. I do not see any point in his interjecting now. We just did not accept his view.

SPEECH.PARA: The very important thing is that, in terms of wage increases, this Government asked for something back. The very encouraging thing in terms of award restructuring goes very much to the question of productivity, which has been raised by way of interjection here by a number of speakers. There are, of course, already available isolated examples of what we mean by this. The Williamstown dockyard in Melbourne is a classic example of an organisation which was run down, overstaffed, maladministered in the period of the Fraser Government.

TALK.START.PARA: —What brought that about?

—Government policy brought it about. It is no good bleating away about this. Government policy brought that about, and if Senator Stone is not prepared to acknowledge that he is a mean-spirited soul. Government policy brought that about, did it not?
—No.

—Something else, such as the H. R. Nicholls Society, I suppose, brought it about? Government policy brought it about. In relation to award restructuring, that is very important to the question of productivity.

SPEECH.PARA: Senator Chaney departed a little from his text to give me a spray about interest rates and living standards, the failure of the accord, and all those things. We have very high terms of trade at present. The incapacity of the previous Government in 1981-82 to handle that was the ruination of that Government. That will not happen to us because of the policies that we have in place, because we will produce a wages outcome this year which, consistent with the needs which Senator Chaney refers to, of better remuneration for wage earners, will also be consistent with the needs of the Australian economy in terms of handling that current account problem.

Senator Chaney offered some sort of cursory comments about comparative figures about inflation and things like that. Senator Chaney had better catch up on some of those figures about inflation next time he makes a speech because he cannot make the same comparisons that he did last year when talking about comparative inflation rates. Have a look at the United States rate, for example. That was Senator Chaney's big figure last year.

I will just sum up. The question that Senator Chaney addresses is this: Some people have been aggrieved, and we understand that, by the decline of standard of living in the community. The greatest burden in the decline of standard of living in the Australian community has been borne by wage earners. It is time some of the Opposition members began to acknowledge that. That is why the Government is seeking to arrive this year at a wage-tax trade-off which will ensure increased wages and more progressive tax reductions, which will benefit lower income earners. That is why we are doing that. That is the solution which the Government is proffering to this problem in times of very difficult economic circumstances which the country is currently in. That deals, in some part, with the question of the burden.

The other sector of the community which Senator Chaney would like to allege has borne the burden is what might be broadly described as the welfare sector. Over a period the Government has really made an enormous contribution to the welfare sector. I want to just put two figures in Senator Chaney's mind. I am not talking about welfare when I say this. If the Opposition's policies had been followed in relation to wages, every family in Australia would be 34 per cent worse off than they are now.

TALK.START.PARA: —What rubbish! Are you saying the inflation rate would have been exactly the same?

—No. I was prompted to say this by the ludicrous figure which is touted around by the Opposition about $58 in relation to families. In terms of social welfare beneficiaries, let me just give the Senate a few figures. Social security supplements for children have been raised from $10 per week in March 1983, when we came into government, to $24 per week in 1988, a real increase of 60 per cent. This Government stands by its commitment to raise combined family allowance and family supplement payments to 15 per cent of the married pension rate by 1990. We have provided an increase in rent assistance to low income families. Medicare is saving families-I am not sure what the current fad over on the Opposition benches is in relation to health insurance-$21 a week.
—Which families?
—Not the very rich ones, Senator. We have increased education allowances, including more than doubling the rate for 16-and 17-year-old secondary students.
—It is no use quoting figures if you don't tell us who they apply to.

—I have really had a fair swag of interjections during my remarks. No doubt Senator Walters will be contributing later. We have provided nearly 80,000 additional higher education places up to 1988. That is over the period we have been in government and something which was never done by the previous Government. We have created 64,000 child care places. By 1992 we will have 30,000 more. None of these things was done by the previous Government. Real public housing funds have doubled during the first five years.
—And waiting lists have nearly doubled-60,000 more on the public waiting list.

—Waiting lists have increased because of the unavailability of land for houses. It is not a demand problem; it is a supply problem. That is essentially the problem in delays for housing. All these things might be unpalatable to members of the Opposition, but of course they are all factual and for that reason they interject throughout my speech. I very much regret that because it is very difficult to try to assist honourable senators on the other side of the House by answering ill-informed interjections at the same time as developing the theme.
—Order! The honourable senator's time has expired.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Haines Sen J.

TALK.START.PARA: —Senator Button concluded his contribution to this debate by stringing out for us a list of things which he claims the Government has done to benefit Australian families. The Government may well have done some of the things that he listed, but I am not sure that the impact on Australian families has been as great as he hoped, given that at the same time this Government has taken a great deal away from the same Australian families. There can be no question at all but that Senator Chaney is quite correct in his assessment of the suffering that is being undergone by a large number of ordinary Australian families. They are feeling the pinch in no uncertain terms. Interest rates are soaring, house and land prices are soaring, and the cost of ordinary household goods is increasing as government sales taxes are increased and extended. On the other hand, the price of goods has failed to fall as it should have in the past quarter with the rise of the Australian dollar because companies are profit taking presumably because they can see some hardship facing them in the near future.

SPEECH.PARA: As Senator Button claims, the Government has made some improvements in education payments for 16- and 17-year-olds, but it cut Austudy to 15-year-olds in their last two years of school and that affected a significant number of low income families in South Australia and Western Australia. If he does not believe this, maybe he should take some of the phone calls that I have had to take from women in tears because they were faced with the prospect of having to take a 15-year-old out of school because they had lost that $40 a week in Austudy payments purely because in South Australia the majority of students in year 11 are still aged 15, apparently unlike the case in New South Wales and Victoria, and they were being penalised for that fact.

Family allowances are now means tested-flying in the face of the fact that not all the money that is earned by the sole breadwinner is shared equitably with many Australian families. Pensions and benefits have been cut. The disposable income of most Australian families has been reduced over the last five years of this Labor Government. I might add that most of those damaging pieces of legislation-cuts to family allowances, taking widows off the class B widow's pension when they get to 45 years of age and putting them on unemployment benefits, cutting Austudy payments, reducing ex-service pensions, delaying the consumer price index increases -have got through this Parliament only because they had the support of the Opposition parties. So it is a bit cheeky of Senator Chaney, having contributed to the problem, to then complain about it. But it does not alter the fact that it was the Government initiatives that led to these problems.

Then we have that age-old problem of bracket creep, meaning that most Australian families are paying excessive tax and have been given fewer opportunities during the life of this Parliament and this Government in particular to decrease this exorbitant amount of tax through tax deductions. Over the past decade both governments have cut concessions to ordinary Australian families. At the same time, they have increased assistance to businesses, often with no resultant increase in productivity or employment so that some companies in this country are proudly asserting, as Alan Bond did last year to the Australian Financial Review, that they will be paying no tax at all in the next financial year. Yet many pensioners in this country are paying in tax 50c out of every dollar they earn over the prescribed amount.

We allow the continuation of tax concessions to businesses that reduce their contributions to Consolidated Revenue to nil. Some of the biggest companies in this country are at fault. Some of the biggest companies in this country are paying less than 10c in the dollar in tax, some of them less than one cent in the dollar and companies such as the Bond Corporation, no tax at all in the financial year 1989-90. On top of this, this Government, with the support of the Opposition parties, saw fit to cut nominal company tax by 20 per cent and when we moved last year to have that cut held over until personal tax cuts were introduced at the same level we got no support at all. What has happened is what we predicted would happen then-that the Government would come into the new year claiming that economic conditions were so bad that it could not see its way clear to offering the promised personal tax cuts. So while companies, many of whom are paying no tax or very little tax, are benefiting from a 20 per cent tax cut, Australian families look like benefiting very little indeed in those areas.

In the meantime the Treasurer (Mr Keating) is complaining that Australians are not saving and, worse, that they are spending as if there will be no tomorrow and they are spending largely on imported goods. We might well ask, `Why are they spending on imported goods?'. Of course, the answer is that our manufacturing sector has not got off its butt sufficiently in the last couple of decades to be producing the sorts of export items that we need to produce a decent balance of trade figure, nor has it gone into any innovative areas where import replacement items are being produced.

TALK.START.PARA: —Was he wearing his Italian suit at the time?

—Senator Stone asks whether Mr Keating was wearing his Italian suit at the time. The answer is probably yes since I understand that that is all he wears. Of course, that raises the question of what we are doing in this country with regard to decreasing the consumption of luxury imported goods. The answer is: very little indeed. The Government should impede the purchase of a significant proportion of luxury imported goods simply by placing a luxury tax on things such as Rolls Royces, imported Italian suits, furs and so on. But it is not prepared to offend its wealthy backers in this way and it continues to penalise ordinary Australian families by cutting back on their benefits, complaining at the same time that those same families are refusing to put their money in the bank. That is hardly surprising. If they put their money in the bank they lose most of the interest they earn in tax. Senator Chaney was talking earlier about the need to bring questions of fairness and equity into the open so that we can address them. But if we look at the situation of Australian families vis-a-vis that of Australian companies we find that the tax concessions offered to the latter far exceed those applying to Australian families. I agree with Senator Chaney; we need to do something about introducing a bit of fairness and equity into the system. That means looking at why Australian families are not saving and what we can do to encourage them to save.
