Mr Keating says that, while Australians are spending as they are on imported goods, we have a grossly distorted balance of trade figure and that this is causing economic problems in the country. This will lead to harsher conditions being applied to those same families that are already feeling the brunt of this Government's policies.

SPEECH.PARA: One of the quickest ways of encouraging people to save is to reduce the tax burden that they face if they do save. I hope that the Opposition's expression of concern about the need for Australian families to own their own homes will lead it to support a couple of the legislative measures that we have introduced this week; namely, to allow some tax concession with regard to the interest paid on home loans, which was something that existed during the last years of the Fraser Government when Mr Howard was Treasurer, and to give a tax exemption to at least part of the interest that people earn in savings accounts that they place with banks, building societies and other organisations that lend for housing.

As Senator Chaney said, something has to be done to balance the equation that is distorting this country's economy. Apparently, we allow unlimited foreign investment in this country in a way which does not happen anywhere else. That foreign investment includes a capacity for people from outside this country to buy Australian real estate. Inevitably, that pushes up the price of land and housing, putting it further beyond the reach of Australian families, even assuming that they can afford the burgeoning interest rates. We have a government and an opposition that support a deregulated financial market and that, in turn, with reduced savings means increased pressure through people wishing to borrow.

The business community is not too worried about interest rates. After all, if it borrows at 16 per cent, because it can write it off against its tax, it is paying an effective rate of 8 per cent, or at least it was when nominal company tax was 49c in the dollar. It is getting a slightly less good deal now; nevertheless, it is paying significantly less than the 16 per cent at which it is borrowing. An individual who borrows to buy a home or a home unit which he or she intends to rent to somebody else also gets that capacity to negatively gear, to write off the interest payment against his or her tax. The only people in Australia who do not get that sort of tax concession at the moment are those people who are borrowing money to put a roof over their heads and their children's heads. I think it is important that we follow the example of both Britain and the United States of America so that some sort of tax concession on the interest on home loans is allowed to Australian families. It has not broken the back of the American and British economies and it certainly will not break the back of the Australian economy if Australians are given that sort of tax concession.

In the last day or two the Treasurer has made some fairly unkind comments about suggestions from some of his own Ministers, some of his own backbenchers, some members of the Opposition and the Australian Democrats that a smidgin of tax relief should be given to people on the savings that they put in banks and building societies. He is arguing that, if we allow, as has been suggested, the first $2,000 of interest earned on certain savings accounts in those sorts of institutions to be tax free it will distort the system. The system is already distorted when some people can get tax concessions and others cannot. But leaving that to one side, either the Treasurer wants people to save and not spend or he does not. If he does, he has to be prepared to forgo some tax revenue in order to achieve what he says he wants to achieve.

We need only look to the example of Japan to see what intrinsic benefits there are to encourage savings. The Japanese Government made a deliberate decision after World War II that it needed access to as much money as possible in order to reconstruct a country that had been devastated during the war. It, therefore, allowed people to save tax free as far as interest was concerned. That country now has the equivalent of about $US2.5 trillion in savings. The results of that saving and the access to investment money through borrowings on it can be seen by anyone who visits Japan, anyone who looks at its domestic surplus, anyone who looks at its trade balance, anyone who looks at its innovative manufacturing sector, and anyone who looks at that nation's development. The Japanese did it, at least in part, by the simple expedient of encouraging people to save. There is no point in Senator Chaney coming forward with a matter of urgency-the Australian Democrats will support it-which talks about the suffering of Australian families because of high taxes, high interest rates, the failure of the Government's economic policies, rising inflation, the balance of payments crisis and the still rising foreign debt, most of which is contributed to by foreign borrowings by private sector companies, if the Opposition and the Government are not prepared to take some fairly simple, equitable and fair steps to correct the imbalance that is there and to give Australian families some of the tax concessions, some of the tax benefits, some of the assistance which, for the last decade or more, has been pouring into Australian companies with no valuable result that any of us can perceive.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Stone Sen J.O.

TALKER.NAME: Senator STONE
TALKER.ROLE: Leader of the National Party of Australia)

TALK.START.PARA: —I support the urgency motion which has been put before us this afternoon by Senator Chaney because there is not the slightest doubt that today we are confronted with a situation of suffering by Australian families due to this Government's high taxes and the failure of its economic policies. This failure is evident in almost every aspect of the economic scene. Take, for example, the first element of that failure mentioned in Senator Chaney's motion: soaring interest rates. Today we have a situation where the short term interest rates in this country as measured by bank bill rates have risen by nearly seven percentage points since the end of 1987. In the past 14 months we have had a seven percentage point increase in interest rates.

SPEECH.PARA: In the Business Review Weekly of 24 February 1989 there is an article by Dr Ed Shann, who at one stage worked for me in the Treasury but who is now employed doing better things. He points out what has happened to the relationship between short term bond rates and long term bond rates in the course of the last year or so in this country. He points out that a year ago long term bond rates were 3 per cent higher than short term rates and now they are about 3 1/4 per cent lower. That switch into an inversion of the relationship between the short term rates and the long term rates is a dangerous phenomenon, the results of which are being seen in this country as in many other countries before. On that matter Dr Shann concludes that we are building for a fall; we are building towards a recession. But he points out that so far as the balance of payments is concerned, the fact is that with exports unlikely to be rising much next year any solution to the balance of payments means that imports must fall. He goes on to say that they have only ever fallen in Australia if domestic demand has been falling-not just growing slowly, but falling-or if we have been in a recession.

Let me take one aspect of the interest rates-the big picture, as the Treasurer (Mr Keating) would call it, on interest rates. Then let us take what might be described as the `little picture', although it is pretty big to individuals who are confronted by it and that is, of course, the subject of home mortgage rates.

Home mortgage rates today are roughly 15.5 per cent, in some cases 16 per cent. They will almost certainly rise to 16 per cent generally before many more weeks have passed. The Treasurer's views on that matter were given in a fascinating interview with Miss Michelle Grattan in the Melbourne Age last Monday, when he was asked when home owners could expect some relief in their mortgage rates. The Treasurer at that time said:
Bear in mind that 40 per cent of mortgages are still enjoying the 13.5 per cent ceiling.

I think I would have to tell the Treasurer that anyone who has a mortgage rate of 13.5 per cent is not enjoying anything. Such a person might regard himself or herself as fortunate by comparison with other less fortunate fellow mortgage holders who are paying 15 1/2 per cent or 16 per cent, but I would not think that he or she would be `enjoying' the situation. I make that point in order to flag another point-namely, the capacity of our Treasurer to tell a different story whenever the circumstances suit him. That article appeared in last Monday's Melbourne Age-no doubt the interview was given a couple of days earlier. On Monday evening in the Australian Broadcasting Corporation's program Four Corners, what did the Treasurer have to say about mortgage interest rates? On that occasion in response to a comment by one of his interviewers he said:

The only thing I'd say to her about that is when we had the old days of 13 1/2 per cent loans, which some people still have, they only had it for 20,000 (dollars) or 30,000 (dollars) worth of the mortgage, they'd then have to go and find another 30,000 (dollars) worth in the secondary market and then they'd get a personal loan . . .

That is, at a higher interest rate. He was talking about the well known interest rate cocktail phenomenon which was a feature of the situation when housing interest rates were totally regulated. The Treasurer in his statement on Monday night was basically saying that people who had 13.5 per cent loans did not really benefit much at that time because they had to get the other half of their cocktail at much, much higher rates compared with the situation today. Yet in his interview with Miss Grattan he points to 40 per cent of those people as still enjoying 13 1/2 per cent mortgages. That is an example of the capacity of our Treasurer to change his story depending on the circumstances. My goodness, he has had a lot of occasions in the past six months or so to do just that. It is no wonder that Mr Keating's credibility is now wearing thin, even within those quarters-the Press Gallery in this place-which have contained his most persistent adulators in the past.

Let us have a look at another example of the Treasurer's story having to be changed because in the end the facts will out. It is the question of rising inflation referred to in Senator Chaney's motion. One will recall that rising inflation was referred to by the Treasurer in his Budget Speech as `Australia's most important economic disease'. Inflation was 7.7 per cent in the 12 months to the December quarter of last year. That compares with the Treasurer's Budget time forecast that it would fall to 4.5 per cent by June of this year. We are told by the press this week that some disquiet has been expressed by the Australian Labor Party Caucus meeting at the weekend because there was evidence showing up in its research that the Party's stocks with women were falling. Well, no wonder. Notwithstanding our more enlightened age, in this country women usually still do the shopping. Inflation is brought home to them every time they do the shopping.

Another area where the Treasurer's credibility has been shot to pieces in the past six months and which is also referred to in Senator Chaney's motion is the balance of payments crisis. The Treasurer in his Budget Speech referred to the balance of payments as Australia's most serious economic problem. We have had a series of successively discredited Keating forecasts for our balance of payments outcome for 1988-89 over the period since the Budget was brought down. In the Budget itself, the Treasurer forecast a deficit for this year of $9,500m. Within less than a month of that figure being published leaks were emanating from the Treasurer or his office or the Department to the effect that the actual outcome was more likely to be about $10 1/2 billion.

After the November balance of payments figures appeared the Treasurer held a press conference at which he said that he hoped the final outcome for the financial year 1988-89 would be not worse than last year's figure, which was $12.3 billion. This is the ever escalating forecast. After the January figures were released a fortnight or so ago, the Treasurer held another press conference at which he said that he now hoped the balance of payments deficit for 1988-89 would be of about the same proportion of our gross domestic product as for last year, which was 4.2 per cent-that is, about $14 billion.

Professor Barry Hughes, to whom our attention was directed yesterday by the Minister for Finance, Senator Walsh, has put forward in a most interesting paper some forecasts which run a good deal higher than that. There is very little point in debating the odd billion or two because the real point is that the Treasurer's forecasts have been so far out that there is no longer the slightest faith out there in the financial markets in the credibility of any forecast or other economic policy prognostication issued by the present Government. I should add that emanating from Professor Hughes's paper is a most interesting passage. At one time Professor Hughes was Mr Keating's own personal economic adviser-in fact, during the latter part of my period in the Treasury. Professor Hughes said, among other things:
Our central message-
that is, the central message of the paper he had written for the First Boston Corporation-

is that a monetary policy stance aimed at creating a 1986-style flattening of domestic demand and consequent major reduction in . . . imports is unlikely to be fierce enough to produce an acceptable annual bottom line-
that is, for the balance of payments-
by early 1990.

That is, early next year-a year hence. What about the still rising foreign debt? When this Government came to office our net debt to foreigners was less than $20 billion. At September last year it was over $93 billion. In the last few days this Government has congratulated itself on the fall of about 10 per cent in the value of the Australian dollar against foreign currencies. When it does so, it might bear in mind that the value of our outstanding debt, or at least that part of it denominated in foreign currencies, has just jumped by about 10 per cent, and so of course has the cost of servicing that debt, which, I might add, is already running at over $8 billion a year in interest costs alone. In the last week or so our Government has pushed that cost up by anything up to $800m a year by the intemperate statements of the Treasurer and the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke). That figure will depend on the amount of our total foreign debt that is denominated in foreign currencies, which is at least half.

What is the Government's policy on this? The Government's policy is to concur with the demand of the Australian Council of Trade Unions (ACTU) that we have a tax cut equal to $20 a week and a wage increase close to $30 a week. How is the Australian economy supposed to deliver that increase in real incomes, and hence in real purchasing power, when we are already living beyond our means internationally by an amount of $14 billion to $15 billion this year alone and raising our international debts accordingly, or selling off bits of Australia accordingly, in order to finance that process of living beyond our national means? Has the Treasurer or Senator Button, who spoke earlier in this debate, given the slightest explanation of how that can be done?

The only mention Senator Button made of increasing productivity, which is the only way in which it can be done other than by fortuitous means such as a further rise in our international terms of trade-that is, the price at which we sell our exports, et cetera-was the flippant reference to Williamstown Dockyard. It was a good reference in one way because it illustrated a more general point. After an extraordinary amount of harassment by the trade unions at Williamstown Dockyard, the managers and employers sacked the whole work force. The workers were out for over three months. At the end of that time they came back and the Government got some sense in the work practices on the site. I presume the analogy that Senator Button has in mind is that this Government is about to sack the whole Australian work force. At the end of that time, it might get some sense out of its trade union mates in the ACTU as to how we can get some sense of desperate need for better productivity in this country, which is the only remedy for our present problem.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The honourable senator's time has expired.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Cooney Sen B.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —The debate has raged about a topic which has become familiar, and quite properly so, in this chamber and the other place-that is, how the economy ought to be run. The Opposition has been joined by the Australian Democrats in pointing out the problems the economy faces. It has pointed out that rising interest rates impact heavily on people, particularly those purchasing homes. Quite clearly, things must be done but, in typical fashion, the Opposition does not come up with the answers, other than suggesting that we should bring about a recession so that people will not be able to spend as much and therefore will not be able to buy imported goods and thereby the balance of payments will be redressed in some measure. That is a very pessimistic and harsh recipe to effect a cure for Australia's economic ills.

SPEECH.PARA: Is it proper, as the other side would suggest, to bring about a recession, or even worse, which would impact particularly heavily on those most vulnerable in society? The alternative suggestion-to be fair to Senator Stone, he suggested this at the end of his speech-is an increase in productivity. I hope I have properly accounted for what Senator Stone said in that regard. Of course productivity should be increased. If productivity is brought to a proper level it will go a long way to solving Australia's problems. However, to say simply that there ought to be an increase in productivity and not go on to suggest a formula or policy or program by which productivity can be increased seems to me not to be meeting the needs of the hour.

TALK.START.PARA: —Equally, to suggest that the country can afford a tax cut of $20 and a wage rise of $30 is just not addressing the problem.

—Senator Stone says that we cannot have tax cuts and wage increases unless productivity improves. I accept that. It is to that end that the Australian Council of Trade Unions has suggested-Senator Stone says that the ACTU is in some way an evil force in the land-that there ought to be award restructuring. That is based on the proposition that productivity ought to be encouraged in a way which is consistent with this community, as a united force, going forward to do something about the balance of payments and this country's economic problems. Certainly we shall not reach that position by setting up an antagonistic camp with the employers on one side and the employees on the other. What would happen would be not an increase in productivity, but a return to the bad old days which predated this Government with armed camps at war, suspicious of each other, and not working together to increase productivity. This Government's policy involves an accord which envisages employers and employees sitting down together and discussing how productivity can be increased and success achieved.
—But it has not been achieved.

—It has been achieved, Senator Messner, and I will give one example. The waterside unions have been much criticised, but let me give an example of what has happened on the Melbourne waterside over the last 18 months. In Melbourne is a depot where the LCLs, or less than container loads, are unpacked. The employers asked the waterside workers to unload five of these containers over a period of seven hours, after which the workers could then go home. That standard was set by the employers. The employees, through their union, said `If incentives are in the right place, there is a better way in which this shed can be made productive so that LCLs can be properly dealt with'. To their credit, the employers listened and put the scheme into operation. In the last 18 months there has been an increase of 200 per cent in the productivity in that shed. That is an example of what can be done through cooperation and if employers and employees, through their unions, sit down and state the ground rules. That is what can happen if there is mutual trust.
—How did the situation originate?

—I am asked how this originated, but if we are to go into recriminations, apportioning blame and discussing where past blame has lain, we will get nowhere. Problems such as those on the Melbourne waterside should be analysed, and people should be optimistic and look to the future. If such an attitude is taken, what has happened on the Melbourne waterfront can be repeated throughout the land, and in certain areas it has been repeated. That attitude will lead to increased productivity and that, as Senator Stone said, will lead us in large measures towards solving our problems. By so doing we can bring down interest rates and give people what they deserve, and in that way Australia can go forward. But unless we understand that every section of the community can work together and that the basis of the accord is correct, I am afraid that we shall have a very pessimistic future.

SPEECH.PARA: It has been said that the sufferings of Australian families should be taken account of and that their problems have occurred as a result of Government policies. Let me make it clear that during these hard economic times we have been through the Government has encouraged productivity and community cooperation, but at the same time the Government has looked to the needs of those who are vulnerable and has done something about them. In other words, Government effort has gone to assist the family, and the family assistance scheme is a great illustration. Let me give an example of a family consisting of mother, father and three children, with an income in the way of earnings of $16,800, with two of the children aged between 13 and 15 and with one child under 13. The family rents privately and currently receives $101 per week tax free-which when added to the wage coming into that family is equivalent to $25,000 a year. The only other way that family could reach such an amount would be by way of a 50 per cent wage increase.

That process operates in two ways. It introduces into that family a much needed injection of income, and also does so without imposing on the community the effects of a huge rise of 50 per cent. About 140,000 low income families receive assistance under the family assistance scheme. The average payment under that scheme is $40 a week, which is tax free. That is a good state of affairs and is consistent with the Government's policy of helping those in need in the most economic way-a way which does not have an impact on the wage structure of this country.

I wish to emphasise two points in debating this matter of urgency. First, it is true that there are economic problems. Of the various solutions advanced by various groups in the community, including the Opposition, the Australian Democrats and the Government, I believe that the Government's solution has the most chance of success. That program involves going forward in a cooperative spirit so that workers and employers can sit down and talk about restructuring and how work practices can be adjusted in order to increase productivity. In that way of cooperation, based on the accord, one can go forward to increasing the wealth of the community.

Secondly, in circumstances where hard times have had their effect on families, the Government has focused on assisting those who are the most vulnerable. It has taken action through the family assistance scheme, through the child welfare scheme, Medicare and a whole variety of social welfare and social justice schemes. This has created a situation in which there has not been, as would be the case in a recession, any fearful impact on those who are least able to bear it.

That is the way forward. Certainly the way forward is not to follow Lego economics involving adjustments here and there, bearing down the wages, putting people into recession and pulling levers to achieve a result. The Government is saying to the people of this country that attitudes are changing and must change even more. It is saying that if there is a sense of fairness in the community, these problems will be solved. Such a course had not been suggested by the Opposition. The Opposition has simply raised issues and, as usual, come up with answers which, if put into operation, would simply fail.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Messner Sen The Hon A.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —It is easy to be negative about the Government's economic performance because there is much to be negative about. First, we have seen the enormous Budget blow-out in terms of the raising of taxes and the new taxes which have been put on the Australian people by this Government since it came to power. These taxes have led to a great lack of incentive in the community to work hard. Secondly, in recent times we have seen Budget figures set down only in August last being blown out of the water by inflation and by the recent figures. Interest rates have all gone through the roof. Most importantly-this is where we will take Senator Cooney to task-we have seen no improvement in productivity under this Government. In fact, we are now witnessing a continuation of the decline that started back in 1985. These are the facts, and this is why we are prepared to debate this matter openly and positively in the Senate today.

SPEECH.PARA: Australian families and the Australian work force are under pressure regarding living standards. One does not have to work too far around the community to understand that. All the Government puts forward in its own defence are bland statements and assertions that somehow we are on the right track. The Australian people want to know: `On the track to where?'. We even get statements from the Treasurer (Mr Keating) and the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) that somehow taxes are good for us. That is exemplified by Keating's Commissioner of Taxation saying, as he does in all his correspondence to members of parliament these days, that taxes build a better Australia. Does the Government understand how silly this is and how it is being thrown aside by the Australian people? Those inanities show how arrogant the Government is and how out of touch it is with the Australian people.

Where is the concern of the Australian Government for the work force, for the individual worker? We have just heard Senator Cooney praise the famous `better than sliced bread' approach of this Government, called the accord. What a monument to failure of productivity growth is the accord. What is needed is not the pulling of levers, which Mr Keating, the Treasurer, is so fond of doing; it is leadership-providing leadership to the Australian community-not some kind of pact between the Government and its surrogates who run the trade union movement. The Government needs to show the way.

This Government continues to mouth the rhetoric of free enterprise but it does not believe in it. Its heart shows no commitment to those principles. All of this is quite clear when one looks at the record: higher taxes, bracket creep, capital gains taxes, assets tests on pensions. All those things are added to increasing government regulation, not less regulation, which is tying down private enterprise and the individual worker. There has been no attempt on the part of this Government to address the very serious problems of micro-economic reform. There is the mess on the waterfront. There is huge potential, if only it were properly unleashed, on the part of the telecommunications industry. This country has a huge capacity to deal with its problems if only the Government would free up the labour market and allow excellence to be rewarded, allow people to work harder and be rewarded for it. Those are the kinds of things which need to be done.

TALK.START.PARA: —Things which this Government sacks them for.

—Of course. As Senator Stone says, these things are the very issues which the Government avoids, yet they are critical to the future of this nation. Misleading statements continually flow from the Government, including the Prime Minister, mainly for electoral purposes. I instance his statements before the Oxley by-election and on the very eve of the Western Australian election that interest rates would not go any higher and would start to fall this year. Yet on the Monday after the election in each case interest rates continued to rise, putting housing under enormous pressure and making the buying of a house almost unachiev- able for Australian families. This Government will have to wear what that is doing to the social fabric of Australia. It is tearing apart the foundation on which this country has been built over many decades.

SPEECH.PARA: If this Government were providing true leadership it would show in a positive light the very real qualities of the Australian people. The Government could provide proper leadership at the appropriate level and assist in improving the skills of individuals who want to improve their skills. It could provide incentive for those who want to work harder, who want to work up the ladder of success and improve themselves. It could galvanise Australians into striving to improve themselves by those means. It could start by saluting the individual efforts of those in the community who want to work harder. But the Government, bound hand and foot by the trade union movement, refuses to throw off the accord and start to reward effort and excellence. It is bound by its political union with the trade union movement which precludes the achievement of the very things which the Australian population is seeking to achieve.

The Government keeps sending the wrong messages to the community. It says: `If you do well we will tax you out of existence. If your income rises you will move into a higher tax bracket and we will rip it off you'. That does not come about only because of inflation. It also comes about when people work harder and lose more of their money in taxes. The incentive for effort is declining. This is right at the time when we should be increasing incentive and opportunities for the individual to improve himself and his family. Everybody in this country knows what should be done except, apparently, the Government. What needs to be done is not the making of some collective arrangement, some political union with an outside corporate body, be it in the enterprise sector or the union sector. The Government needs to improve opportunities for ordinary Australians to enhance their lifestyles. This Government totally fails to understand that basic point, which shows how arrogant and out of touch it is. All we hear about from Keating, Hawke and Walsh is hands on levers and numbers from Treasury that appear on bits of paper that are thrown around the Parliament, which have no relevance whatsoever to the lives of the ordinary human beings of this country. Sir Arvi Parbo, in a remarkable speech made in Adelaide to a Liberal Party gathering, a speech which was quoted by my Leader only a few minutes ago, was very neat on this point. He said:
Our basic need is for a better performance.
He went on to make the following point about how we can improve the performance of Australians:

This includes working harder, but it means much more than that. It means improving our skills, removing artificial obstacles to the efficient functioning of the economy and, above all, developing a community attitude which supports and applauds achievement. It means encouraging, not discouraging, the natural desire of individuals to improve themselves.

Those words should be carved in stone, with apologies to Senator Stone. They are a clear statement of what is needed in this community to improve the quality of life of every Australian. This Government refuses to acknowledge that. It refuses to acknowledge the right of individuals to improve their living standards. It will not provide the proper leadership to enable individuals to do that. Instead, it stultifies the opportunities Australians might have to exercise their right to self-improvement. It throws road blocks in the way. It taxes people out of existence when they want to improve themselves. It applies to them a system of industrial relations which stops their opportunity to improve. It prevents them from changing jobs freely. It locks them into a union system that absolutely stultifies opportunities to improve themselves and their families.

Sir Arvi Parbo went on to refer to how we might transform Australia into a performance-oriented society. He talks about attitude. He does not talk about levers. He does not talk about numbers. He talks about how people think and work. He says:

Superior performance is not achieved by governments, the industry, the unions or any other part of the machinery; it is achieved by individuals. The advantages we have as a country do not entitle us to anything; on the contrary, they represent an obligation to make full and wise use of these advantages.

That is the point. This Government should be leading individual Australians down the track of improving their own circumstances by their own efforts. It should be providing incentives for that to be done. It should be removing the roadblocks in the way of business and individuals improving their own situation.

We are faced with enormous problems in the future which have all been created by the mismanagement of this Government. We have seen the most important issue of productivity dropped aside in recent months. For instance we have seen in the last quarter of this financial year that the percentage of gross domestic product per hour worked by our work force has fallen by about 3 per cent. This is right at the time when it should be rising. We are now faced with a situation where the interest we have to pay on our gross debt owed to people overseas, in terms of a percentage of exports of goods and services, has risen since the Fraser Government was in power in 1982 from 8 per cent to 20 per cent of the total amount of our exports. If one likes to express that in terms of net debt as a percentage of gross domestic product, we have seen it triple in that time.

The problem is that the growth is not stopping. One or two years ago the debt of this country was less than $100,000m. By May it will be $140,000m. It is growing every month by $15,00m or, in hourly terms, about $2m an hour. While this debate has been going on the debt of the country has risen $5m. Those are the problems that are not being addressed by this Government. It is failing to come to terms with the most urgent and worrying concerns of Australians.

Where is the Government's policy? It asks for ours. I will tell honourable senators what our policy is. It has already been released in our industrial relations policy. It goes to the core of the issue-to improve the circumstances of individual Australians by encouraging them to do better, by offering them a way of changing the arbitration system and the industrial relations system in this country so that they can improve their own circumstances by their own efforts. They should not have the Government sitting across the road, blocking their entry to the way of prosperity. That is what this Government has not and will not address apparently while it is bound hand and foot to its trade union masters. It has to change and, most of all, it has to explain to us how it will stop the huge growth of debt to overseas countries by this nation. That is not stopping; it is going up every month. How is the Government going to stop it? The Government should explain that to the Australian people forthwith.

Finally, for all the reasons that we have just given, for all the arguments that have been put forward so strongly by Senator Chaney and Senator Stone, we believe the Government should move immediately to introduce a mini-Budget to explain and show a way to the Australian people out of the huge mess which it has created.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Maguire Sen G.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —This afternoon we are debating a motion which has been moved by Senator Chaney on the question of families, their economic circumstances and their economic welfare. It is the height of hypocrisy for Senator Chaney, who was a Minister in the Fraser-Howard Government, to stand in this place this afternoon and lecture the Hawke Government, despite its fine record, on the treatment of families in Australia.

SPEECH.PARA: Let us look at the last 12 months of the Liberals in power. Let us look at what happened in 1981-82 when the Liberals were on the Treasury bench in the House of Representatives. The record is that 186,000 Australians, not 18,600 but 186,000, were thrown onto the industrial scrapheap as a result of the policies of Senator Stone in his previous incarnation over the road at the Treasury and by Mr Howard, the then Treasurer. One hundred and eighty-six thousand Australians lost their jobs. That is what Liberals did for job security. That is what they did for family welfare in this country. No wonder they paid the price at the ballot box six years ago next weekend.

Let us examine the economic realities of the present day and age and compare them with the past. In 1982-83, when Senator Stone was Secretary to the Treasury, this country had its worst recession in 50 years. That is the record. It was the worst economic recession in 50 years. Not only did we have inflationary price rises in the double digit range and the cost of living going up over 10 per cent per annum but we also had unemployment peaking at a seasonally adjusted figure of about 10.4 per cent. That was the record of these people. This afternoon they come into the chamber on the second day of the new parliamentary period to lecture this Government on its treatment of Australian families. That is the cheek of those people. They left this Government with a prospective Budget deficit in 1983-84 of $9,600m. Opposition senators should read Paul Kelly's book. It is all documented there. Page after page describes how this situation came about. I am not talking about $960,000 but $9.6 billion. That compares with a surplus today of $5,500m. I have referred to their record on unemployment and I have referred to their record on inflation.

This motion talks about the balance of payments. Australia has always had a balance of payments problem. It is nothing new. We are a net importer of capital. With a few exceptions, for a couple of years, we always have been. Senator Stone knows the economic history as well as I do. I remember reading the fine articles by Professor Trevor Swan which were written in the 1950s. At that time he was documenting Australia's balance of payments constraint on growth. That is what it was all about; it has not changed. It is not a new problem.

Despite the disappointing figures in recent times, real progress has been made on this particular matter. But, of course, a significant element of the balance of payments in the present day and age is, in fact, imports of items that are necessary for Australian growth. This means better plant and equipment, better machinery and a lot of raw materials which are vitally important for growth in the Australian economy. That is what a significant part of our import bill comprises. I go back into economic history again because I find it fascinating to be lectured on these matters by Senator Chaney and Senator Stone. In Mr Howard's last full year as Treasurer, that is, 1981-82, the balance of payments current account deficit in relation to Australia's national income, broadly defined as Australia's gross domestic product, was 5.9 per cent. Despite the difficulties that we are having at the present time with the balance of payments, it is most unlikely that it will reach 5.9 per cent. In fact, the figure will probably be more in the order of 4 per cent of gross domestic product. It is very important, through you, Mr Acting Deputy President, to respond to Senator Stone. We must relate these things to the size of Australia's income-our gross domestic product. When the current Leader of the Opposition (Mr Howard) was the Treasurer of this country, our balance of payments current account deficit was 5.9 per cent of Australia's gross domestic product. It will not reach that figure in this financial year.

The Opposition is bleating about interest rates at the present time. The Government has made it clear that we will ensure that interest rates fall as soon as economically possible and not before that time. We will not be looking at the short term options. We will make sure that demand is held down to improve the balance of payments by shaking off the high level of demand for imports at the present time. We will not be releasing policies to reduce interest rates for other than economic reasons.

It is unfortunate-I am the first person to admit this-that the housing sector, which is essentially a domestic sector, not a traded goods sector, bears the brunt of interest rate policies. But as the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) has made clear time and again, interest rates will come down as soon as it is economically possible.

I would like to look again at the record of the Government of which Senator Chaney was a member-the Fraser-Howard Government. Mr Howard was Treasurer with Senator Stone advising him. At the time of the economic recession in the early 1980s that I referred to earlier, we also had quite high interest rates. That has been forgotten by the people who have spoken in this debate this afternoon. We had a period in the early 1980s in this country under the Liberals of economic recession-not a boom-coupled with high interest rates. Under the Hawke Government, admittedly we have high interest rates, but we also have a rapidly expanding economy. We now have economic growth, compared with the economic recession under the Liberal Government of which Senator Chaney was a member. That is the difference. I am as concerned as any member of the Government about the level of inflation in the community. I was disappointed by the December quarter consumer price index, showing an annual rate of 7.7 per cent in cost of living rises. Importantly, as has been pointed out, that reflected the pent-up demand for housing, particularly in Sydney. I have seen a Treasury paper which suggested a reworking of the methodology with respect to incorporating housing in the consumer price index base. Treasury came up with an alternative figure of 7.3 per cent which, although still an unsatisfactory figure, shows that a particular method of calculating housing costs can add almost half a percentage point to the national inflation rate.

At the same time as members of the Opposition lecture the Government about the inflation rate, they conveniently ignore what is happening overseas. In the period since about October, I have noticed that all the international comparisons the Liberals make when lecturing us about our economic management do not include Britain. It is very interesting that they have dropped Britain from their international comparisons. Despite the fact that Mr Howard goes over to London and worships at Mrs Thatcher's knees, why has Britain been dropped as a basis for comparison in Liberal Party speeches? The reason can be deduced from the front page of London's Sunday Times of 19 February, just 10 days ago. The article refers to Cabinet concern about an 8 per cent inflation rate. In Australia, we are talking about a 7.7 per cent inflation rate. The Opposition tells us that that figure is far too high.

According to Mr Howard, Mrs Thatcher is a great conservative Prime Minister. He went over there to ask how he could get elected. However, the British inflation rate is already 7.5 per cent and is heading for 8 per cent. That was reported in the Sunday Times 10 days ago, so Senator Stone and Senator Chaney should not lecture us about how conservative governments can bring down the cost of living. The former Liberal Government failed in that. I well remember how it cranked up the level of unemployment to try to reduce the inflation rate. Mr Howard's policy throughout the years of the Fraser Government was to fight inflation first. Higher levels of unemployment were created to try to create slack in the labour market, to create a position in which inflation would fall. Conservative policies in operation in the United Kingdom have created an 8 per cent inflation rate, as reported in the Sunday Times. Mrs Thatcher's policies have brought about that situation. Honourable Senators opposite should be honest and talk about the position in the United Kingdom when they lecture us about the economy.

They might also start paying some attention to the United States. I noticed the other day that a monthly figure on its price rises suggested a 0.6 per cent increase in one month. I will not do what the late Sir Phillip Lynch did and multiply 0.6 by 12 to arrive at an annual rate. In his case he multiplied a quarterly figure by four and suggested that was the annual figure. Inflationary pressures are building up in other countries and honourable senators opposite should not lecture us about the inflation rate in Australia, particularly in view of the policies pursued by the former Liberal Government under Mr Howard as Treasurer, which were described as fighting inflation first.

I also feel affronted that members of the Opposition should lecture this Government about so-called cuts in the standard of living when month after month, year after year, they use only cash wage and salary figures. Sometimes they relate them to price indexes, but they miss the point completely. The Government's policies, as announced in the 1983 election campaign, were to generate the concept of the social wage. We do not see family welfare being measured necessarily only by wages and salaries in cash terms. That is why we embarked on programs such as Medicare, the first home owners scheme, family allowance supplements, and a range of other Government programs that go well beyond comparisons of cash incomes and salaries, beyond even relating those to consumer price indexes to get real figures. They go well beyond those concepts and incorporate the social wage, which is a much broader measure of the economic welfare of families. By definition, the Liberals are missing the point completely when they castigate this Government for its record in wages and salaries.

Senator Chaney has yet again moved an urgency motion which refers to the plight of Australian families. It is interesting that in October or November last year, the Leader of the Opposition, the failed former Treasurer of Australia, Mr Howard, released a document called, I think, `Future Directions', a manifesto of the Liberal Party. It was to be the blueprint for the brave new world of conservatism in Australia, as handed down by Mrs Thatcher in London. It is interesting to look at a recent opinion poll conducted by the Melbourne Age newspaper of 9 February. The article said that a poll showed that the ALP was ahead on issues. When electors were asked which party was more committed to supporting families, 48 per cent of those polled responded that the ALP was more committed; a mere 27 per cent said that the coalition was the more committed party. About three months after Mr Howard's manifesto of future directions for Australia was released, the people rejected it resoundingly. They indicated that they did not believe any of this nonsense because they well remembered when Mr Howard was Treasurer of Australia. The Liberals keep pulling their hair out, asking what they are doing wrong. They forget that people do not have short memories. The sooner the Liberal Party gets rid of Mr Howard, the more chance it might have.

In conclusion, Labor's first priority has been to get the economic fundamentals right. We have faced the economic realities. We have not taken the short term options as the conservatives have. We have not taken contradictory positions in doing that, but we see that we must get the fundamentals right if we are to achieve Labor's traditional goals and long term reform. We believe that economic and social policies work hand in hand. Through economic growth, Labor has created jobs, improved welfare and generated extra revenues for family assistance.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Harradine Sen B.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Senate is debating a motion by the Leader of the Opposition (Senator Chaney) in effect condemning the Government for its attack on family living standards. The Labor Government's family policies are a fraud because over 90 per cent of all Australian families with dependent children have suffered a substantial drop in living standards since the Labor Government came to power in 1984. Those hardest hit are the families with dependent children which are not eligible for the family assistance supplement. Their disposable income has dropped by more than 12 per cent in the last five years. If those families are caught up in having trouble meeting their mortgage payments because of the increasingly high level of interest payments, their standard of living drops more than the 12 per cent by which their disposable income has dropped. Figures that were provided to me by the statistics group of the Parliamentary Library show that only 7 per cent of all Australian families with dependent children have benefited from the family assistance supplement.
—Seven per cent?

—That is the figure that was supplied to me. While the family assistance supplement has been of considerable help to some lower income families, it has benefited only 7 per cent of all Australian families with dependent children. Many of those families in receipt of the family assistance supplement have been pushed into poverty traps by the family assistance supplement program. I will give a typical example of this.

SPEECH.PARA: Let us take what is known as a sitcom-a single-income three-children one-mortgage family. An example of that is the one-income family on $19,000 per annum, with three children, which is finding it difficult to keep up with its mortgage repayments or with the rent, if it is renting a home. The wife decides that she will go out to take a part time job, which pays $10,000 a year. How much does that mean to the family? Because of the loss to the mother of the family assistance supplement, the loss to the husband of the spouse rebate, and the increased tax the Government actually claws back $6,611 of the $10,000 the mother is earning, leaving her only $3,389. That is an absolute disgrace. It is an example of the poverty traps into which this family assistance supplement scheme is pushing a number of families.

Furthermore, the Federal Government stands condemned of daylight robbery from the purses of Australian mothers because it has frozen family allowances. Honourable senators will recall in this chamber in 1976 the then Government explaining to us why it was changing the tax rebate system to a family allowance system. It cost the Government nothing to do that because it was taking money out of the hip-pocket of the taxpayer husband and placing it into the purse of the mother. We in this chamber all applauded that. We thought it was a good idea. I recall getting up and saying that it was a great idea, provided it kept pace with inflation. I was supported in that by the spokesman for the then Labor Opposition, Senator Don Grimes. He also realised that the family allowance system was a cashed up tax rebate system paid to the mother out of the hip-pocket of the breadwinner.

Since that time, because of the failure properly to index the family allowance supplement, there has been $19.2 billion purloined from the purses of Australian mothers. In the current year alone the Federal Government is robbing Australian mothers of more than $1 billion through that tactic. We have all heard the promises and the publicity stunts of the Government over its family policies. We heard as far back at 1983 Bob Hawke giving a promise to the electorate that if he gained government he would increase the spouse rebate. Not only has he not done that, he has also frozen the spouse rebate to such an extent that the pittance it represents now is a gross insult to the mothers of Australia in their most important work of nurturing furture Australians.

Mr Acting Deputy President, you have not heard me speak before, if not so bitterly, then so trenchantly against the Government. It is time that this was done so that the Government can put things right, if not for the families that are suffering then for its own neck. Families are feeling the burden and that is a fact that will react very much against the Government. My time has expired and I understand a vote is required on this matter. I thank honourable senators who have enabled me to speak.
Question put:
That the motion (Senator Chaney's) be agreed to.

ROW.ENTRY: (Senator Knowles did not vote, to compensate for the vacancy caused by the resignation of Senator Gietzelt).

DIVISION.RESULT.PARA: Question so resolved in the affirmative.

DEBATE.TITLE: OVERSEAS VISIT BY THE MINISTER FOR INDUSTRY, TECHNOLOGY AND COMMERCE

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Tate Sen The Hon M.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —I seek leave to make a statement relating to the recent visit overseas of the Minister for Industry, Technology and Commerce (Senator Button).

SPEECH.PARA: Leave granted.

TALK.START.PARA: —In the period 25 January to 18 February 1989, Senator Button visited Japan, the Philippines, the United States, Italy, France and the Federal Republic of Germany. The main purposes of the visit were to discuss fields of common interest in economic development and science and technology matters, and to promote greater collaboration between Australian businesses and their counterparts in some of our major trade and investment partners. In Japan Senator Button took part in the Tenth Australia Japan Ministerial Committee Meeting (AJMC), ably chaired on the Australian side by my colleague the Minister for Foreign Affairs and Trade (Senator Gareth Evans). This was Senator Button's fourth AJMC and, at least from his perspective, the most satisfying and constructive.

SPEECH.PARA: Senator Button does not intend in this statement to attempt a full report on the outcome of this meeting. That is, strictly speaking, a job for Senator Evans. He does, however, report with some satisfaction that it was agreed with our Japanese counterparts that it was appropriate and timely for Australia and Japan, in many senses the most advanced economies in the Western Pacific, to characterise their political and economic links as a `constructive partnership' and to work harder and more consciously in several fields to strengthen that partnership. Senator Button was particularly pleased with the positive attitude of the new Minister for International Trade and Industry, Mr Mitsuzuka, to the so-called Multifunction Polis project. Honourable senators may be aware that the Australian and Japanese governments, with the private sectors in each country, are sponsoring a feasibility study relating to this project, to be concluded at the end of the year.

Senator Button was also pleased to hear several Japanese Ministers speak about Japanese investment in Australia in a way which showed both a clear understanding of our wish to see it diversified into new, productive sectors of the economy and sensitivity to the concerns of some people in the Australian community about the rapid rate at which that investment is growing, particularly in the real estate and tourism sectors.

Senator Button thinks that the excellent atmosphere which pervaded the meeting may reflect the respect which Japanese Ministers and officials feel for the achievements made in recent years by Australia, by the unions, business and the Government, in tackling many of the economic problems we face. Senator Button thinks that they can see clearly what many honourable senators sitting opposite him unfortunately still fail to grasp: that the union movement, many in the business community and, of course, this Government have a clear idea of the new directions that must be taken to ensure that Australia can compete and thrive in the 1990s, and that great strides have been taken towards laying the foundations of a more modern, innovative and competitive economy.

Senator Button went on to the Philippines, where he attended the Second Association of South East Asian Nations Science And Technology Week as a keynote speaker. He did this for two main reasons. Firstly, he wanted to demonstrate the respect the Government has for the efforts being made by the ASEAN countries to strengthen their science and technology capabilities and our judgment that their efforts will bear fruit and lead to enhanced science and technology collaboration as well as practical business opportunities for Australia. Secondly, he wanted to support efforts made by Australian firms and research institutions and the Scientific Industries Steering Committee (SISC), in the context of the ASEAN Science and Technology Week, to create commercial opportunities for Australia in the ASEAN countries. Senator Button signed a memorandum of understanding on science and technology cooperation with his Philippine colleague, Dr Arizabal.

Senator Button thinks that the ASEAN Ministers responsible for science and technology appreciated Australia's interest in, and support for, their Science and Technology Week. Our support included a small financial contribution from the Australian International Development Assistance Bureau for the Science and Technology Week as well as a strong Australian private and public sector presence in the associated exhibition.

In the United States the primary objective was to promote the image of Australia as an attractive location for high value-added investment projects. The itinerary involved a press conference in New York and a series of meetings with corporations with investments in Australia. The press conference gave impetus to the efforts of our Investment Commissioner in North America who commenced operations last year. In an extremely competitive investment promotion market, Australia has raised its flag and its opportunities will increasingly be noted. Meetings with executives from some of the large corporations, either currently investing in Australia or considering such investments, highlighted our attractiveness as an investment location. For example, Merck, Sharp and Dohme, the world's largest pharmaceutical company, has recognised our expertise in medical research and invested in a joint venture with Australian Medical Research and Development (AMRAD) in Victoria to commercialise the results of AMRAD's research.
The objectives of the visit to Italy were:

to assess the potential to broaden the trade and industrial linkages into new sectors of manufacturing industry, such as biotechnology, and scientific and medical instruments, through ministerial discussions in Rome and promotional activities in Milan.
to encourage increased Italian investment in Australia's skins and hides and wool processing industries through Milan investment seminars and separate discussions with relevant firms.

to discuss with representatives of the Italian Government multilateral and bilateral trade issues, including the outcomes of the December 1988 mid-term review of the Uruguay Round of the Multilateral Trade Negotiations (MTN).

The formal component of the joint working group took place in Rome in the form of discussions with a delegation of Italian officials and industrialists led by Mr Ruggiero, Minister for Foreign Trade. This was followed by separate discussions with Minister Ruggiero on the outcomes of the mid-term review of progress on the Uruguay Round of the MTN. Senator Button affirmed Australia's commitment to the multilateral trading system and emphasised the importance of advancing those areas not agreed at Montreal. Senator Button also met with Mr Prandini, the Italian Minister for Merchant Marine, and discussed possibilities for closer cooperation between Australia and Italy in the fishing industry.

A trade and investment promotion seminar was held in Milan on 7 February. Over 150 Italian industrialists attended to listen to Australian industry representatives from the biotechnology, scientific and medical instrument, wool processing, skins and hides processing, and transport and construction industries. Senator Button provided a broad overview of the investment climate and opportunities in Australia while other speakers outlined specific industry sectors highlighted by the mission and provided details of specific opportunities at the firm level. The following two days involved a series of site visits and separate discussions for members of the delegation. During the same period, Senator Button met with Italian firms Benetton, Olivetti and Telettra to discuss their investment plans in Australia and the surrounding region. He also met with Mediobanca and the Milan Chamber of Commerce.

Although a detailed assessment of the outcomes of the mission has yet to be undertaken, initial responses from industry participants have been uniformly positive. Many of the delegation reported useful discussions with Italian counterparts and potentially valuable new contacts made during the Milan exercise.

During Senator Button's visit to Paris, he met with the Minister for Research and Technology and the Minister for Industry and held talks with a number of the major French firms investing in Australia. Discussions at the meeting with Mr Curien, Minister for Research and Technology, covered the need to give substance to the recently signed science and technology agreement and explored a variety of potential areas of cooperation. Senator Button outlined progress on negotiations with the European Community in Brussels for a science and technology agreement and sought French support for such an agreement. Minister Curien indicated French support for the initiative and suggested the agreement might be signed during the French presidency of the Council. Senator Button subsequently met with representatives of Thomson-CSF, CGE and Aerospatiale to discuss their corporate strategy and, in particular, their investment plans in the Australian market. He also addressed a private luncheon attended by 30 or so prominent French businessmen on the investment climate in Australia. In discussions with Mr Faroux, Minister for Industry and Regional Development, French expectations in relation to the single internal market for the Economic Community in 1992 were canvassed and Senator Button discussed opportunities for increased cooperation in the Asia-Pacific region, in the context of the rapid economic development occurring in this area.

A group of some 16 business people accompanied Senator Button to the Federal Republic of Germany for investment and industrial cooperation promotion seminars in Stuttgart and Munich. Daimler Benz and Siemens respectively hosted the Stuttgart and Munich exercises. The objectives of the mission were to promote German investment into Australia's manufacturing industry and to promote greater cooperation between Australian and German manufacturing firms. The seminars attracted substantial audiences in both cities. Speakers included representatives of Australia's automotive components, scientific and medical instrument, advanced manufacturing, aerospace and information and communications technology industries. In addition, there were speakers from German transnationals which have successfully invested in the Australian market. The initial response of the business delegation was positive, with many reports of new contacts made and new opportunities identified.

Senator Button also held talks with Mr Lothar Spath, Minister-President of the State of Baden-Wurttemberg, Mr August Lang, Minister for Economic Affairs and transport of the State of Bavaria and Dr Helmut Haussmann, the Federal Minister for Economic Affairs. These discussions canvassed such issues as the opportunities for closer industrial and technical cooperation, the rapid economic development of the Asia-Pacific region, and general industry and investment policy. Separate discussions were also held with senior representatives of Siemens and Daimler Benz about their operations in Australia and plans for further investment in this region. I commend the statement to the chamber. I move:
That the Senate take note of the statement.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Chaney Sen The Hon F.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —I can understand why Senator Button decided not to be here to read this statement; I understand that he is meeting with an Italian delegation and I do not make light of that. But the statement itself tells us where Senator Button went, whom he met and, in a very broad and descriptive way, claims results. It is fairly difficult to spell out precisely what those results might be. The thing that bothered me about the statement was the passage at the end of the first page which I think reflects the quite extraordinary complacency and, indeed, smugness of Ministers of this Government in the economic area. We find Senator Button saying, through the mouth of Senator Tate:

SPEECH.PARA: I think that the excellent atmosphere which pervaded the meeting may reflect the respect which Japanese Ministers and officials feel for the achievements made in recent years by Australia, by the unions, business and the Government, in tackling many of the economic problems we face.
He then takes a passing slap at the Opposition, which is fairly characteristic of Senator Button, and he suggests that the Opposition:

. . . fail to grasp, that the union movement, many in the business community and of course this Government, have a clear idea of the new directions that must be taken to ensure that Australia can compete and thrive in the 1990s, and that great strides have been taken towards laying the foundations of a more modern, innovative and competitive economy.

That is a very worrying statement. Two years ago we were told by the Treasurer, Mr Keating, that we faced the status of a banana republic. The pressure on the Government seems to have dropped away. The main cause for this seems to be the increase in our commodity prices, which is entirely fortuitous. Nothing that this Government has done has affected the price of bauxite, aluminium, copper, wool, wheat, or any of the other commodities which, while still having a distressing and dangerous level of foreign debt accumulating year by year, have kept us from total panic stations. The truth is that, at the moment, there is a downward turn in the price of our basic commodities. Anyone with half a brain can see that this country will be in the most extraordinary difficulties.

Today, Senator Button and Senator Maguire in their speeches in this place reflected some of that complacency which is preventing this Government from coming to grips with the task which it must attack if we are to have any hope of avoiding a crisis in this country. For example, Senator Button referred to a passing comment of Sir Arvi Parbo made in about September or October last year, that it was good doing business in Australia. I made some comment and, in fact, I discussed that comment with Sir Arvi Parbo, because I must say that I thought at the time it was out of line with the frequent warnings that that businessman has given us about the fundamental imbalances in our economy. If we look at the first edition of a magazine published by the National Australia Bank, which I am sure all honourable senators would have received, we see Sir Arvi Parbo's February 1989 assessment was that this country faced 20 years of restructuring. We will not get the restructuring which is required in this country if we have the sort of complacent lead which is being provided by the Minister for Industry, Technology and Commerce (Senator Button) in the statement which has been put down before us today.

Senator Maguire, in his contribution to the debate this afternoon, referred to the United Kingdom and the difficulties it is facing with respect to inflation. When we look at the figures on the chart which I have, which relate to the indebtedness of countries around the world, we find that we are included in the dangerously high debt countries, along with Bolivia, Argentina, Peru, Turkey, India, Israel and Pakistan with a very high ratio of our debt as a multiple of export earnings. Our debt is 2.4 times our export earnings according to a table published back in 1986 and it would not have improved since then. The United Kingdom has a ratio of 0.7 and a little more room to move than we have. Japan has a ratio of 0.7 and Germany has a ratio of 0.6. This country, which is classified as being dangerously in debt, cannot afford the sort of smugness we have had from the Government benches this afternoon and in this statement.

I remind the Minister again of an assessment, quite independent that of the Liberal or the National parties, contained in the Business Review Weekly in an article prepared by Syntec published on 24 February which shows the comparative changes in unit labour costs. Senator Button went to Japan. He has talked about the satisfaction expressed by the Japanese in tackling basic problems; yet in Japan we find that unit labour costs are negative whereas in Australia the rise is the highest of the countries shown. Compared with Japan, Germany, France, Canada, Italy, the United States of America, the United Kingdom and Sweden, our rise in unit labour costs is the highest of all. I stress that Syntec is respected as an independent economic commentator. It says that we deserve a better explanation than the one we have been getting from the Hawke Government on the shocks that have been received on a fairly regular basis in relation to our external account position. Contemplating the chart, to which I have already referred, might help. It tells us that the surge in imports now undermining Australia's external account is not just a matter of an ebullient demand spilling abroad, as the Treasurer would have it; it is due at least as much to the fact that Australia's unit cost of production is deteriorating so rapidly compared with that of our trading partners, that increasingly it is a simple commercial proposition to get supplies from overseas.

When one looks at the productivity trends published by the Organisation for Economic Cooperation and Development (OECD) in December last one finds that in the current triennium, 1987-1990, Australia's productivity is expected to show negative growth as against positive growth in all those countries with which we compare ourselves. The OECD average of positive growth is 1.2 per cent, whereas Australia's negative average is minus 0.2 per cent. That is fundamental and says a lot about the way in which the system is operating in this country. The smug expressions of satisfaction about where the Government and the economy are at is the worst possible news because we will not get the pressure for change which is absolutely essential whilst that smugness persists.

I remind the Government that it gave similar expressions of satisfaction back in 1987 when there was a similar mission. At that time there were some adverse comments from the leader of the Japanese mission on his return to Tokyo. Indeed, I raised that matter with Senator Button in the Senate just two years ago. On his return to Tokyo, the leader of the delegation expressed doubts about prospects for the Australian economy and he identified the uncertain exchange rate, interest rates, commodity prices and the level of foreign debt as factors which would discourage investment. Whilst we have had an increase in commodity prices-the factor over which we have no control and which certainly affects our exchange rate-our interest rates and our foreign debt have grown worse since that time. The so-called restructuring reforms which are part of the current national wage case will deliver some efficiency gains in a narrow band of industries, but I confidently predict that, overall they will simply deliver another across the board wage rise without regard to productivity change in this country.

I think it is absolutely inimical to Australia's interests to have the sort of expression of smugness which is contained in this statement put down on behalf of Senator Button today. Whilst the Government retains that degree of complacency, it will not maintain the pressure for structural reform which is absolutely essential if we are to avoid a real crisis in this country. I remind the Government that in May 1987 the Treasurer told the people of Australia that the great challenge for the Government was to obtain a more flexible labour market and a more flexible wages outcome. At that time he said that what was required was a wages system which delivered differential outcomes in different industries according to their capacity to pay. To this point-two national wage cases later-we have no sign of that emerging. The award restructuring process has reached the point at which, as Mr Kelty has said, it will deliver the same wage rise to 98 per cent of the Australian work force. This is not the time for a lengthy debate on this matter, but it is vital in terms of Australia's long term welfare. The significance of that was explained in great detail by a respected trade unionist. In 1986 Mr Charles Fitzgibbon gave papers to the Productivity Council of New South Wales and to the Economic Planning Advisory Council. Anyone who has not read those papers should do so, because they set out in great detail the relationship between differential rates of pay and the encouragement of excellence and improvement of the way we do business in Australia. It is extraordinary that Mr Charles Fitzgibbon can see this so clearly, that in May 1987 the Treasurer could diagnose so clearly what was required and yet we still get continuing expressions of government satisfaction about a total lack of progress since that time.

One would hope that the tour of the Minister for Industry, Technology and Commerce, involving countries of commercial significance to Australia-countries which have a lot to offer us in terms of technology, investment, the taking of our exports and the provision of high quality goods and productive equipment for Australia-and the optimistic tone of the report will be vindicated by the results which flow from it. But if the optimism about the meetings held by Senator Button is based on the same sort of consideration as the optimism he expresses about the respect that people have for our tackling of many of our economic problems, it may well be that the whole statement is worth very little indeed. The fact that the Minister for Industry, Technology and Commerce in the Government of Australia in 1989 can be as complacent as Senator Button showed himself to be in both the urgency debate this afternoon and in the terminology of this report is very bad news for Australia.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Macklin Sen M.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —The ministerial statement by the Minister for Industry, Technology and Commerce (Senator Button) relates to his visits in January and February this year to Japan, the Philippines, the United States, Italy, France and the Federal Republic of Germany. As the report sets out, he undertook a number of tasks. I wish to focus on those items concerned with trade. Since part of that visit, at least, was with the Asian area and concerned Asian-Pacific trade, I think it is odd that the report is not more expansive about the views that the Government wishes to express as to where trade in that area is headed.

SPEECH.PARA: I say that because, at the same time as Senator Button was in those countries, the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) was also travelling and making some quite extraordinary statements. I think it is very difficult to know the way in which one would want to take those statements because they could be read as giving strong promotion to a bilateral trade context or even to the provision of an Asian Pacific trading bloc. The difficulty with those statements made by the Prime Minister at that particular time is that the current round of the General Agreement on Tariffs and Trade (GATT) talks is in abeyance-a series of talks that are very delicately poised. The basic dispute at the moment is between those countries whose trade is based on agriculture and those countries whose trade is based on industry or services. Of course, amongst the latter group, the United States has been leading the thrust trying to get some type of agreement under GATT with regard to services. Quite rightly, Australia-particularly through the Cairns Group that this Government has sponsored and promoted; a very telling and useful group in the international trading arena-by and large has been saying that while there will not be any moves on the services front until there is some move on the agricultural front, we can get some better regime for international commodity trading.

Having regard to the Prime Minister's statements, I would have hoped that Senator Button might spell out a little bit more clearly whether the Government intends to go down the line of an Asian trading bloc. In other words, it has made a judgment that the GATT process is dead and we might as well move into a trading bloc arrangement as, of course, the United States and Canada are doing. The European Community will also do that in terms of its One Europe Act of 1992, and we know that trading blocs are current on the agendas of a very large number of countries.

I am not disputing that one way or the other. However, I hope that we will get a clearer view from the Government as to where that is taking us. I think we should still be attempting the exercise through GATT. Undoubtedly, if the world breaks up into trading blocs it will be to the devastation of many economies, particularly Third World economies and economies such as ours that are still based largely on agriculture.

It seems to me that at least in some part the last GATT Round showed an inkling that people acknowledged the problem and, in doing so, were willing to go forward. One would have hoped that in that round there would have been bigger moves on the part of the United States, as a main player in this area, particularly in the area of services, to come in on the side of agricultural reform. However, we are also fully aware that in the United States internal political pressures are such that seemingly not even the new Administration feels itself able to go beyond the rhetoric that President Bush has been using in the last few days and actually move to some concrete and substantial movements under GATT for a liberalisation and a lowering of the international rates of protection. I thought that that part of Senator Button's ministerial statement dealing with the trip to Japan and the Philippines was disappointing.
