I now turn to that part of the statement dealing with the European sector, which is much more promising. I am particularly pleased with the emphasis placed on the Italian sector. It is interesting to note that Senator Button is unable to be in the chamber because he is engaged in ministerial duties with a visiting Italian delegation. The relationship between Australia and Italy has been one of the bright spots on the Government's negotiating table in the past few years. It has moved ahead in leaps and bounds. That is an important move for Australia. The reason is relatively obvious for those who have followed the internal operations of the European Community.

Essentially, with the accession to the European Community of Spain and Portugal and, a few years before that, of Greece, together with Italy, which was one of the founding members, the focus of attention in the European Community moved from Germany towards the Mediterranean countries. In terms of their agriculture, the Mediterranean countries are not helped one whit by the common agricultural policy of the Community. Traditionally, those countries have small holdings and those small holdings are not supported by the common agricultural policy. It is the larger producers who get most of the money out of that, particularly producers in France and Germany. France and Germany are relatively happy with it, but nobody else could possibly be, particularly the Mediterranean countries. That is why it is vitally important that Australia enhance its relationships with Italy, which is the leader of those Mediterranean countries within the European Community. I think it is as bold and barefaced as that and it is in our interests to continue that line.

In response, Italy has shown itself, particularly in its emerging economy, to be a very powerful economic force in the world. Certainly, in terms of the much more venturesome investment policies it has had compared with those of other European countries we are well placed, particularly given the fact that there has been a large amount of Italian migration to this country since the Second World War. Many of our major industries are dependent upon the Italian-Australian community. I mention one that is very important to me-the sugar industry. I grew up in a sugar town, which makes one realise the enormous contribution Italians have made to that industry in Australia. Of course, they are now moving out of the agricultural area. Their major investments in Australia and other countries have been through their technology applications, particularly in the area of scientific and medical instruments, biotechnology and machinery. If the optimistic note in Senator Button's statement is followed through, it will be a great advantage to Australia.

That part of the report dealing with Senator Button's visit to France and the Federal Republic of Germany also gives us a modicum of hope. When one reads between the lines one still finds a fair amount of frustration, particularly in regard to the French and their operations. Looking at the difficulties we have had in the trading area with the French, especially in the last 18 months, it is probably a good reason for us to go back there and keep talking. The German aspect is useful. I hope that at least some of those talks with possible investors, particularly Daimler Benz and Siemens, to which Senator Button referred at the end of his statement, may bear more fruit. There has been an on and off investment exercise in Australia by a number of major German firms. We hope that there will be a continuing and more pointed investment project.

I make one comment on that exercise of investment that is important: Australia needs to keep in mind, as I must admit it has in the GATT Round, that we are seen by many countries, particularly those that have a fragile and weak economy, such as many Third World countries that do not have the resources or capacity or skills to engage in many of the international negotiations that we do, as undertaking negotiations not only on behalf of Australia as a major agricultural producer but also on behalf of many of those countries that are massively in debt. Australia has a role to play in that respect and should see its role as being a positive and constructive one to enable those countries to move out of their debt-ridden position. Previously I have given the very telling example of the entire continent of Africa paying out more money every year in repayments on international debt than it gets in international aid. It is a net supplier of resources to the rest of the world and yet it is strapped for resources.

The world is in an extraordinary situation. It is important that, when Australia engages in such international exercises, it keeps in mind that we speak not only on behalf of ourselves as an agricultural exporting country but also on behalf of other countries which are heavily dependent on agriculture. Unless we can get a more equitable trading arrangement through GATT, I am afraid that the other moves Senator Button has tried to introduce under his ministerial responsibility for industry, technology and commerce will be of very little use. We are still in an agricultural mode. It will take us a very long while to move beyond that. While Senator Button has tried as enthusiastically as he can to move us along, it will be a long time coming, even if he is successful. In that intermediate period it is very important for us and many other countries that an intensive effort be made with the United States and the European Community to convince them that the problem of debt can be solved only by a liberalisation of the trading regimes in agricultural commodities.
Question resolved in the affirmative.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Reynolds Sen The Hon M.

TALK.START.PARA: —I seek leave to make a statement on behalf of the Minister for Defence (Mr Beazley) relating to the Defence Intelligence Organisation and I seek leave to incorporate the statement in Hansard.

SPEECH.PARA: Leave granted.
The statement read as follows-

I wish to announce today some changes to our Defence intelligence arrangements. At present we have the Joint Intelligence Organization which combines military expertise from the three Services and civilian analysts in an organisation that provides both current military intelligence and longer-term strategic assessments, and we also have a small intelligence group established in the Australian Defence Force Headquarters to provide direct operational support to the ADF. From 27 March these functions will be combined in JIO. Later in the year-when the necessary legal changes are made-JIO will become the Defence Intelligence Organisation, or DIO. The new name will better reflect its central role in the preparation of intelligence assessments for Defence and the provision of operational intelligence for the ADF.

These changes are part of the process of developing our self-reliant defence effort, which has been the central theme of this Government's defence policy. For Australia, high quality intelligence assessment of our security environment and assessing the possibilities for military threat is a front-line defence capability. It is at the core of our defence planning and guides the decisions we make about our force structure, the location of our forces, and their levels of readiness.

Good intelligence is also critical to our military effectiveness in the event of conflict. Australia is investing heavily in modern high technology intelligence collection and surveillance systems. We are also developing the communications and data systems necessary to use intelligence effectively and to provide timely support to operational commands. We have introduced new command and control arrangements under the Chief of the Defence Force for the conduct of independent operations for the defence of Australia. By combining our national Defence intelligence assessment effort in the one organisation we will strengthen JIO's central role in monitoring Australia's regional environment and preparing defence assessments. At the same time we will ensure that the Australian Defence Force Headquarters and the functional commanders are provided with an integrated and up-to-date operational intelligence service.

In periods of tension or hostilities the demand for intelligence to support the planning and conduct of operations and to protect against enemy action will grow dramatically and the system for providing that intelligence and in forming appropriate countermeasures has to be able to expand accordingly without the need for disruptive reorganisation or demarcation disputes over responsibilities and allocation of resources.

Additionally the system that meets the needs of the CDF and other senior Defence policy makers, has to also provide the senior commanders of the ADF at the operational level with the intelligence they need but cannot provide by employing their own resources.

Existing arrangements for intelligence support to the ADF have evolved over the last twenty years. They therefore do not necessarily match contemporary military strategy and defence self-reliance nor meet fully the ADF's requirements.

For these reasons we will gain considerably from integrating the ADF Headquarters intelligence staff into JIO. It means that instead of a small group in the headquarters responsible for operational intelligence, the military planners in the headquarters will now be able to draw directly on the full resources of JIO-without the need to go through co-ordinating channels. And the interaction can occur at a number of levels which greatly helps operational efficiency in a crisis situation.

The new JIO and-later-DIO will be headed by Major General John Baker who took up his appointment as Director JIO last week. General Baker will have the task of overseeing the transition from JIO to DIO and he will be responsible for the conduct of a comprehensive review of the arrangements for the supply and management of intelligence to support the command structure of the Australian Defence Force. That review will be conducted during this year and there will be scope for further adjustments to our Defence intelligence arrangements in the light of General Baker's report.

In announcing these changes I want to pay tribute to the excellent work done by the Joint Intelligence Organization since its formation in early 1970. JIO has a well-deserved reputation for carefully-considered and authoritative judgments of military and security situations, and this is particularly so in its work in the area of warning time, which continues to be a poorly understood concept in Australian defence thinking. I think it is poorly understood in part because people think about warning time as an exercise in prophecy. They resile from any notion that we can predict the future and they draw on a whole wealth of historical experience to demonstrate that surprise is at least as common in human history as accurate prediction. But that is not what warning time is about. Rather, the Australian concept of warning time is about calculating the possibilities for a major attack on us by placing limits on what is physically possible in terms of the forces and equipment available to a putative enemy, and the time that would be required to improve them.

This leads to a central point in our defence planning. There have been, and still are, possibilities for lower levels of conflict in our region that could arise with very little warning and which could be very demanding of our defence effort. I make no predictions about these, nor do I assess any of the possibilities as being particularly likely; but simple prudence demands that we have the military capacity to deal with them. This Government's defence policy has paid critical attention to these contingencies, whilst still maintaining the skills and equipment necessary for expansion to meet higher levels of threat.

What is important in considering such possibilities is to determine the limits to the military capacity that might be employed against us. This is not an exercise in prediction. Rather, it is a matter of counting and measuring regional military forces and assessing how they might be most effectively employed against us should presently favourable political intentions towards us change. In this effort we have the advantage of access to modern intelligence systems and techniques that allow us very great confidence in our assessments. These systems and techniques are at the very heart of JIO's capabilities.

Intent to use force is, of course, rather more difficult to measure. We have examples in recent history where governments have seen military preparations but misjudged the intentions of their adversary. There are less well-known examples of the converse-where both capabilities and intent have been properly judged and deterred. But again, simple prudence requires that we acknowledge the possibility of misjudgement of intent and that we are prepared to deal with the consequences of miscalculation. This reinforces the need to have the military capacity to deal with situations which could arise in fairly short time-scales-which, as I have stressed, has been a consistent theme of this government's defence policy.

I want to say something here about the claim that the Fiji coup represented some kind of intelligence failure. Of course we didn't know that there was going to be a coup, and very few others did either. Indeed, according to Rabuka's account he did not finally make up his mind until just beforehand. Thus, the precise prediction of such a decision is not possible and we cannot expect intelligence to do so. What good intelligence assessment does is to help to understand the circumstances that give rise to such events and to guide our policy responses. I make the further point that, while deeply tragic, what happened in Fiji did not represent any fundamental undermining of our national security. There was no consequent military threat to Australia, or any risk of threat. The only defence response required was to position our forces so that they could assist in the evacuation of our citizens should this be necessary. And I would add that-contrary to some reports-the ADF carried out this task efficiently and with great professionalism.

In considering possibilities for serious assault on Australia, we necessarily enter the world of speculation and assumption. This is sometimes a recipe for all kinds of loose-if imaginative-thinking about how Australia might be attacked with massive military force at some future time. But what we need are careful assessments of what would be necessary for sustained assault against Australia. We need to compare that to what is available in the region now and we need to judge how long it might take for any country to acquire the capabilities that would be necessary. Over 15 years ago such a judgement was commissioned by a previous Labor Government-and it was parodied as ``the no threat for 15 years'' assessment. But, in fact, the careful work of the then JIO, which was endorsed by the Defence Committee, in the Strategic Basis document of 1973, has been borne out by subsequent events.

It is not sensible for a Defence Minister to speculate about friendly countries attacking us at some future time, but I think it is important in the interests of an informed public debate that I set down in general terms the broad conclusions of some of the work done by JIO intelligence staffs and Defence strategic planning staffs as it has been conducted over many years. A central conclusion is that a very considerable military force would be required to launch and sustain any kind of major assault against Australia. If, for a moment, we put aside motive and contemplate the kind of force that would be necessary to mount a sizeable assault against Australian territory, we are talking about a minimum of a divisional group-that is an organised and balanced force of some 15,000-20,000 men.

Some might argue that such forces are already in existence in the region. Even if we accept this, those forces have little relevance unless they are deployable across the formidable realities of the sea/air gap to our north. The distances involved are many times greater than the English Channel, which has been so effective in deterring invasion of Britain for the last 900 years. An adversary seeking to invade Australia would first have to dominate the sea and air approaches to our continent and sustain that control for the period of conflict. This would be a most difficult task requiring massive amounts of specialised and long-range air power and naval forces-and forward logistic bases close to Australia capable of supporting such forces. These things are not available now to any regional power. They could not be acquired quickly or easily and they certainly could not be acquired without our knowing about them.

To take this point a little further, we might consider the kind of airpower that would be necessary to control the sea/air gap. We are not talking here about short-range fighters or ground attack aircraft that are in plentiful supply in many parts of the world. We are talking about advanced long-range surveillance and strike aircraft equipped with the most modern weapons and avionic systems. Australia is one of the few countries to have these in significant numbers. It takes time to acquire such aircraft and even longer to know how to use and support them. As the Australian Minister for Defence, I know only too well how difficult and time-consuming it is to develop the highly skilled manpower necessary to operate and support such aircraft. And yet I consider myself very fortunate in that Australia can draw on a population that is well-educated and technically competent, and certainly so on any regional standards.

There are many assumptions in this kind of analysis and I have given but two examples of the kind of problems any country would face in contemplating a major assault on Australia. It will be properly pointed out that an adversary may well see maritime harassment or interdiction as a more profitable means of putting military pressure on Australia. Indeed, this consideration is reflected in the emphasis that Australia placed on developing its maritime capabilities. There is nothing in the region that matches our maritime combination of P3 aircraft, submarines, surface combatants and long-range strike aircraft. And this Government is putting in place a force structure for the 1990s and beyond that will improve impressively our maritime forces with the new construction submarines and the ANZAC frigates.

It might also be properly pointed out that it is difficult to conceive of a motive for any kind of major assault on Australian territory. Again this is acknowledged by the Government. But we cannot assume that any and all possible adversaries would reach the same conclusion in all future circumstances. This is why we need a dedicated organisation in the JIO which devotes its considerable talents to constantly monitoring Australia's strategic circumstances.

This leads to what, I think, is a central conclusion that should be drawn from the work on the idea of warning time. It is not sensible to think of warning time as a finite period in which we will not be faced with military threat of any kind. Rather, the concept provides a basis on which we can assess our own priorities for defence preparation and the time-scales for our own defence effort. Should there be a trend in regional defence preparation towards the development of substantial power projection capabilities, we would have to consider what we would need to do to maintain the relativity of military strength we now enjoy. Monitoring these trends and assessing our own requirements are thus central to our defence planning effort.

Under the new arrangements for Defence intelligence these responsibilities for longer-term assessment will continue to be at the core of the work of JIO, and later DIO. What we are doing is to add to those core responsibilities the vital task of ensuring that the ADF is provided with comprehensive and timely intelligence in support of operations. This will include not only supplying more timely current intelligence to the Maritime, Land and Air Commands, but also developing a more integrated approach to foreign intelligence collection with information on the north of Australia and Australia's territories. By combining the major responsibility of these intelligence functions in the one organisation we are ensuring that the totality of our defence intelligence needs are properly met. It remains only for me to congratulate General Baker on his appointment, to wish him well with the tasks that lie before him and to thank the staff of JIO for the ability, dedication and commitment they have shown over the years.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Newman Sen J.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave-I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Senate take note of the statement.

The statement which has been brought down by the Government today relating to the reorganisation of the Defence Intelligence Organisation is welcomed by the Opposition. It has taken a long time to implement. We have been waiting for action for some time. In brief, this boils down to an integration of the Australian Defence Force headquarters intelligence staff into the Joint Intelligence Organisation (JIO) whereby the military planners in the headquarters, as the Minister for Defence (Mr Beazley) said in his statement, will now be able to draw directly on the full resources of JIO without the need to go through coordinating channels. This is to take place on 27 March, and later in the year when the necessary legal formalities have been completed the organisation will change its name to the Defence Intelligence Organisation (DIO). It is to be headed by Major-General John Baker, who has been given the task of comprehensively reviewing the arrangements for the supply and management of intelligence to support the command structure of the Australian Defence Force. In the paper the Minister has gone on to discuss matters other than intelligence and I intend to do the same, while remaining relevant to the matter of the statement itself.

The Opposition welcomes the appointment of General Baker to this position and wishes him well in his new appointment. We hope that only good will come of this reorganisation. It is essential to remember how important the intelligence function is to the operation of an effective defence force. In referring to Australia's defence and the part played by intelligence in that effort the Minister has failed to mention that we cannot fulfil this task on our own. We need close and continuing reliance on and cooperation with our allies. I draw the Senate's attention to the serious impact which New Zealand's action has had both on its own intelligence efforts and on the cooperation in our region of the allied effort.

One of the things that concern the Opposition is how well this reorganisation will be implemented. Will the new intelligence organisation be properly funded? It is a reasonable question in the light of this Government's continuing record on defence matters where the wording and phraseology has been acceptable-in many cases it has been very acceptable-but the grim reality has been that the performance has not been there and nor has the funding. If there is not funding in an area such as defence, one might just as well spit into the wind. It will not do a scrap of good in seeking to defend this country if all one does is talk.

The reduced capacity of our defence forces makes it doubtful that any intelligence gathering organisation will be used to maximum effect. The successive, continuing and savage cuts to our defence forces in the operations and personnel areas have meant that the capability to implement action is seriously flawed. I fear that that is likely to worsen seriously in the near future. Yet we find on page 2 of the Minister's statement that the Minister refers to defence planning in this way:
There have been, and still are, possibilities for lower levels of conflict in our region that could arise with very little warning and which could be very demanding of our defence effort.
That, of course, is exactly what the Opposition has been telling the Minister for all the years he has occupied his position. The Minister then says in his statement:

. . . simple prudence demands that we have the military capacity to deal with them. This Government's defence policy has paid critical attention to these contingencies, whilst still maintaining the skills and equipment necessary for expansion to meet higher levels of threat.

Once again, it is a case where the words are right but the action is wrong. The Government has not paid critical attention to these contingencies because it has allowed skill levels in the defence forces to diminish. It has done that in several ways. First, it has allowed through the massive and haemorrhaging losses to our defence forces a dilution of our experience levels. There are soldiers, NCOs and officers all with reduced experience levels. The position will only get worse for the next decade or more. The position is serious and the Government is directly responsible for allowing the losses to continue at such a rate over its period in government.

Secondly, the Government, through financial cuts, has reduced training at unit level so that units can no longer get the operational experience they need. Thirdly, by plugging the manpower holes as a result of the personnel losses, officers in particular have had tremendous disruption to their career development and once again are doing a little bit here and a little bit there and inevitably their skill levels will be affected. The Government is directly responsible for that, yet the Minister claims that it is maintaining the skills necessary to expand to meet higher levels of threat. The Government is not even able to provide the skills and equipment necessary to deal with a low level of conflict within our region. The stark fact is that low levels of threat are very manpower intensive, yet the Government has lost trained people and cut manning levels. As a result, soldiers, sailors and airmen are overworked and in many cases less experienced than they should be. This flows directly from the Government's actions, and those actions speak louder than words.

The cutbacks in the defence budget have been such that the Government is now planning a major political exercise-I would not call it a military exercise because it has to be political-in spending some $100m on Exercise Kangaroo 1989, at the expense of practically all other training in the forces. It will take most of the operations vote for 1988-89 and I believe all the exercise funding for 1989-90. Once Exercise Kangaroo 89 has been completed, that will be it until the end of the financial year 1989-90. That is the position in which we find ourselves. It is particularly important to realise that there is grave doubt within the forces that this exercise will be very effective in testing our defence capabilities. It is much more of a showpiece and is doubtful in its long term value to the forces in testing their own abilities and skills. These forces would be much better served by smaller exercises without the same attention of the Minister and his media manipulators. It will be a good thing for flamboyant appearances by defence Ministers who like the toys of war, but I have grave concerns about the long term cost-effectiveness in testing Australia's defences.

When one thinks of testing our defences, a good test occurred in Exercise Morris Dance, where Australia deployed forces to Fiji to try to rescue Australian tourists stranded during the first coup. The Minister refers to the Fiji affair on page 3 of the statement:
. . . the ADF carried out this task efficiently and with great professionalism.

I have no quarrel with that. My quarrel is how effective the ADF would have been. It was efficient in getting ready and getting away. It did it all with great professionalism, which is exactly what this country would expect of the Australian Defence Force. The Force has had a long and proud history of efficiency and professionalism. But there are grave doubts about how effective it could have been in action.

The Force went away with 120 men. They were told not to take their machine guns. There was no helicopter carrier. There was inadequate operations training with the Navy beforehand. There was no training experience in evacuating civilians. The maps were inadequate. There was little or no coordination with our ally, New Zealand, in the exercise. There was no surgical team, and personal equipment of all kinds was insufficient. That is the story of the Force that we spent to Fiji to carry out this task efficiently and with great professionalism. I thank God that the Force did not need to go into action and fight an opposing force. This should at least be a good lesson as to how unprepared this Government has allowed our defence forces to become.

As a lesson from the Fiji exercise, the Government needs to take on board that one does not go off on a picnic in these exercises; one deploys for the worst case. That means that adequate numbers of properly trained personnel are sent away fully equipped for the worst situation they might have to deal with. Our personnel have suffered because of major cuts in the personnel and operations area, yet the Minister would try and tell us that he is doing the right thing by them.

As I understand it, the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) is champing at the bit in his keenness to announce a date to send the Force to Namibia to represent Australia in the United Nations force there. He is keen to get into the action. I think there is a bit of competition between him and the Minister for Defence Science and Personnel (Mrs Kelly) as to who will send the Force on its way and say `Jolly good show, chaps'. He is also very keen to travel around our region, offering the assistance of our troops, if need be, in Cambodia. He is now reportedly lending a sympathetic ear to the Prime Minister of Papua New Guinea promising him troops if there is any escalation of the problems with the military in that country. The Prime Minister is ready to use the forces when it suits him in making token gestures around the world. Perhaps he does not remember just how badly he has treated the forces and how unable they would be to cope with those requirements. There is no way we could give extended assistance to any neighbour in our region as the forces are currently constituted, with their present manning levels and the cuts that have taken place in their training and equipment. On page 4 of the Minister's statement he says:

We are talking about advanced long-range surveillance and strike aircraft equipped with the most modern weapons and avionic systems . . . It takes time to acquire such aircraft and even longer to know how to use and support them. As the Australian Minister for Defence, I know only too well how difficult and time-consuming it is to develop the highly skilled manpower necessary to operate and support such aircraft. And yet I consider myself very fortunate in that Australia can draw on a population that is well-educated and technically competent . . .

That is the Minister's usual passing reference to the personnel who are so vital to any use of the equipment on which he has staked his reputation. In the White Paper on defence, and in subsequent statements he has made, he has been prepared to make only token gestures to our manpower, the training of whom is very difficult and time-consuming. Yet they are vital to operate this equipment. We are lucky that we have a well-educated and technically competent population. The people who make up our defence forces are the people whom the Government is so undervaluing. It is so lacking in sympathy for them that it is not prepared to improve, for their benefit and for the benefit of their families, their pay and conditions of service. It is not prepared to provide the political leadership that they need. How often do we hear the Minister for Defence make a proper statement about these people, who serve their country so well? They are still leaving the defence forces. They do not believe that the Minister for Defence, Mr Beazley, cares much about them. They think that even if Mrs Kelly cared about them-and we are not too sure about that-she does not have the financial means to do much for them.

As I said earlier, the Minister's statement on the Defence Intelligence Organisation is welcome, but our intelligence-getting is only as good as our ability to make use of it. This Minister, who has reorganised the defence industry and who has made big strides in regard to the capital procurement problem, has failed. In spite of the positives he has failed. He has failed because the imbalance in the defence budget, which he has been directly and personally responsible for, has led to an inexperienced and depleted Force, struggling to keep going. The commanders occupy too much of their time juggling an impossibly limited amount of resources and manpower.

The Minister has also failed because he has refused to perform the radical surgery needed on that monster across the lake, known as the Department of Defence. These will be major blots against his reputation as a Defence Minister forever. The reputation that he could have aspired to as a successful Defence Minister has not been achieved. His deep interest in defence matters, which we have all known about for so long-therefore, much was expected of him-has led only to a disappointing and flawed performance as Minister for Defence.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: McLean Sen P.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Australian Democrats recognise the critical role of intelligence in real military preparedness. Our opposition to joint facilities, American dependence and participation in intelligence processes which render us a nuclear target is well known and we do not withdraw from that. However, we welcome such reorganisation as will heighten our intelligence competence. We congratulate General Baker and his staff and wish him and his organisation well in their critical role. Certainly there is an increasing potential for low level conflict in our region. Intelligence is vital to appropriate government responses. It is the view of the Australian Democrats that it is unlikely that military responses will be the most appropriate ones, rather that diplomatic and other responses before the event will be more appropriate. We acknowledge, however, the critical role of intelligence in either response.

SPEECH.PARA: The Democrats have been very critical of this Government's record on defence. I have moved motions, which have been carried in the Senate, which have been extremely critical of the Minister for Defence (Mr Beazley) and the Government but never of those in service. I recently moved an urgency motion calling for profound changes to our military organisation, funding and alliances. That would imply significant changes to our intelligence organisations. We see our forces as tragically demoralised and our nation as virtually defenceless. We have called for urgent and serious Government action. Such calls were recently rejected by both Government and Opposition. If this ministerial statement, and the organisational changes that it elaborates, move us in any way in that direction, that is, to a more secure Australia without subservience to any super-power and without rendering Australians nuclear targets, the Australian Democrats welcome them.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: MacGibbon Sen D.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Opposition welcomes and supports this statement, which announces that the Joint Intelligence Organisation (JIO) will be combined with the military intelligence group within the headquarters of the Australian Defence Force and will operate as an advisory group to the ADF. So far so good. We would like to know though, what wider ambit the new defence intelligence organisation will have with respect to providing advice to the Prime Minister and the government of the day. But they are details, I guess, that will come along later.

SPEECH.PARA: It is absolutely impossible to overstate the importance of intelligence in the security of a country. One must have high-grade, accurate and timely intelligence. It is something that is often overlooked by a lot of people in a discussion of defence. It is absolutely important that one knows what is going on in the region. Australia, of course, has a longstanding obligation, as part of the Western democracies, to provide the intelligence for the region in which we live. In return for the intelligence we gather here, we benefit from intelligence from more distant parts of the world, from the European, North American and other regions. It is, indeed, the only way we can obtain our intelligence supplies. It is quite beyond us to run a worldwide intelligence network with our forces.

I return to my starting point that the provision of adequate, timely, high-grade and accurate intelligence is absolutely vital to us. One of the points that I also comment on is that the Government of the day must be prepared to act upon that intelligence. If one looks at military history over the centuries, one will find that even professional military personnel have not always been prepared to accept intelligence advice when it has flown in the face of their plans or preconceptions as to what the situation was. One of the classic cases in the recent past, in 1944, was, of course, Operation Market Garden. The British Army tried to seize a bridge at Arnhem. At the last minute it received intelligence reports that there were two Panzer divisions actually deployed in the drop zone. That just did not fit in, after all the planning that had been done; the aircraft were loaded and ready to go. So the professionals at the time failed to recognise the importance of that intelligence. I do not know how many thousands or tens of thousands of men were killed and wounded as a consequence of the reluctance of the people in authority to accept that intelligence when it was relevant.

Expanding on that theme, I also have grave reservations as to what governments of any complexion would do. We have been living with the Australian Labor Party's no threat doctrine. I wonder what would happen if we had a threat given to the government of the day by the relevant intelligence organisations. I am not sure that it would respond to it or that it would increase its expenditure on defence matters, or start its preparedness going so that we met that threat. I think the Government would rather rationalise it away and talk its way out of it. If that happens there is really no point in having any intelligence organisations whatsoever.

I hope that the reorganisation of JIO with the organic military intelligence tri-service group that we already have in ADF headquarters leads to an upgrading in the performance-not that I think it is necessarily bad at present, but it is no secret that the intelligence gathering capabilities of Australia have been degraded under the present Labor Government. We need to go no further than the Fiji coups to demonstrate that point.

The statement by the Minister for Defence (Mr Beazley) is in his usual bombastic, self-congratulatory style. One of the points I take exception to is the way he uses the statement to justify the no threat doctrine. Quite a bit of the statement deals with warning times. The whole reason behind warning times and the doctrine of no threat for 10 or 15 years that the Labor Party has come up with is to justify the reduction in expenditure on defence preparedness and, therefore, national security that is so much part of a Labor government. There is no other reason for it.

The lessons of history show that one cannot predict the timing of threats and the nature of them. One must know what is going on. One must take the steps that are reasonably within one's power to cope with it. One does not sit back and try to define the threat and then meet it. To do that is simply to invite some sort of attack. The central part of this paper is a justification of the head in the sand approach, the no threat doctrine that we have seen fail so many times in history. No matter how good our intelligence is, if we do not have any defence forces to use that intelligence it is all in vain; it is all pointless.

What we have seen under the Labor Party is the three, admittedly small but very professional, defence forces-the Australian Army, Navy and Air Force-reduced to impotence through lack of funding and lack of leadership from this Government. We have seen 45,000 men and women leave, out of a force structure of 70,000, in about 5 1/2 years under this Government. The really crucial thing is the loss of the experienced professionals, the middle-ranking officers and the senior non-commissioned officers, the people in whom the actual professional expertise of the three Services is vested. The men and women with 10 and 15 years' service, the people who know and can teach in the light of that experience the new recruits coming on, have all left. They do not want a bar of this Labor Government because they know that it does not value what they are prepared to do for this country. To pick up the words of Senator McLean, who preceded me in this debate, we now have three defence forces that are tragically demoralised and a country which is undefended.

To return to the statement of the Minister, there is a great deal of dissembling about the Fijian coup. If ever I have seen a weak and weaselling explanation that tries to cover up the inadequacies of this Government in the defence field, it is those paragraphs where Mr Beazley tries to pretend that nothing was wrong with the Australian response to Fiji. Everything was wrong with it. We had no intelligence. We not only did not know that the first coup was on; we did not know that the second one was on. The dogs were barking in the street before the first coup happened. One had only to walk up and down the streets of Suva to know that something was happening. Mr Beazley in his statement said that no one at all could be reasonably expected to know. It may be that Mr Beazley could not be expected to know, but the rest of the human race would have known. The real clincher of Mr Beazley's argument is at the end where he says, in trying to rationalise away the inadequacies of the Government's response:
There was no consequent military threat to Australia, or any risk of threat.

In other words, he is saying that we were not troubled by it, so it really did not matter that we made a mess of it. Nothing could be further from the truth. It demonstrated to the region Australia's total inability to go to the support of a friendly government. It demonstrated that we simply did not know what was going on.

The importance of that, if I may illustrate it, lies with respect to India. Everybody knows that India as a Soviet client has embarked on a massive expansion of its military capability, particularly in its navy. India has no history of maritime responsibility or involvement. It now has two carrier battle groups and it is building a third. It has nuclear-powered submarines. It is a major naval power in the world. This has all occurred in the last 10 years. I do not know what appreciations Mr Beazley makes of Fiji, but I suggest to him that he ought to think very hard about what might happen if Australia took one point of view with respect to Fiji and India, with its great military capability, took a differing point of view with respect to the large Indian population in Fiji. Where would the Australian Government be in that situation? How would it cope with that? That gets us back to the matter we are talking about: adequate intelligence and adequate force capabilities to back up our national interests. I agree with Senator McLean entirely that the national interest in the international arena is mediated in the first place through diplomatic activity. We always try with words to get across our point of view and to get cooperation for the policies that we wish to follow. However, all the diplomatic activity in the world is worth nothing if we are not seen and known to possess the military forces to back the point of view that we are putting across. If we are seen to be absolutely unable, through having no military forces, to enforce our foreign policies, no one will take any notice of our foreign policies. Therefore, while the medium through which we work most of the time is the Department of Foreign Affairs and Trade and diplomatic activity, the existence of a well-constructed and appropriate defence force is absolutely essential for the prosecution of any policy of foreign affairs.

Apart from the no threat doctrine, the other thing that upsets me about this paper is on page 4 where in great detail Mr Beazley sets up a straw man and then knocks it over; I refer to the business of the invasion of Australia. At present, the least likely eventuality to befall us is an invasion of this country by a major power. That is not the risk we face, yet Mr Beazley puts up that argument. He is just stating as a reflex action the old Labor Party view that sees defence in terms of invasion and continental defence. He lacks the vision, experience and comprehension to be able to see that we are not an island country isolated to ourselves. We live in a region and what goes on in the region is almost as important to us as what goes on in our own country. The defence of Australia cannot be defined in terms of the likelihood of a massive invasion by several divisions. Mr Beazley goes on with a lot of nonsense about the sea-air gap and the existence of long-range strike aircraft and naval forces to dominate that. Although it is such nonsense, sadly he believes it and so does the Government. However, it is not the risk we face.

The most likely defence problem Australia will have to face is having to go to the aid of a friendly power in the Pacific region. That will happen in the next five to eight years. It is an absolute certainty that we will be involved in some sort of military adventure there and if the Labor Party is still in power we simply will not have the force structure to cope with it. The risk of interdiction to our air routes or our sea routes is just as important to us as any major invasion. What would our response be in the hypothetical case that some power interfered with our air routes either to Asia or to North America? We would have to make a response in such a case. The consequences of a breach of our air communications by someone putting a barrier across them would be very important. If anyone breaches or breaks our sea lines of communication, with our huge export tonnages of coal, iron ore and alumina, where would the economy be? We could not tolerate that; we would have to do something about it. Under the Beazley-Labor scheme we have no way of doing anything at all about it because we have this continental defence mentality which is so explicitly portrayed on pages 4 and 5 of Mr Beazley's document. They are not the risks we face. We live in a region and our defence forces and the intelligence gathering part of our defence are essential for the promotion of peace and stability in the part of the world in which we live and for the protection of Australia's essential interests beyond our shores.

On page 5 we come to the heart of Mr Beazley's argument. In the middle paragraph, he says that the concept of lead and warning times provides a basis on which we can assess our defence effort. That is the heart of it. It is the rationalisation, a way of saying that there is not threat at the moment so we can afford to run down our key defence forces and live secure in the belief that no-one is a problem to us for at least 10 years. This statement cannot be taken in isolation. The matter of the reorganisation of the military intelligence gathering capabilities of this country cannot be seen as standing alone. It has to be seen as part of the overall moves of the Government to look after the national security of Australia.

The record of this Government with respect to the defence of this country is one of absolute disaster. Mr Beazley has done more damage to the defence forces of this country than any other single person or nation in our history.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Vallentine Sen J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am glad to hear in this chamber a statement about defence intelligence arrangements, because it is a subject which is generally taboo. Any questions I have ever asked on the subject have been met with a blunt refusal to comment on the grounds of national security. As I have often commented, it seems that it is not our national security which is being protected, but the perceived national security of the United States, which Australia constantly serves by providing a continuous flow of information through the so-called joint facilities like Pine Gap and Nurrungar. The statement of the Minister for Defence (Mr Beazley) is timely, following a useful feature article in the Bulletin last September entitled `The Spooks Exposed; Who are our Spies and Who are they Spying On?'. The authors observed that for a small nation Australia has an amazing number of spy agencies. He went on to refer to various acronyms which he presumed were to confuse our enemies-ASIO, ASIS, DSD, ONA and JIO. The article states:

SPEECH.PARA: Some of these agencies watch Australians, some of them watch the rest of the world and some of them watch each other.

In this respect, the new Defence Intelligence Organisation (DIO) may at least deal with this nonsense of having so many intelligence groups for such a small country, even if we have not been told the details. I also welcome the Minister's comments on invasion threats in our area, as they have been a constant feature of white Australia's history and are still beloved by various figures in the military and on the Opposition benches. I recall one scenario conjured up by the Captive Natives Association in my home State, whereby the Soviets were going to zap down to Perth from Cam Ranh Bay in their Caspian Sea monsters and 24 hours later Canberra would also surrender.

As recently as last month, Brigadier Ted Serong addressed the Australian Defence Association in Perth. He warned that Australia had become an open target for military attack. He said that in his opinion Australia was now so vulnerable that a city such as Perth could be captured by a foreign invader with as few as 600 troops. He added that 3,000 men could do the job comfortably. Once Perth was occupied, there would be little anyone in Australia could do about it. The invader could just sit back and wait until the Government in Canberra capitulated or at least agreed to terms. He went on to say that at least three countries in the region had the capability to mount a successful invasion of Australia in her present lightly defended state. He named India, Indonesia and Vietnam.

I was therefore considerably relieved to hear the Minister tell us that it would require a minimum of 15,000 to 20,000 persons to mount a sizeable assault against Australian territory. Perhaps the Minister might also take advantage of the visit of the Indonesian Foreign Minister, currently in Canberra, to check out possible Indonesian invasion plans. Perhaps the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) also had the chance to sound out India's plans for invading Australia while he was talking to Sri Rajiv Gandhi last month and the Minister for Foreign Affairs and Trade (Senator Evans) was doubtless getting the lowdown on Vietnamese contingency plans while he was in Vietnam last month.

One thing that always perplexes me about these worst case scenarios is that the scaremongers never suggest why these countries would want to invade or attack Australia. Of the 130-odd wars fought since 1945, only 15 per cent have involved one country invading another. I am glad that the Minister reiterated the difficulties a potential invader would face in attacking Australia.

However, I do want to take issue with the Minister on this question of self-reliance. There was no mention in the statement of our intelligence-sharing arrangements under the 1947 UK-USA agreement so admirably outlined in a book available in any good book store in Australia, The Ties that Bind, written by Jeffrey Richelson and Des Ball.

I have never understood the secrecy which seems to obsess our spy masters when we can read about intelligence matters in books but are not allowed to discuss these matters in Parliament. Information publicly available cannot be referred to in this place on the grounds of national security, whatever that is. For this reason it is very difficult to comment in detail on intelligence issues when we are denied the information to discuss, which is, of course, exactly the intention of this or any other government.

Self-reliance is a contradiction in terms. We share our intelligence with the United States National Security Agency (NSA), along with the intelligence agencies of the United Kingdom, Canada and New Zealand. While this Government refuses to admit the existence in Australia of the National Security Agency, senators can read about this agency in a book in the Parliamentary Library, The Puzzle Palace, by James Bamford. In Australia the NSA operates out of Pine Gap, North West Cape, Nurrungar, and other places, working with our own Defence Signals Directorate and other intelligence agencies. Yet none of this is ever referred to in Parliament and questions about the NSA are met with a refusal to acknowledge its existence. When Mr Hayden asked a question about the NSA in 1977 when he was in opposition, the Prime Minister, Malcolm Fraser, refused to answer it. When I asked exactly the same question of Mr Hayden several years later, when he was the Minister for Foreign Affairs, he also refused to answer it with exactly the same form of words.

The obsessive secrecy of the intelligence world seems to affect whichever party is in power and thus denies us the chance to get an answer to the age old question: Who guards the guardians? Again in my home State, this Government has announced the setting up of a new satellite communications station near Geraldton as part of its so-called self-reliance program. We are not allowed to know what this station costs. The appalling imbalance in our balance of payments might be due to the import of the huge IBM computers for the Geraldton spy base or other defence departments. Again, we are denied the figures. We do know that, when they can least afford it, the unfortunate people of New Zealand are being forced to pay for a smaller version of the Geraldton spy base at Waihopai. This is on top of the frigates we are bullying them into buying, but again we are denied the opportunity of asking questions or getting information in order to have a reasoned debate about an issue that affects one of our closest neighbours.

Australia would be better employed in promoting closer understanding of its neighbours, training its diplomats in language and negotiation skills, increasing cultural exchanges, and strengthening regional and international institutions which can act as a forum for conflict resolution, rather than spending money on intelligence, or spying, whichever one prefers to call it. We certainly need to take an interest in what our neighbours are up to, but we can do that through extensive reading of foreign affairs and defence journals and using our diplomats to take an interest in what is going on where they are stationed, rather than spending large amounts of money on these highly secretive, highly technical listening exercises that now circle our planet as everyone spies on everyone else, thus increasing the general level of paranoia. I do not know who or what we are listening to because we are never given enough information to discuss these matters in detail. I suspect that a lot of the information we are fed by the United States is irrelevant to the defence of Australia. We are told that it is not, but when we are not given the details I think it is only sensible to be suspicious.

Intelligence is like a fix. The more you get, the more you feel you need. People in the so-called intelligence community crack up at the thought of being deprived of more and more of this material. It is like getting hung up on the technological bandwagon as a universal problem solver. A great deal of the information which passes through our Defence Signals Directorate and other intelligence-gathering organisations in Australia is probably irrelevant to our national security. Maybe a country has to go through cold turkey to realise this, in the way that New Zealand has found that it has not sunk into the Pacific since the United States denied it shared intelligence following New Zealand's ban on nuclear warship visits.

In the meantime, I welcome this slight crack in the window revealed by the Minister's statement and can only add that I wish it were larger so we could have a reasoned and open debate on intelligence and national security issues, particularly on the subject of self-reliance and our real continued dependence on our local pusher, the United States.
Debate (on motion by Senator Tambling) adjourned.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Panizza Sen J.H.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Senate take note of the report.

It is with pleasure that I rise to speak on this report. There could be no better day for the report to come before the Parliament than today. In the financial section of the Australian this morning there is a big article entitled `China pays $300m for wheat as price soars'. Not only was it a big contract, but the price has hit a record height of $219 a tonne. This has been brought about to some extent by the drop in the dollar and also by our catching up with world supplies. The only thing that does not do much for this article is the photo of our brilliant Minister for Primary Industries and Energy (Mr Kerin) on the same page. The article states that the guaranteed minimum price (GMP) for this year will be $153.37 a tonne, which is $5.77 a tonne more than expected. This will put a lot of extra money into the pockets of farmers around Australia.

On the first page of the report one sees that for the first time in many years world production of wheat has fallen below consumption. That is the reason why the price of wheat in Australia and the world has turned around in 1987-88. This has brought to the farmers in Australia the guaranteed minimum price of $153 compared with about $140 or less last year. In 1986 we had a disastrous low of about $116 a tonne. It is very good to note that things have moved ahead. Incidentally, on the GMP, it was announced yesterday that there will be $29 a tonne left in the pool when it is finalised in a few years' time.

I have noted from the report that the domestic market has used up 200,000 tonnes on the grower-to-buyer permit system and 700,000 tonnes were sold under the stock feed permit system. This shows that those two systems, introduced in the last few years, together with a certain amount of freeing up of the way the Board works in Australia, are certainly effective. I have also noticed that the consumption in Australia of wheat grown by us is 19.2 per cent of the crop. When one looks at the export totals for each country, it is apparent that the Australian consumer is the Australian wheat industry's biggest customer. This figure of 19.2 per cent compares with Egypt at 14.2 per cent-our biggest customer; the next biggest customer is Iran at 14 per cent. Those figures show that our own consumption is very important.

In the limited time I have available, I would like to congratulate the Wheat Board on its various efforts, the first of which is its encouragement of quality production in Australia. The standard of the Australian crop far exceeds that of any other country in the world. That is why our wheat is selling so readily on the world market, considering that there are corrupt prices in the European and American markets by their subsidisation. Incidentally, just the other day there was a big sale of subsidised wheat. Secondly, I congratulate the Australian Wheat Board on its marketing skills and, thirdly, for supplying the customers with clean wheat and wheat true to specification. The last point I commend it on is its performance on selling this crop, not only this year but also in the last two years, against the corrupt world prices, especially the big crop it had two years ago. It has done very well. I congratulate the Wheat Board all around for its performance and wish it a good future.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Brownhill Sen D.G.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —5.41-I also commend the annual report of the Australian Wheat Board (AWB) to the Senate. I think it is quite significant that we have been growing wheat now in Australia for 200 years. We have built up an outstanding industry with wheat. The Wheat Board has only been in operation since the Second World War. I would like to highlight just a few parts of this report. As a wheat grower I believe that the Wheat Board has played a significant part in protecting my interests over many years. There are 44,000 wheatgrowers in Australia. We most probably all know that one in five of all Australian farms grow wheat. We have earned a reputation around the world of supplying a clean, high quality wheat-a white wheat, actually, which is quite interesting; many other places in the world have their red wheats. We have an outstanding quality of white wheats in Australia.
—Russian.

—I am not talking to the Minister for Immigration, Local Government and Ethnic Affairs. The industry remains a market driven and a very efficient industry. As Senator Panizza has just mentioned, we have had problems with the European Community and the United States with their schemes of bolstering up their growers and really corrupting the whole of the Australian wheat market because of the things that they have done in the world. They have actually corrupted the whole of the world wheat market. But that is a subject for debate in another place, I would imagine.

SPEECH.PARA: The AWB has always had its strategy to supply regular markets with high quality wheat. It wants to achieve long term price maximisation whilst assuring loyal customers a ready supply of grain. It had trouble just recently supplying the Chinese market because the Chinese were buying some of the cheaper subsidised wheat from America at that particular stage. Because of the foresight and the forward looking approach by the Wheat Board, with its technical assistance to China and the construction and commissioning of the China-Australia Training Bakery in Tianjin, by spending $1m there, as we have read in the paper today, it has made a sale of some $300m worth of Australian wheat to China. I think that that is a great feather in the cap for the Australian Wheat Board.

The objectives of the Board are well worth spelling out to the Senate. They are: to market Australian wheat efficiently, maximise the financial return to the growers; establish and maintain cost-effective financial facilities; enhance accounting, financial and business systems; promote development of cost-efficient receival, handling, storage and transportation systems in Australia; determine and implement optimum quality standards, testing and control procedures; promote relevant marketing and technical research in the wheat industry-it has done an outstanding job in producing better quality wheats, making sure that we have disease free wheats, and keeping rust problems at bay-communicate AWB policies to the wheat industry, governments and the general community; and optimise utilisation and development of human resources.

As far as the farming community is concerned, the Australian Wheat Board is a body that has been forward looking, as I have just mentioned with its sales to China, but it has also been forward looking with its innovative changes to its handling of the wheat grain in Australia in the last few years. I commend the report to the Senate. I congratulate the Wheat Board on producing such a good and comprehensive report and the wheatgrowers for 200 years of wheat growing in Australia.
Question resolved in the affirmative.

DEBATE.TITLE: COMMONWEALTH SCIENTIFIC AND INDUSTRIAL RESEARCH ORGANISATION

SPEECH.SPEAKER: MacGibbon Sen D.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Senate take note of the paper.

The Senate has before it the 1987-88 report of the Commonwealth Scientific and Industrial Research Organisation (CSIRO). It is a further milestone in the great national tragedy of this Government's handling of science. For the sixth successive year now we have seen significant reductions in the funding of CSIRO, which is our premier research body. That comes about simply because the Government is not prepared to meet its responsibilities and fund science-just as about a quarter of an hour ago I was saying that it is not prepared to meet its responsibilities in national security and the great cuts we have had in the defence forces. We have seen for six successive years, in every Budget that this Government has brought down, that the CSIRO has suffered, and suffered very severely. We have now an organisation that despite the glib sophistries of the Chairman, Mr Wran, is utterly demoralised, has no idea where it is going, cannot recruit people, and is simply reduced to a stage of totally bankrupt morale, purely because the Government will not put the money into it. There is nothing more important to us nationally than a concerted scientific effort to maintain the industries, whether they are rural, mineral or manufacturing, to play this country's way in the world.

The report of the Organisation for Economic Cooperation and Development in 1986, only two years ago, criticised this Government for running down the funding of scientific research. It made a particular point in saying that the Department of Finance had a `poor understanding of the relationship between research and economic development'. This means that the Government cannot see the economic benefit immediately of spending money on research. That just shows that it has no comprehension of scientific methods, because one does not always see an instant return; sometimes one does, but in the great majority of cases the benefit is deferred.

The research and development effort of Australia is absolutely minuscule. It is just a bit over one per cent. Twenty years ago it was 1.5 per cent of our gross domestic product (GDP). The successful Western countries such as the United States and Japan spent in excess of 2.5 per cent of their GDP. Comparable countries in the Western democracies to Australia spend at least twice what we spend.

There is another factor to it that is also very important. The great bulk of research and development in Australia is spent by the CSIRO and, to a very much lesser extent, by the Defence Science and Technology Organisation. In other words, the Government's share of research and development in Australia is far higher than that of any other Western countries. So when one reduces the Government input, one has a much greater effect on the research and development activities than one would have in another country. Of course, it is wrong that industry does not pull its own weight, and I think that is a consequence of the taxation policies that various governments have followed, but it cannot be corrected in the short term. It is only in the long term that that can be corrected.

The Government simply has misled the Australian community with respect to the cuts for CSIRO. It has said that they are minor and they are picked up by industry. I just want to expand on that for a moment. When one is running an organisation such as the CSIRO, one has certain fixed costs-for salaries, heating, building, lighting laboratories, buying equipment and running the place. Only a small part-I just forget what the fraction is, but it is probably something like 10 or 15 per cent of the budget-goes for actual research. When one cuts the budget, it is the flexible part, namely the research part, that gets cut. The Government has said to CSIRO, `Go to industry and get support for it'. That is where the Government is wrong. Industrial support for research is directed towards short term goals. People want an immediate response. Twelve to 18 months is the limit of their patience. The things that CSIRO is involved in-long term solutions to the soil degradation of this country and the development of rural industries-need 15- to 20-year time spans. CSIRO needs to recruit people to come in to learn the skills and see that there is a future for them.

This Government is quite wrong in substituting industrial funding for short term gain. It must be complementary to, not a substitute for, the Government's responsibility to fund long term research. The consequence of this is that Australian science is suffering enormously because CSIRO is the central point from which so many scientific skills have been developed.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Coulter Sen J.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise also to speak to the 1987-88 annual report of the Commonwealth Scientific and Industrial Research Organisation (CSIRO) and to continue the deprecating remarks that were just made by Senator MacGibbon. I think the way in which this Government has behaved with respect to science-indeed with respect to intellectual activity in Australia-is absolutely despicable. At this time we have an anti-intellectual, anti-science Government which has run down not only the CSIRO but also the universities and other academic institutions. It has introduced tertiary fees to make entry into university life and particularly into science and technology more difficult when, clearly, we are living in a more scientific age. Not only is it important-I would say it is less important than was recently indicated-to deal with science as an economic activity but also it is important to deal with it as a way of the community understanding the world in which it lives. If we do not put more effort into science education and support for science we will become an increasingly less relevant and less democratic society.

SPEECH.PARA: Mr Wran was put in to head CSIRO. He has presided over its dissolution. It is clear that Mr Wran is also a man who does not understand the role of science. In the report he states:

But scientific excellence requires more than just good science. It requires science and technology to be integrated. It requires management skills, entrepreneurial flair and public communication skills.

Elsewhere in the report we find the description of the development of a zirconia based ceramic by CSIRO. It has taken 15 years to bring it from its early basic scientific development to a point where it has now become a commercial reality.

The application of science is a great deal more than simply the pulling of economic levers. That factor alone seems not to be understood by this Government. I think it is worthwhile stressing again the figures which have already been mentioned by previous speakers. The graph on page 47 of the report shows that, in 1987-88 constant dollars, the expenditure on CSIRO has fallen from just over $400m to less than $350m and that that has not been picked up by private sources. Private sources have grown from about $40m to around about $70m. So there has been a net fall in the amount of money which is being spent on research in CSIRO-one of the premier science and technology institutions in this country. On pages 8 and 9 of the report we see a comparison of the expenditure of various countries. We see that, while most other countries have increased their expenditure in this area, in Australia the expenditure has essentially remained static from 1974 right through to 1989.

I addressed a rally for science late last year at the opening of the National Science and Technology Centre in Canberra. It was clear then that scientists in Australia were very angry about what is happening to science. At that meeting Mr Jones offered the establishment of an interdepartmental committee which would report early in the new year. I understand that that committee has still not reported. There was a Cabinet meeting several weeks ago to consider that matter. It was to be considered at the Cabinet meeting on Tuesday. It has still not been considered. That course of events indicates that even now this Government is not elevating the matter of science, the funding of science, the work of science, the role of science in society, to the status which it demands. I make a plea that the Government get off its backside and recognise the importance of science, recognise the importance of CSIRO, and do something about it. If it does not, we will become a poorer country financially and a much poorer country intellectually.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Watson Sen J.O.W.

TALK.START.PARA: —I wish to comment on the increasing ambivalence with which the Hawke Government is viewing science as evidenced by the whittling away of funds and research grants over the past few years. I believe that the Minister for Science, Customs and Small Business (Mr Barry Jones) is a sincere and enthusiastic proponent of the development of Australian science, yet he has found the technocrats in the Treasury, supported by Keating and others, keen to slash funding to scientific research and development. This is a most disgraceful state of affairs.

SPEECH.PARA: Australia has an international reputation in several areas: immunology, soil research, marine and veterinary sciences and in vitro fertilisation, to mention but a few. We have developed this reputation through, first, a quality higher education system and, second, a commitment by previous Commonwealth governments to the advancement of science and learning. The Commonwealth Scientific and Industrial Research Organisation (CSIRO) has been the basis for this development as Australia's premier scientific research foundation. In his introductory foreword, the Chairman of CSIRO, Mr Wran, states:
The next few years will be a crucial period for CSIRO and we all need to pull together to meet the great challenges ahead; to see that CSIRO has adequate resources (financial and otherwise) . . .
It must be embarrassing for the Government to have one of its own political persuasion spelling out in clear terms the concerns of CSIRO over the reduction of government funding.

If I can turn to the activities of CSIRO, I note with satisfaction the increase in sponsored research undertaken by the Organisation for Australian Private Companies which has risen quite significantly. This is encouraging because it shows that the board and permanent officers of the organisation are forging stronger links with industry and business, which is an essential component of future scientific development. The other side of this, however, is the insistence by the Treasury that any money that CSIRO obtains from private enterprise reduces the Commonwealth grant. This is a shortsighted attitude because, on the one hand, it shows people in industry that the Government is not prepared to emulate their contribution and, on the other hand, it means that in the future industry funding will become even more crucial, thus effectively ruling out what I term pure research.

The chief executive, Dr Boardman, notes that Australia lags behind countries such as the Netherlands and Canada in research and development expenditure, which is still only a worrying 1.3 per cent of gross domestic product. In fact, there is a table on page 9 of the report which I urge honourable senators to examine and reflect upon. It shows the shameful level of government funds for research and development as a percentage of gross domestic product compared with some of our trading partners.

The Government has recently tried to encourage more students both at school and tertiary level to study science, but they must create an environment whereby the scientific area will be attractive and exciting for young people to join. Otherwise, bright students will continue to move away from science to other subjects and the brain drain of good analytical scientists from Australia will continue.

I would like to conclude my comments on a positive note. I was fascinated to read some of the varied projects with which CSIRO was involved in the year under review. These range from work to eradicate the cattle tick, development of an Australian seedless grape, measures to strengthen ceramics, and the development of the lamination of the new $10 note to the developing of a technique of using radioactive particles in soil to find the source of eroded soils found in dams and water channels. Also, they must be congratulated on the discovery of a high potency muscle growth protein for the treatment of victims of burns, infections and injury. Although it is invidious to single out people in such an organisation, I would like to formally congratulate Dr Hugh Tyndale Biscoe, of the Division of Wildlife and Ecology, on receiving a CSIRO medal for his world famous work on the reproductive physiology of marsupials. I commend the report to the Senate.
Question resolved in the affirmative.

DEBATE.TITLE: FUTURE DIRECTIONS FOR PAY TELEVISION IN AUSTRALIA

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Lewis Sen A.W.R

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Senate take note of the paper.

This is a departmental report and it is, indeed, an indictment of the Government's mismanagement of the provision of pay television services to Australians. The report, in fact, contributes nothing new to informed debate on the issues surrounding the introduction of pay television. As the report notes, as far back as 1982 the Australian Broadcasting Tribunal (ABT) recommended that Australia introduce, as soon as practicable, cable television services and radiated television subscription services (RSTV). In 1983 the then Communications Minister, Mr Duffy, invited expressions of interest in the provision of RSTV. Subsequently, the Hawke Government announced a four-year moratorium against the introduction of pay television services. However, as the report shows, technological issues are not holding up the introduction of pay television in Australia. It is clear that the issues that must be resolved are purely political. The hold-up has been the procrastination by successive Ministers, since Mr Duffy, in the Hawke Government who were unwilling to make the necessary decisions to allow the introduction of pay television. Meanwhile Australian viewers and industry are slipping further behind the rest of the world and the report shows that the citizens of many other countries have access to pay television services while Australians continue to wait.

Honourable senators will be aware that new satellite pay television services have been introduced recently in the United Kingdom and there are media reports which indicate that pay television services may be available in New Zealand this year. The expectations of Australians regarding pay television are continually raised then dashed by this Government. This report is another example of that procedure. The Government announced last April that this review would be conducted and the report was due last July: expectations were raised. Instead of July 1988, the report has been tabled in March 1989.
