And what is it? Simply a damp squib. All it does is set out all the things we knew about pay television last April when the review was announced. This report is just an exercise in buying time and I am sure that the Government will now take another seven months or more in which to consider this report and advise further.

I wonder what modifications the Minister demanded to the earlier departmental draft of the report which contributed to the delay. I put the situation that this report should have been and is a departmental document to introduce debate on the subject. But it is difficult not to suspect that the draft report which was prepared earlier by the Department had some teeth in it and the Minister demanded that the teeth be extracted because the report which has finally been tabled, notwithstanding that it is two full volumes, has in fact no bite at all. It seems strange that a departmental discussion paper required the clearance of the Minister and the Cabinet before it became a public discussion paper.

It is about time the Government made decisions which it has been avoiding since it was elected in 1983 and lifted the moratorium on pay television. But instead of making substantial decisions, all this Government does is hold inquiries. In addition to the inquiry of which this report is a part, there is a parallel inquiry. In November 1987, the then Minister, Senator Gareth Evans, gave a reference to the House of Representatives Standing Committee on Transport, Communications and Infrastructure on new broadcasting related services, in particular, pay television. That Committee only recently commenced its inquiry.

There are several questions that the Government could be asked about this report and the parallel inquiries. Instead of providing any answers or indicating the future directions for pay television in Australia, all the report does is raise further questions, the most important of which is how much longer must Australians wait before they are able to be provided with or have access to pay television services.

DEBATE.TITLE: STANDING COMMITTEE ON LEGAL AND CONSTITUTIONAL AFFAIRS

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Cooney Sen B.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —I present a report of the Standing Committee on Legal and Constitutional Affairs on the Commonwealth Ombudsman and the Defence Force Ombudsman annual reports, together with the transcript of evidence.

SPEECH.PARA: Ordered that the report be printed.

TALK.START.PARA: —I seek leave to make a short statement.

SPEECH.PARA: Leave granted.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Committee has considered and reported on the Ombudsman's annual report pursuant to sessional order No. 7. This is the third time that this Committee has reported on the Ombudsman's annual report. In addition, the Committee has reported on two Ombudsman's special reports. In preparing this report, the Committee was pleased to receive both written and oral submissions from the current Ombudsman, Professor Dennis Pearce. The Committee welcomes Professor Pearce to the office and wishes him well during his term of office.

SPEECH.PARA: The Ombudsman told the Committee that one of the matters which he intended to give attention to during his term of office was the strengthening of the relationship between the Parliament and the Ombudsman. He said that, in his view, the provision of means of control of Executive action was becoming more and more significant as governments exercise increasing power over citizens' daily affairs. As a result, he believed that the Parliament and the Ombudsman needed to work together to ensure that this power was not abused.

The Committee has always taken an interest in the work of the Ombudsman and has followed the annual reports of the office closely. In so doing, the Committee has developed the type of relationship with the Ombudsman's office which Professor Pearce has indicated his intention to build upon. This report is a further example of the interest which the Committee takes in the work of the Ombudsman.

In this report, the Committee has considered several specific matters raised by the Ombudsman's annual report. I would like to briefly refer to one of those matters-the question of resources. The Ombudsman identified lack of resources as the most pressing problem that his office is encountering. This issue has been discussed in previous Ombudsman's annual reports and, indeed, dealt with by this Committee in its consideration of those annual reports.

The Committee commends the efforts of the Ombudsman to maintain the level of service provided by his office within the prevailing climate of fiscal restraint. However, the Committee, in this report, recognises the special problems which exist in maintaining a small office under these fiscal pressures. Accordingly, the Committee endorses the need for the Ombudsman's office to be maintained at a proper level of funding.

DEBATE.TITLE: JOINT SELECT COMMITTEE ON CORPORATIONS LEGISLATION

PROCTEXT.PARA: Motion (by Senator Short)-by leave-proposed:
That so much of Standing Orders be suspended as would prevent the Joint Select Committee on Corporations Legislation meeting during the sitting of the Senate on the morning of Thursday, 2 March 1989.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Harradine Sen B.

TALK.START.PARA: —There is nothing in the Standing Orders which would prevent the Joint Select Committee on Corporations Legislation from sitting. As I understand it, there are provisions which relate to the attendance of senators who are members of the Committee. I am concerned about the tendency of committees meeting while the Senate is sitting. I believe that there should be a very urgent reason for this necessity. That reason should be explained to the Senate. That has not been done on this occasion. On some occasions it is done-for example, when it is unforeseen that the Senate would be sitting at a particular time when a joint or Senate committee had made arrangements with witnesses to come to Canberra to give evidence. I would have thought that the Joint Select Committee on Corporations Legislation would have known that the Senate and the House of Representatives would be sitting tomorrow.

SPEECH.PARA: I oppose the motion. I can understand why Senator Short has put it forward. Whilst I said that I thought the Committee could sit, votes cannot be taken at the Committee, as I understand it, if not all the senators are present. Party members are able to go away from the chamber and be closeted in the committee rooms. They do not really know what is going on here. They are under the Whips and if there is a division the Whips call them and they vote one way or the other, irrespective of what has been said prior to their entering the chamber for the vote.

The practice which is developing for committees to sit at the same time as the Senate is very questionable. What it means in effect is that, no matter what honourable senators say here for and against a motion or a Bill, it has no effect on the outcome of that motion or Bill. That is what it means if committees are to sit at the same time as the Senate is sitting. I understand that the point I made when I rose is not, in fact, correct-that unless this motion is passed the joint Committee cannot sit. I would like to hear from Senator Short the urgent and overbearing reasons why the Committee should sit tomorrow while the Senate is sitting.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ray Sen The Hon R.F.
SPEECH.MINISTERIAL: IMMIGRATION, LOCAL GOVERNMENT AND ETHNIC AFFAIRS

TALKER.NAME: Senator ROBERT RAY
TALKER.ROLE: Manager of Government Business in the Senate)

TALK.START.PARA: —I intervene in this debate only briefly. I have heard Senator Harradine's views on this many times before. I am one who generally supports motions such as the one Senator Short has moved today, provided committees do not make a meal of it. This is the first time, I think, that the Joint Select Committee on Corporations Legislation has made such a request. I am sure it would not have done so if it had not had severe timetable problems. I imagine that with Easter coming up there will be some problems. This chamber should think a little more seriously about timetables before it sends references to committees. The tactic is to send a reference and then put an unrealisable date on it, just to prove that the chamber is not stalling legislation. We all vote for or against it knowing that the date will blow out. It is inevitable; dates blow out all the time. One always adds five months to the date put forward before the report is brought in.

SPEECH.PARA: This is a special case that differs from that of some of the other Senate committees in as much as it is a joint committee. We have different Standing Orders from the House of Representatives. I take the view that joint committees are a very valuable commodity; I regard them as being better than individual committees of either chamber. We do not want to get into a confrontation position. If Senator Short, representing the Committee, has to come back 10 or 15 times and move such a motion, some of us will start to object.

Senator Harradine's point about whether people should or should not follow votes and the proceedings of this place is very well made, but this decision will not alter that pattern. People vote according to the direction of their Whips because they do not always follow the debates in here. That may be for many reasons, not the least of which is that they are as boring as all-get-out. Maybe if they were made more interesting, people would follow them more closely. Whether or not this Committee sits on a certain day will not alter the work patterns of honourable senators so that they can follow everything that is happening in this chamber. We certainly support Senator Short's motion. It does not make a meal of it. It refers to one date. I know that Senator Short will give us a slightly longer explanation as to why he specified that date.

INTERJECT.SPEAKER: The ACTING DEPUTY PRESIDENT

TALK.START.PARA: —Honourable senators may be interested to note that the matter is covered by standing order 300a, adopted on 22 September 1987 in our sessional orders, the last line of which reads:

INTERJECT.PARA: . . . and shall not otherwise sit during the sittings of the Senate unless by special order of the Senate.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Short Sen J.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave-I thank Senator Robert Ray for his very helpful remarks. I also express my thanks to Senator Harradine for his contribution because I think it was an important one. I wish to clarify the reason for my seeking leave in the way that I have. I wish to amend the motion that I moved by adding at the end of it the following words: `for the purposes of a public hearing'.

SPEECH.PARA: Leave granted.

TALK.START.PARA: —Senator Harradine certainly deserves a fuller explanation for the reasons for this request. The reason is that the Joint Select Committee on Corporations Legislation has been given an extraordinarily tight timetable. He may recall that, according to the timetable that was established in October or November last year, the Committee was to report on the first sitting day in 1989 on the whole thrust, breadth and content of the Government's proposals to amend the corporations law in Australia. It was an enormous task.

SPEECH.PARA: Honourable senators may recall that yesterday I sought leave on behalf of the Committee to have the deadline extended to 13 April. It is still a very tight timetable. We still have two witnesses to hear. They are both important witnesses who have appeared before the Committee in its public hearings to date. They were both sufficiently important-one representing the Australian stock exchanges-that we want to have another brief public hearing before we commence the very difficult and lengthy preparation of the report. If we do not hold that public hearing in the next day or so, the prospect of our meeting the now extended deadline will be much more difficult. It will be a monumental task anyway, and it is for that reason that we have sought the Senate's approval for the Committee to have a public hearing tomorrow, during the sitting of the Senate.

I assure Senator Robert Ray, Senator Harradine and the Senate that this is the first time the Committee has sought an extension. We will certainly not be making a meal of it. I hope it is a once and for all case. The Opposition does share Senator Harradine's view that it is only as a matter of urgency and semi-emergency that one should seek to take this action and that, as a general rule, the idea of committees sitting when the Senate is sitting is not something that commends itself to us. This is a rather unusual circumstance.
Question resolved in the affirmative.
Motion, as amended, agreed to.

DEBATE.SUB1.TITLE: Darwin and Alice Springs Airports-Pensions: Fringe Benefits Tax-Senator Crowley

PROCTEXT.PARA: Motion (by Senator Robert Ray) proposed:
That the Senate do now adjourn.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Tambling Sen G.E.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —The issue I wish to address tonight concerns the development of airports in Australia. We have seen considerable media coverage in the last few days about the response of this Government in respect of the important matter of runways for Sydney (Kingsford-Smith) Airport. It is interesting to compare this Government's attitude to aviation when dealing with electorates which it regards as sensitive. I refer to seats in capital cities such as the one occupied by the Minister for Telecommunications and Aviation Support, Mr Punch, whose electorate adjoins the important Kingsford-Smith airport in relation to which a number of my colleagues advocate major and significant changes which should be implemented to facilitate air services for New South Wales.

SPEECH.PARA: I wish to take the time of the Senate tonight to refresh the memory of the Senate as to the Darwin and Alice Springs airports, with which this Government has dealt callously and in a cavalier manner. Honourable senators will recall that five years ago in an election campaign the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) sat on a bulldozer at Darwin Airport and promised major and significant redevelopment. Well, that has not happened. During the term of this Hawke Government we have seen nothing but constant and deliberate procrastination on any civil works programs to implement and to put into place new significant terminals at either Alice Springs or Darwin. Both are crucial to the economy of Australia. The tourist industry certainly uses them very significantly, and both Alice Springs and Darwin airports have been constantly pointed to as being important and as having vital interests for tourists, and specifically for the residents of the Northern Territory.

Last year in August Senator Collins and the Federal Member for the Northern Territory, Warren Snowdon, gave firm commitments that deliberate action would occur in respect of these airports within a matter of months. But none of that happened. They were unable to convince either the Cabinet or the Caucus of the priorities required for both Darwin and Alice Springs airports. The matter has dragged on and on through the media. It appears that it is now being fed out on a fishing line as if it is to become another electorate issue and that the timing will be very significant for whenever elections are going to be called. Perhaps we will again see the Prime Minister during election campaigns sitting on bulldozers at the Darwin Airport. I am sure I do not need to remind any honourable senator who has been to Darwin Airport in the last year or so that the conditions there are appalling.

TALK.START.PARA: —They had such a crook Federal member from 1975 to 1983.

—I remind the honourable senator that in 1983, just prior to the election which Labor won, I obtained a firm and promised commitment from the then Fraser Government which the Australian Labor Party when it came to office immediately scrapped and put on the back burner.

SPEECH.PARA: We have seen in the last year constant changes in the Public Service form of administration by this Labor Government. It set up the Federal Airports Corporation (FAC). We have now discovered that that Corporation has been hidebound by the same procedures as those in the Public Service. It does not have the flexibility to operate with private sector licence with regard to construction or timetables in that area. It has been unable to engage the consultants that it requires and it has been constrained by this Government in where it can go and what it can do.

Last week, in debate in the Northern Territory Legislative Assembly, a number of issues were quite properly raised by the Northern Territory Government concerning the Federal Labor Government's having walked away from its commitments. The commitments that Senator Collins and Mr Snowdon gave last August locked us into particular timetables. The FAC has not been able to proceed with any degree of freedom in order to get the proper programs, the proper financing and everything else into place. Admittedly in recent weeks Senator Collins and Mr Snowdon, because it looks like there is an election around the corner, have been feeling very threatened. They feel that they have to screw down the hatches before things get very tight for them. Of course there has been reaction from both the Northern Territory Government and the people of the Northern Territory, who are feeling threatened and do not feel they can trust this Labor Government again.

There is now a draft preliminary redevelopment program for the Darwin Airport for 1989, 1990 and 1991. It is very interesting to look at some of the time constraints that have been built into the bar chart. There is still a Public Works Committee process to be gone through between May and October of this year, a period of some four and a half months, which ought not to be necessary. As Mr Finch, the Minister for Transport and Works in the Northern Territory, pointed out to me, not only has he had to deal with seven Labor Ministers in this portfolio in the last two years, two senior and five junior, but also a larger project in this regard, requiring more significant financing than the program that is currently under consideration, has already been before the Public Works Committee. Yet this Government is going to wheel the Federal Airports Corporation back before the Public Works Committee. It would be appropriate for the Prime Minister to bypass that program, to wipe aside that timetable. The Labor members of the Public Works Committee, who have the numbers, ought to be able to side flick that issue and save the construction program, and save Senator Collins and Mr Snowdon a great deal more embarrassment. That could be done and it ought to be done straightaway.

We also need to look at the standard procedures for the implementation of the design and construction program. It is obvious from the bar chart that the tendering procedures are going to be undertaken differently. The design and construction program is fuzzed in, so obviously there is now intended to be some form of fast tracking in this regard. We need to make sure that the FAC is empowered now to get the architects, the engineers and the project managers into place so that the project can go ahead properly. Under the program that has been outlined by the FAC, the duration of this project could be shortened significantly, by at least six months. Six months or more have been wasted since Senator Collins and Mr Snowdon made these commitments last August, which they were not able to honour.

Recently the FAC has become very involved in trying to fast track this matter because of the pressure, I gather, of an election being around the corner. I understand that an announcement was made this afternoon by the General Manager of the airports division of the FAC, Jack Moffatt, regarding a commitment to have the construction program commence by November this year. That would shave two months off the date shown on the bar charts. This project could certainly be brought on stream a lot faster, and the design and construction program tightened up, with the involvement of the architects and engineers on the ground, either in the Northern Territory Department of Transport and Works, which has good facilities available, or in the Northern Territory private sector, who have had the experience of working on projects in the Northern Territory and interstate. If this does not happen, the Northern Territory airports fiasco will continue. The people who will be affected will be those of the Northern Territory. They have to put up with the rotten facilities at both the Darwin and the Alice Springs airports.

Recently the business community has felt so threatened that it has formed an important lobby group. It has taken out expensive advertising. It has engaged in a project on which it ought not to have to waste community resources-putting the ginger up the Labor Government. But it feels so threatened that it has to do so. It has to keep the issue alive with Senator Collins, Mr Snowdon and, hopefully, the Labor Cabinet down here. We are facing serious cutbacks in the financial area because of the economic mismanagement of this Labor Government. We are not able to get simpatico support from the Government for the Northern Territory in this important area. The issue is continually shoved aside. The Federal Airports Corporation needs to get on with the job. It needs to be given the power by the Labor Government to proceed on the fastest possible tracking of this project, ensuring that the construction program does not start, as on the bar charts, in 1990-which will be after the next election-but as soon as possible.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Collins Sen R.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Northern Territory has never carried a more useless piece of baggage in Canberra than Senator Grant Tambling.
—Order! Senator Collins, I think you should withdraw that.

—Mr President, I will withdraw, of course. But if comments like that are to be considered unparliamentary, it is going to be a very tame chamber. Senator Grant Tambling has displayed in the chamber tonight the profound ignorance about this proposal that he displayed today in the Northern Territory media. Senator Tambling, this latter-day champion of these important projects in the Northern Territory, has had a total performance on the airports question in this Parliament since he has been elected of asking two tired old questions without notice. I dug them out this afternoon. He has not spoken in a single debate on the subject. He has not made a single speech on the subject. He has not made a single visit to a Minister on the subject. He has not even picked up the telephone in 18 months to talk to anyone about the subject. He has trotted out only two tired old questions in Question Time since he was elected to this Parliament. Now he is the latter-day champion of getting the airports built. The two years that have preceded Senator Tambling's address this evening, castigating me and the honourable member for the Northern Territory (Mr Snowdon) for our sloth in getting these airports under way, have been characterised by almost non-stop efforts on the part of the Federal member for the Northern Territory and me to get these airports put on the program of the Federal Airports Corporations (FAC).
—You haven't been very successful.

—I do not know how much more success one could have than to have the airports placed on the program when that is what one has set out to do. Personally, I call that 100 per cent success. The significance, of course, of having the airports placed on the FAC's program, which they were not initially intended to be, is because the construction--
—You've done nothing.

—In response to that ignorant interjection: at that time the FAC did not exist; it was established by legislation only last year. Senator Tambling should do a little basic homework on this subject before he again makes a total fool of himself. At that time the FAC did not exist. The package of airports that was proposed for the FAC did not include Darwin and Alice Springs. It required a considerable amount of effort--
—Why?

—Because the FAC did not want them. That is why. The dollars and cents scenario at Darwin Airport is such that, in return for the traffic that goes through that airport as against the dollars that have to be spent on construction, not even the FAC, with the very good deal it has had from the Federal Government on this, will make a cent out of that airport for 10 years. That is why they were not on the list; the FAC did not want them. It took two years of negotiation by the Federal member and me, numerous meetings with the Department of Finance, which was inextricably involved in that process, and with the Minister for Finance, Peter Walsh, to negotiate a package with total cooperation by the Federal Government wherein the airports became a financial benefit to the FAC rather than a total detriment. It took two years to put that in place.

SPEECH.PARA: Of course, Alice Springs will be profitable because it carries greater traffic than Darwin Airport. The difference between the two airports, which Senator Tambling would not know, is that Darwin has a far greater number of originating passengers whereas the majority of passengers that go through Alice Springs are transit passengers. However, in terms of return for the FAC, a $20m facility at Alice Springs, which will solve its problems, will return on the dollar invested by the FAC far more than the $65m it has to spend in Darwin on less traffic. I know that Senator Tambling finds it very difficult to understand under those circumstances the commercial realities of why the FAC would not be interested in taking on Darwin. Political lobbying achieved it. This constant reiteration by Senator Tambling that nothing has happened and nothing has been achieved is absolute nonsense.

The significance of having these airports placed on the FAC package is very fundamental. It removes the financial question of constructing those airports out of the direct Federal Government budget process. It puts it on to the FAC to raise that money. The General Manager of the FAC, a matter of only weeks ago, confirmed that this had been budgeted for by the FAC. The General Manager of the construction group of the FAC, directly responsible for the construction at both Darwin and Alice Springs-he is in the Northern Territory as I speak at the moment-confirmed again today that both airports had been budgeted for by the FAC; the money is there.

The reason that I canvass that issue is an extraordinary interview that Senator Tambling gave today on talk-back radio. It is necessary to give the Senate the background to this interview. In the last couple of days-

TALK.START.PARA: —Not too long, I hope.

—I will make a decision about that; not Senator Hill. In the last couple of days a group of Darwin businessmen were panicked by a totally irresponsible, indeed criminal, furphy run by the Northern Territory's Minister for Transport and Works that the airports would not be constructed until next year. This was based on the same bar graph referred to by Senator Tambling. I hope he was holding it the right way up because it was probably the first time he had ever seen it. This bar graph had the word `draft' written straight across the front of it. Unfortunately, those businessmen were panicked into putting a lot of money into full-page advertisements in the Northern Territory News saying, `The airports will not be built until next year; we are soliciting donations for an airports action group'. Senator Tambling, sniffing a few cheap votes, for the first time since he has been down here took up the airports issue, climbed on the telephone and said to the interviewer on talk-back radio, `Look, I am anxious to present in the Federal Parliament any petitions that this committee might collect'. One must not forget the fact that Senator Tambling has not lifted a finger since he has been here on the project. With a few cheap votes in the wind, he is on the telephone. Col Krohn, not known for his Labor sympathy, spoke to Senator Tambling. Senator Tambling said to him:

SPEECH.PARA: . . . I'll be happy to act in concert with them. I'll be presenting their petitions into the parliament and I'll be taking every opportunity to raise the issue down here with the Ministers in Canberra . . .
It would be a first if he did. He continued:
. . . and in the Parliament.
It would be a first if he did that too. He continued:
I'll be backing up the efforts of the committee and trying to gauge what community response is in the Territory.
. . . I'll be supportive of everything they're doing.
Col Krohn said:
Are you saying, Grant, that nothing has happened?
Senator Tambling said:
Well certainly the FAC has sought to get on with its job but . . .
Col Krohn then said:
Well you just said nothing has happened. Now you're saying that the FAC is getting on with the job.
Senator Tambling then said:
(inaudible) we would see results within a couple of months. The FAC has obviously been trying to put it into their timetable . . .
This is today's interview. He continued:
. . . but they're not being given Government support or finances . . . that we need.

Senator Tambling goes on to say-I will read that out too-that he has not sought to receive a briefing from the FAC on the airports. He has not been near them. I am not surprised that he could demonstrate such total ignorance of the situation as to say that the FAC cannot even get these airports on its timetable because the Federal Government will not give it the money to build the airports. I am happy to quote the FAC on this in a statement it issued this afternoon. I can tell you, Mr President, that the FAC is extremely unhappy and very angry with this sort of furphy being issued because two weeks ago the General Manager of the FAC, Bill Swindle, put out a statement in response to this nonsense and said:
The FAC has budgeted for both airports. There is no problem whatever financially with the airport construction proceeding.
Again, Mr Jack Moffatt, who is the General Manager of new airports for the FAC, today said:

As planned the Federal Airports Corporation will control the affairs of Darwin Airport from the first of next month and our first priority is the redevelopment programme. A critical factor which seems to have been lost in the debate is that the funding of the $65m development will not come from the Northern Territory or Federal Government monies.

It certainly seems to have been lost on Senator Tambling, who was the only conservative senator representing the Northern Territory in this chamber. It does him no credit that he could make such a profound mistake in respect of this very destabilising campaign. Why should he be criticised for it? I will tell honourable senators why. The Northern Territory has been going through quite a slump in the last two years. Because I am not a Jonah and because I am not a person who wants to talk it even further down, I have been saying on every public occasion that I have been asked this question in the last two years that it is a slump that the Northern Territory is coming out of. When Warren Snowdon and I announced that the airports had been secured for the Northern Territory-and they have-I said at that press conference, and I meant it, that there were two reasons why the construction of these airports was important to the Northern Territory in the current crisis that it is in with the lack of business and investor confidence in the Territory.

The first reason is that the airport terminals themselves would be constructed. But the second reason, and even more important, is that it would be a very public declaration of support and confidence in the fact that the Northern Territory's economy was going to improve. Nobody would want to build $90m worth of new airport facilities if, in fact, business was going to go down the chute. I said that quite deliberately; it was not accidental.

Until that point, I might tell honourable senators, Warren Snowdon and I had succeeded in a very cooperative, bipartisan campaign and program with Fred Finch, the Minister in the Northern Territory. Of course, Christmas and this year changed all that. To quote Fred Finch: now that there is an election in the wind, the bipartisanship that existed on this project has gone out the window and this year `the gloves are off'. Because Senator Tambling failed for the first time in the history of the Territory to even get a quota in the Senate elections, which is unheard of for a conservative politician, he snips a few cheap votes if he can muddy the waters. But the problem is that at the same time as he is trying to pick up a few cheap votes he is substantially assisting in destroying the public confidence and the business confidence that were returning to the Northern Territory as a result of these projects being on stream.

Senator Tambling said today that the FAC is trying to get these airports on its timetable. Not only are the airports on its timetable but also two weeks ago it issued a design brief for the construction of Darwin Airport to Australian Construction Services. If Senator Tambling had gone into the Darwin office of Australian Construction Services last weekend he would have seen the officers of ACS working all day Saturday and Sunday on that design brief. But of course he has not been near the Australian Construction Services group which, because he is a senator, would be happy to brief him. He did not go near the FAC before he jumped on this bandwagon. He has talked to this Territory Airports Action Committee. He will present its petitions to Parliament. What did Col Krohn say to him today? I quote from the interview on talkback radio this morning. Krohn asks whether Senator Tambling has been briefed by the FAC. The transcript shows that Senator Tambling replied:
No, I haven't been briefed in that area. I'm certainly asking for . . .
The transcript continues:
Krohn: You have approached them, have you? You have approached the FAC for a briefing?
Tambling: I've been having constant representations yes.
They must have been very quiet ones. Col Krohn obviously loses patience with Senator Tambling and asks:
Have you approached the FAC for a briefing, Senator?
Senator Tambling replied:
I haven't, Col, because Fred Finch was handling that . . .
The transcript continues:
Krohn: Yes, but yet it's fair for you to get involved with this airport committee; to, indeed, represent them in Canberra and not get briefed by the FAC?
Tambling: Well, my written . . .
Krohn: Isn't this a contradiction of principles:
And here it is folks; Senator Tambling said:
No, not at all. I'm in opposition down here.
He is dead right. He goes on to say:
Well, of course I'm being political, Col. I'm a politician.

TALK.START.PARA: —Not a very good one.

—And not a very good one. So Senator Tambling is quite happy to blow this restored business confidence in the Territory to the wind, despite the fact that both airports have been placed on the FAC's package. Secondly, the manager of the FAC has publicly confirmed that the total budget for the construction of both airports has been set aside by the FAC. Thirdly, despite the fact that the FAC does not in fact take formal control of the airports until April, a design brief on the Darwin Airport has already been given to the Australian Construction Services group in Darwin. It has been working on it for a week. For the honourable senator's information, the only reason Alice Springs has not been given a design brief at the moment is that a decision has not yet been made on the physical location of the terminal. The reason that the design brief has already been issued for Darwin is that part of the design brief is to use the existing facilities that were constructed on the north side of the airport which, of course, as the honourable senator does not know, includes the pad for the terminal. So the design brief already has been issued.

SPEECH.PARA: Alice Springs Airport has a problem. There is a great restriction on the area-Senator Tambling would not know this even though he uses the airport twice a week-between the front of the existing building terminal and the runway. The aircraft cannot manoeuvre; so the new terminal will be set well back from the runway. I have seen a number of conceptual designs for that location. I have been assured by the director of the airport group in Darwin that it will have the design brief on the Alice Springs Airport within two weeks. This honourable senator has the criminal irresponsibility-that is what it is-in the face of this lack of business confidence in the Territory to go on public radio today, despite the facts I have presented, and say that the FAC still has not placed these airports on its timetable. That is absolutely appalling for a Federal representative of the Northern Territory to say publicly.

Senator Tambling says that he will hang on the coat-tails of the group of businessmen in Darwin. I say to Senator Tambling that I briefed the Northern Territory Confederation of Industry and Commerce last Friday on the airport construction. It was satisfied with what I told it. What we have seen has been purely a result of the political smoke- screens that are being put up by the Northern Territory representative down here to try to save his own bacon at the next election, and to hell with the good interests of the Northern Territory. I am like any other party politician. I rarely cooperate in bipartisan agreements with politicians. It is difficult, as Senator Tambling well knows. My record in the Northern Territory in the last 12 years, however, probably demonstrates that I do it far more often than most. It is a matter of profound regret to me that the highly successful bipartisan cooperation between the two Federal Labor members and the Chief Minister for the Northern Territory until the end of last year, which kept this matter off the front pages, significantly assisted the fast tracking of this project. That is the position now. I tell Senator Tambling that the new regime this year-`I am a politician and I am in opposition which makes it my job to try to pull these two people down, despite what they are trying to do for the Territory'-will substantially damage the gradually returning business confidence in the Northern Territory. Senator Tambling stands condemned for it.
The statement put out today by Mr Moffatt indicates the extreme frustration-

TALK.START.PARA: —I hope you are getting satisfaction from this, because you are boring us.
—Boring!

—The honourable senators who are interjecting can be forgiven for having no interest in the economic welfare of the Northern Territory. As Senator Tambling should know, it is difficult with our lack of numbers in the Federal Parliament to keep the interests of the Territory front and centre on the Federal agenda. While those honourable senators can be forgiven for interjecting, Senator Tambling cannot.

SPEECH.PARA: Mr Moffatt's press statement today simply indicates the extreme frustration and anger of the professional officers of the FAC, who are trying to get on with the job Senator Tambling is trying to shoot down in flames. In the FAC media release Mr Moffatt noted that the stated aims of the Territory Airports Action Committee, which Senator Tambling recently joined, were the same as those of the Federal Airports Corporation and local and Federal political spokesmen. He said:
Everyone wants the Corporation to take over Darwin and Alice Springs on 1 April and everyone wants a construction start on the terminals before the end of this year. Both will happen.

The other factor that has entered into this is a totally unnecessary and destabilising debate based on nothing except a single piece of paper, a draft bar graph tabled at the first meeting that was held between the FAC--

TALK.START.PARA: —Not again.

—In response to the continual interjections, I remind Senator Hill that this is a House of debate and that I have utilised the adjournment debate twice since my election. (Quorum formed) In response to the quorum call, I point out that I could hardly be accused of being cavalier in detaining senators in the adjournment debate. I listened to Senator Tambling in the adjournment debate last night pouring buckets all over the Australian Labor Party about Kakadu. For that reason I decided that I would not respond. I notice that he is listed for the adjournment every day this week. The reason is quite simple.
—Preselection.
—That is right. The Opposition thinks it is a Federal election year. Senator Tambling failed to get a quota at the last election.
—Are you going to go through that again?
—I will respond to that interjection. This is the second time--
—You have already repeated that three times. Why don't you get on with your speech?

—If Senator Hill continues to interject I will continue to respond. This is the second time that I have spoken on the adjournment since becoming a member of this Parliament. I do not think I could be accused of frivolously detaining honourable senators.
—Get on with the job.

—Warren Snowdon and I are getting on with the job. We are going to get the airports built in the Northern Territory. That is the great difficulty for the Opposition, and Senator Tambling knows it. Senator Tambling and the Minister for Transport and Works in the Northern Territory, Fred Finch, now know, Mr Finch having been briefed on the actual detailed construction program for these reports, they are going to be built. They see a political opportunity slipping away from them. They are not in the least bit interested in getting $90m worth of badly needed facilities built in the Northern Territory. It is just a political opportunity to belt the Labor Party which is slipping away from them. They have climbed onto the bandwagon in a last desperate attempt to muddy the waters. This issue, which without any question will return the seat of the Northern Territory to the Labor Party at the next election when it is delivered on, and rightly so-and they know that-is going to cause them a great deal of trouble.

SPEECH.PARA: The CLP is also in a dreadful position having just selected an appalling candidate to run for the House of Representatives seat. The only party that he has not joined is the Christmas party. He has joined every other party-the Labor Party, the CLP, the Northern Territory Nationals-and is back to the CLP again. The CLP is going to have to try to shore up the chances of this hopeless candidate to win the seat. I understand that as a politician. There is no question at all that because of this sudden transition of cooperation last year to absolute, to quote Fred Finch, `gloves off political opposition' this year is purely an attempt to try to salvage a few votes for the hopeless ticket that the conservatives are running in the Northern Territory. The great problem with that relates to the second agenda that was involved in getting these airports secured, as they have been, for the Territory. I refer to the vital problem, about which Senator Tambling knows, of trying to stem the flow of net population loss that the Northern Territory has suffered in the last two years. It is the first time it has happened in 40 years. That agenda has been significantly blown out of the water and damaged irretrievably by the Northern Territory's own conservative Federal member. He should stand condemned for it.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Panizza Sen J.H.

TALK.START.PARA: —I can assure the Senate that I will not be here for half an hour. There is a point that I would like to make. This time last year I spoke in an adjournment debate about the problem of pensioners being caught in the provisional tax net. In other words, when they received their pension plus a certain amount of money from non-pension areas, they were getting lumped into the provisional tax trap.

SPEECH.PARA: In the last Budget the Government announced that it would legislate-and it has legislated-to remove the imposition of provisional tax on the Australian pension. There is a certain amount of money on top of that pension, to the limit of $1,000, where the pensioner rebate cuts out and upon which there is no provisional tax raised.

We have now come to an anomaly. I have a constituent in Western Australia who has pointed out that he is receiving a British pension rather than an Australian pension, but that the legislation does not cover his situation. This client is receiving a British pension and a certain amount of other income, not being pension. This puts him above the threshold at which he has to pay provisional tax, whereas if he were simply getting an Australian pension he would not be liable for that provisional tax.

If one lives on a pension, it is a pension and nothing else. Whether that pension comes from overseas or whether it comes from Australia, it should be treated in the same way. In other words, neither pension should attract provisional tax. It is far cheaper for the Australian Government that this pensioner receives a British pension, because the Australian Government is not paying it out. It would be better for this person in Perth, and for many others throughout Australia who are in the same position, to turn in their British pensions and get Australian pensions. Going on just under $1,000 of other income, these pensioners would be better off to the tune of $146.25, which is a great amount for someone living on a fixed pension.
I would like the Minister at the table to take on board the fact that this anomaly exists in Australia and to ensure that something is done about it in the next Budget, if not before that.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Maguire Sen G.R.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Treasurer, upon notice, on 15 April 1988:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) What revenue has been collected from the capital gains tax or is estimated to be collected from the capital gains tax, over and above the long-standing collections on capital gains through the income tax system under the `12-month rule' and `purpose of purchase' rule, in the financial years: 1986-87; 1987/88 (estimate); and 1988-89 (estimate).

(2) What net increases in collections from income tax have been or are expected to be collected as a direct result of the introduction of the capital gains tax in September 1985, in the following financial years: 1986-87; 1987-88 (estimate); and 1988-89 (estimate).

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Walsh Sen The Hon P.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Treasurer has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) Capital gains tax applies to assets purchased after 19 September 1985 so that the first contribution to revenue under the capital gains tax provisions occurred during the 1986-87 fiscal year. No data are available which isolate the contribution to revenue of the capital gains tax in 1986-87, although this would not be substantial. For the 1987-88 fiscal year, the revenue directly attributable to the capital gains tax amounted to $89m, being collections from individual taxpayers of $43m and from corporate taxpayers of $46m. The estimated yield in 1988-89 from the capital gains tax is $100m. These figures do not include collections under the `purpose of purchase' rule referred to by Senator Maguire, which was abolished upon the introduction of the capital gains tax on 19 September 1985, or the so-called `12-month' rule. In relation to the `12-month' rule, the Government announced in the 1988 May Economic Statement that it would be abolished with effect from 25 May 1988 and that the gains to which that section previously applied would be subject to the capital gains tax provisions.

(2) It is likely that the capital gains tax provisions are indirectly generating revenue through other provisions of the Income Tax Assessment Act. This indirect income tax generation reflects one of the major objects of the introduction of the capital gains tax, which was to reduce the tax motivated distortion of investment toward assets that produce capital gains rather than income. The income tax revenue generated indirectly by virtue of the capital gains tax cannot be isolated by the Tax Office precisely since it is not separately identified in tax returns, but it is expected to be substantial. It has been estimated that it may be up to $300 million per year.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Archer Sen B.R.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Treasurer, upon notice, on 23 May 1988:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) How many rural landholdings in Australia are owned or partially owned (40 per cent or more) by foreign nationals or foreign companies.
(2) What is the value of agricultural production of these landholdings; (a) as an absolute amount; and (b) as a percentage of total agricultural production.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Walsh Sen The Hon P.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Treasurer has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) and (2) Since the changes to the Government's foreign investment policy in April 1987, proposed acquisitions by foreign investors of rural properties have only been examinable where the properties are valued at $3 million or more. The policy provides that such proposals are approved unless they are judged contrary to the national interest.

Many foreign acquisitions would involve properties valued at less than $3 million and would not be recorded in the Foreign Investment Review Board's statistics after April 1987. In addition, proposals which are approved may not always proceed to finality, while sales of rural properties by foreign investors to Australian buyers do not require approval by the Commonwealth Government. For these reasons it is not possible to maintain a comprehensive register of foreign landholdings. I note also that matters relating to the title and registration of land fall within the responsibilities of the Governments of the States and Territories, rather than the Commonwealth.

While the data collected by the Foreign Investment Review Board are insufficient to provide the information requested by the honourable senator, I have attached a table from the Board's 1986-87 Report which may be of some interest.

The Australian Bureau of Statistics also conducts periodic surveys on foreign ownership and control of selected Australian industries, its most recent survey in respect of agriculture relating to 31 March 1984. At that time foreign ownership of agricultural land was estimated at 5.9 per cent, while foreign ownership accounted for only 1.8 per cent of total gross value of agricultural commodities produced.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Archer Sen B.R.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Treasurer, upon notice, on 1 June 1988:

QUESTION.PARA: Will income derived from bona fide redundancy payments `rolled over' into Approved Deposit Funds be subject to the new 15 per cent superannuation tax.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Walsh Sen The Hon P.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Treasurer has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

ANSWER.PARA: A bona fide redundancy payment will not be subject to tax on roll-over into an Approved Deposit Fund (ADF). Investment income derived from a rolled-over bona fide redundancy payment in an ADF will, as from 1 July 1988, be assessable for tax at the rate of 15 per cent in the hands of the fund. A fund will be able to offset or even neutralise the effects of this tax in various ways including, for example, by receiving imputation credits on franked dividends received from Australian companies and by investing in assets such as property which yield a high proportion of their return in the form of capital gains.

On withdrawal from the ADF, components of the payment will be treated differently for tax purposes, as occurs under current law. The amount referable to the original bona fide redundancy payment will continue to retain its identity and be taxed by including 5 per cent in assessable income. The amount of the withdrawal referable of earnings in the ADF will continue to be treated as an eligible termination payment and, as from 1 July 1988, will be subject to reduced rates of tax as announced in the May Economic Statement.

Because the reduction in tax on the earnings component of the withdrawal is likely to exceed the net effect of the tax on fund earnings, the total after-tax amount of the withdrawal from the ADF can generally be expected to be higher under the new arrangements.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Watson Sen J.O.W.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy, upon notice, on 1 December 1988:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Given the differing interests of the Australian Wool Corporation, which acts on behalf of growers, and the Minister for Industry, Technology and Commerce, whose preferred position is for improvement in down-stream processing in order to add value to our raw material, what steps is the Minister taking to resolve this dichotomy.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Cook Sen The Hon P.F.S.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Primary Industries and Energy has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) There is no dichotomy in the positions of the Minister for Industry, Technology and Commerce and the Australian Wool Corporation concerning further processing of wool. The objective of the Australian Wool Corporation is to increase the commercial returns to Australian woolgrowers. This is achieved by a number of means, one of which is the facilitation of wool marketing. The marketing powers of the Corporation, as set out in the Wool Marketing Act 1987 include to process, or arrange for the processing of, wool.

To this end, the Corporation has participated in an early stage wool scouring venture at Laverton, Victoria. This joint venture plant is utilising scouring technology developed by CSIRO and equipment manufactured in Australia and market access for half the output has been secured through one of the joint venture partners. Through participation in the processing sector, the Corporation aims to position woolgrowers in the manufacturing pipeline in order to protect their long-term interests; and to enhance the long-term viability of Australian woolgrowing. The Corporation also provides advice to potential investors in further processing.

The Corporation's approach is consistent with the Government's policy of encouraging further processing activity provided there is sound economic potential. Such commercially viable activity can play an important role in generating employment opportunities and export earnings for Australia's future.
I believe that the activities of the Australian Wool Corporation make a valuable contribution towards achieving these goals.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Dunn Sen I.P.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Defence, upon notice, on 15 December 1988:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) As the Australian/American bases are joint facilities, what is the nature of the joint control.
(2) Is the Australian Government privy to operational orders sent to American submarines at North West Cape; if so, has the Government the power to veto over such orders.

(3) Given that current United States of America nuclear strategy, which is known as `flexible response', will at some point in the escalation of conflict require the employment of the nuclear option, is the Prime Minister prepared to have any joint facility used for first strike, not retaliatory, nuclear strike purposes.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Richardson Sen The Hon G.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Defence has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) The joint defence facilities are for defence purposes which have been jointly agreed between the Australian and US Governments. Control is exercised by the Australian and US Governments by ensuring that the facilities are used only for those purposes to which agreement has been given. This control is implemented through an integrated staff of Australian and US personnel with responsibilities for the operation and management of the facilities in accordance with the agreements between Australia and the US.

(2) At North West Cape, neither Government has a right of access to operational orders relayed through the facility to the armed forces of the other party. However the Government has in place arrangements which ensure that the Government receives full and timely consultation on US strategic and operational policies likely to involve North West Cape. This includes, inter alia, the regular Defence to Defense consultations established under the 1974 Barnard-Schlesinger agreement, the access guaranteed to the Head Australian Defence Staff (Washington) to senior US Defense officials under the 1983 Scholes-Weinberger agreement, and the creation of a new position of Counsellor Defence Policy in the Australian Embassy in Washington. In toto these arrangements safeguard Australian sovereignty by providing that the Government has advance knowledge of the purposes for which the US might wish to use the Station's capabilities.

(3) US nuclear strategy is that of deterrence, and deterrence works by persuading possible adversaries that the risks they run from their aggression outweighs any likely gain. To implement this strategy of deterring war the US, and NATO, have a doctrine of flexible response, together with versatile military capabilities. Flexible response does not involve automatic or inevitable escalation to the use of nuclear weapons.

The purpose of US and NATO military doctrine and war fighting options is to make clear that deterrence does not rest upon a bluff, and to make clear that effective military responses which are appropriate and not excessive are available in the event of aggression. In the remote and extreme event of Soviet attack, where the USSR did not restrain its aggression to non-vital Western interests, and where conventional Western forces proved unable to defend those vital interests, US and NATO doctrine has reserved a retaliatory option of first-use of nuclear weapons. The US and NATO have clearly disavowed any nuclear first-strike however. A threat of first-use of nuclear weapons is not a threat of a massive disarming first-strike intended to destroy the opponent; it is a threat of nuclear retaliation to conventional attack that threatens truly vital interests.

The conviction of all Western leaders that `nuclear war cannot be won and must never be fought' is clear. The Government is confident that the US and NATO strategy of flexible response is defensive and reactive; its intent is to deter all war and to minimise the consequences should any conflict occur.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Jenkins Sen J.A.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for the Arts, Sport, the Environment, Tourism and Territories, upon notice, on 15 December 1988:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) On what dates did the Minister or the Australian Capital Territory (A.C.T.) Administration receive from the Australian Electoral Commission written or oral advice or opinions on, or input to, the Australian Capital Territory (Electoral) Bill 1988.
(2) What were the broad topics or aspects addressed in that advice or those opinions on each occasion.

(3) Has the Minister or the A.C.T. Administration received written or oral advice from the Australian Electoral Commission since the debate on the Bill in the Senate; if so, on what occasion and with respect to what aspects of the Bill.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Richardson Sen The Hon G.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable senator's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) Neither I or the Minister for the Arts and Territories had any direct communication with the Australian Electoral Commission (AEC) in relation to the Australian Capital Territory (Electoral) Bill 1988. There was, however, continuous oral communication between AEC and the ACT Administration ACTA) during the drafting of the Bill. This oral communication occurred on almost a daily basis and it is not possible to provide precise dates. The AEC also wrote to ACTA on 31 October and 18 November 1988.

(2) The oral communication with the AEC was limited to advice in relation to the conversion of the policy underlying the Bill into law and AEC correspondence. The correspondence clarified the role of the Electoral Commission in the development of the Bill, addressed the nature and complexities of the amendments made to the Bill after its introduction into the House, as well as possible dates for the first ACT election.

(3) I have not received from the AEC written or oral advice since the debate on the Bill in the Senate. The Minister for the Arts and Territories received a written advice from AEC on 8 December regarding the respective public information roles of AEC and ACTA regarding the first ACT election. On 14 December AEC wrote to ACTA drawing attention to three technical or typographical errors in the Bill. AEC wrote to ACTA on 21 December regarding possible dates for the first ACT election.

ANSWER.TO.QON.TITLE: Australian Defence Force Education and Tuition Allowances

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Newman Sen J.M.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Defence Science and Personnel, upon notice, on 16 December 1988:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) What are the latest figures for children receiving the Australian Defence Force Education and Tuition Allowances.

(2) Has the Defence Department conducted any studies in order to determine the number of children who are theoretically eligible for these allowances; if so, could the Minister provide the figures; if not, how does the Department determine the effectiveness of the Allowances.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Richardson Sen The Hon G.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Defence Science and Personnel has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) For the 1988 school year 82 members of the Australian Defence Force were paid Education Allowance in respect of 93 children.
Twenty-four (24) payments of extra Tuition Allowance were made during the same period.
These figures do not include education assistance for children of members posted overseas as the two allowances mentioned by the honourable senator are only paid to members serving in Australia.
(2) No specific study has been conducted to ascertain the number of children who could attract the allowances.

The demography of the child population of Defence Force members would not provide a measurement of the effectiveness of these allowances. It is a matter of free choice for parents whether they seek access to Education Allowance or have their children accompany them on posting. Likewise it is largely a matter of parental judgement whether a child requires extra tuition following a change of school.
It is possible for Education Allowance to be paid in respect of any child whose secondary education would suffer serious interference by having to accompany a member of posting.

It is worth mentioning that in 1988 only seven applications for Education Allowance out of a total of 100 were not approved. Applications not approved are carefully evaluated to judge whether the legal provisions are inappropriate.

It is also possible for Extra Tuition Allowances to be paid in respect of any child in the last or second last year of primary education, or for secondary school students, who accompany a member on a long term posting if the qualifying conditions for that Allowance are met.

Extra Tuition Allowance has been available only for the 1988 school year. A review of the allowance will be conducted at the end of 1989 to determine whether it is adequate and comprehensive in the light of experience gained by operation. The Australian Defence Families Information and Liaison Service (ADFILs) regional staff will be assisting in the review.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Sanders Sen N.K.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Defence, upon notice, on 21 December 1988:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Is the Minister aware of the damage done to the dive-boat Coralita when it was side-swiped, while berthed, by the USS Berkeley in Cairns on 4 September 1988.
(2) Is the Minister aware that the owner of the Coralita is ineligible for compensation under the Status of Forces Agreement because his claim arose from the navigation of a vessel.

(3) Is it a fact that, under Article 12 (2) of the Agreement, the Australian Government can seek compensation from the United States (US) Government if an Australian Government vessel is damaged in the same circumstances as the Coralita.

(4) Is it a fact that, under Article 12 (3) of the Agreement, the Australian Government can settle a claim on the US Government's behalf if a privately-owned vessel chartered by the Australian Government is damaged in the same circumstances as the Coralita.

(5) Is it a fact that, under Article 12 (7) (a) of the Agreement, the Australian Government can settle a claim on the US Government's behalf if a privately-owned vessel is damaged by a US B-52 bomber which crashes while on a training flight.
(6) Why does the Agreement discriminate against the owners of the Coralita by not allowing them to seek damages from the Australian Government through Australian Courts.
(7) Will the Government be making an ex-gratia damages payment to the owners of the Coralita in recognition of this discrimination.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Richardson Sen The Hon G.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Defence has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) Yes.

(2) The United States/Australia Status of Forces Agreement contains special procedural provisions (paragraph 12 (7)) for handling claims arising out of the activities of US forces in Australia. These procedures do not apply to claims arising from the navigation of a vessel. A claimant's legal right to seek compensation, whether for a navigation claim or any other loss, is not affected by these procedural arrangements.
(3) No, assuming that the vessel is used by the Australian Defence Force.
(5) In the hypothetical situation referred to, paragraph 12 (7) of the US/Australia Status of Forces Agreement would enable the Australian Government to settle a claim.
(6) The US/Australia Status of Forces Agreement does not discriminate against the owners of the Coralita: their rights to take legal action (if they so choose) are unimpaired.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Brownhill Sen D.G.C.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy, upon notice, on 21 December 1988:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Has the Government approved the import of refined sugar in light of an industrial dispute disrupting supplies?
(2) Are supplies of Australian refined sugar held in Sydney in sufficient quantity to have made the import of sugar unnecessary?
(3) Does the import of sugar break the terms of the Sugar Agreement?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Cook Sen The Hon P.F.S.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Primary Industries and Energy has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) The embargo on the import of refined sugar into Melbourne was lifted temporarily from 20 December 1988 to 5 January 1989 to overcome shortages of refined sugar caused by an industrial dispute at CSR Ltd's Yarraville sugar refinery.
(2) Following consultation with CSR Ltd and industry it was assessed that there were insufficient supplies of refined sugar in Sydney to overcome the need to import sugar into Melbourne.

(3) The import of sugar under these circumstances does not break the Sugar Agreement. The embargo was suspended temporarily under clause 16 (2) (b) of the Sugar Agreement following consultation with the Queensland Government. This clause states that sugar and sugar products may be imported if ``after consultation with the State, the Commonwealth considers it necessary to meet any deficiency or shortage of sugar products in Australia''.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Baume Sen M.E.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Attorney-General, upon notice, on 21 December 1988:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Has the Attorney-General agreed to move, at a cost of millions of dollars, the central registry of the Family Court from Sydney to Melbourne following the appointment of a Melbourne-based Chief Judge of the Court? If so,
(a) why is this costly move taking place?
(b) how much will it cost? and
(c) why has it not been publicly announced?
(2) What consultations took place with the 42 employees of the central registry?
(3) What redundancy or other payments will be required to compensate for the loss of their jobs and the end of career opportunities?
(4) Is any industrial action now underway on this matter?
(5) Is it government practice to move such office functions whenever a new Chief Judge of the Court is appointed with a different domicile from the previous Chief Judge?
(6) Has the principal registry in Sydney recently moved into new premises? If so,
(a) what was the cost of that move?
(b) what lease or other arrangements exist? and
(c) what plans are there for re-allocating staff or facilities from the Principal registry in Sydney?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Tate Sen The Hon M.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Attorney-General has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) The Chief Justice has proposed relocation of part of the Principal Registry of the Family Court for the purpose of improving the administration of the Court. While no final decision has been taken, the Attorney-General is agreeable to such a move subject to the availability of funds, the development of a detailed proposal and consultation with staff and unions.

(a) The resignation of the Principal Registrar and anticipated resignation of the Deputy Principal Registrar and several other staff vacancies, together with the desire of the Chief Justice to restructure the Principal Registry with a view to strengthening its policy and administration areas, provided the opportunity to also consider its relocation.

(b) No accurate costing can be prepared until discussions with the Chief Justice concerning the preferred restructuring proposal are finalised, those elements of the Registry likely to relocate are identified and consultations with staff are completed.
(c) It would be premature to make any public announcement until interested parties have been fully consulted and a formal proposal is agreed.

(2) Staff of the Principal Registry were advised of the possible restructuring and re-location on 30 November 1988, the same day that agreement in principle was reached between me and the Chief Justice.

(3) The need for redundancy payments cannot be determined until the formal restructuring and relocation proposals are finalised and all staff affected by the proposals have been consulted. For example, it may be possible to redeploy staff who do not wish to move. However, should it become necessary to consider voluntary retrenchment for affected staff, the Commonwealth will, in accordance with the Australian Public Service Redeployment and Retirement (Redundancy) Award 1987, be liable for severance pay to the extent of 2 weeks salary for each completed year of Commonwealth service to a maximum of 48 weeks, payment in lieu of notice of up to 4 weeks salary and payment in lieu of accrued recreation and long service leave.

(4) Yes. All staff Associations with coverage of staff in the Principal Registry have resolved to place a ban on any matters relating to the proposed re-location. Notification of a dispute has also been lodged with the Australian Conciliation and Arbitration Commission.
(6) Yes. The lease at the previous premises, La Salle Building had expired.

(a) The cost of relocating the Principal Registry from La Salle Building to HCF House was $21,500 of which $8,000 was removal costs and $13,500 was for minor re-partitioning and upgrading of security.

(b) The Commonwealth had a current lease in respect of the HCF premises which were previously occupied by the Constitutional Commission. The lease has subsequently been renewed for a further three years from 11 February 1989.
(c) These matters are under consideration-see answer to question (1).

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Crichton-Browne Sen N.A.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Industry, Technology and Commerce, upon notice, on 28 February 1989:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Is the Minister aware that for a person to register a change of address under the Patents Act necessitates the payment of a fee of $35.
(2) Is the Minister also aware that, as stated at the bottom of Patents Act Form 31, the fee for such a task was previously $2.

(3) How can a fee increase of $33 be justified to carry out a minor task which most private businesses regard as a normal cost of conducting that business and for which they charge no fee at all, particularly if, assuming a labour rate of $12 an hour, the job of changing the address on the register equates to about three hours work.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Button Sen The Hon J.N.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable senator's question is as follows:

(2) The fee for such a request was $2 from 1957 to 1974, then $3 until 1979. Copies of Form 31, printed in 1970, were available until recently from the Perth Sub-Office of the Patent Office.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Colston Sen M.A.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Defence Science and Personnel, upon notice, on 28 February 1989:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Do Defence Force establishments provide advice to personnel concerning their rights and obligations to vote.
(2) What procedures are followed to enable Defence Force personnel, including newly enrolled Recruits, to vote in Federal elections and Referenda.
(3) What procedures were followed at the Naval Defence Force establishment, HMAS Cerberus, to enable newly enrolled Recruits to vote in the 1988 Federal Referenda.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Richardson Sen The Hon G.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Defence Science and Personnel has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) On the occasion of an election or referendum Navy and Air Force advise personnel of their voting rights and obligations. Army does not provide advice to personnel on their rights or obligations to vote. Army considers that promotional material provided by the Government is available to soldiers as it is to the rest of the community.

(2) When Navy is advised of a forthcoming election or referendum the information is promulgated from Navy Office Canberra by signal and facsimile to every ship, establishment and overseas location where members of the RAN are serving. All ships and establishments have a designated ``electoral officer'' who has the responsibility of ensuring that personnel are aware of the forthcoming election or referendum, of the requirement to vote and of arrangements made for lodging of votes.

Air Force establishments advise personnel periodically of their voting rights and obligations through the medium of Unit of Formation Routine orders. Air Force members, both in Australia and overseas, are advised of forthcoming elections and referenda and are reminded of their rights and obligations including postal and overseas voting procedures. A Returning Officer is usually established at Butterworth, Malaysia. Where voting facilities are not established at RAAF bases members may be conveyed to the appropriate polling facility by RAAF transport.

Army notifies all units of forthcoming Federal and State elections, by-elections and referenda. Because many soldiers are not located where they are registered to vote a specific effort is made to notify all members in sufficient time to ensure members can attend voting booths or apply for postal votes. Particular arrangements are made by units for those members on field training or on duty on election days. No member is denied their right to vote.

(3) HMAS Cerberus received a facsimile pertaining to the 3 September 1988 election on 3 August 1988. This information was promulgated in HMAS Cerberus Daily Orders and on notice boards. On 3 September 1988 a bus was provided for all Cerberus personnel, including newly appointed recruits, to go to Crib Point, the nearest polling facility. Further, it is standard routine for all personnel when joining HMAS Cerberus, including new recruits, to be given a form to change their electoral details.
