QUESTION.SPEAKER: McLean Sen P.A.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Industry, Technology and Commerce, upon notice, on 28 February 1989:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Is the Minister aware that the Service Station Association of New South Wales has a 20 per cent turnover of membership per annum, and that most of the 360 members who drop out each year do so due to economic difficulty.

(2) Is the Minister aware that a high rate of business failure in the petrol retailing industry is due to facts which are beyond the control of the owners of individual businesses, because they stem directly from practices of the oil industry.

(3) Is it correct that Ampol now holds a controlling interest in Solo, if so, is Solo now subject to the provisions of the Petroleum Retail Marketing Franchise Act 1980 and the Petroleum Retail Marketing Sites Act 1980.

(4) Is Coro Pty Ltd a splinter company of a major oil company; if so, do the Petroleum Retail Marketing Franchise Act 1980 and the Petroleum Retail Marketing Sites Act 1980 as amended, cover the operation of splinter companies such as Coro Pty Ltd.

(5) Is the Government aware of moves by oil companies to proceed with multiple franchising of one service station business, so that there is a franchise for petrol, a franchise for retailing, a franchise for the workshop, etc; if so, does the Government intend to allow oil companies to proceed with this action.
(6) What percentage of retailing and service business in petrol retailers is now conducted under franchising arrangements.
(7) What protection is available to the franchisee.

(8) Does the Government consider that current federal legislation provides sufficient protection for the franchisee; if not, will the Government introduce legislation specifically to protect this vital section of our economy.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Button Sen The Hon J.N.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable senator's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) and (2) While membership turnover of the Service Station Association of New South Wales is, in itself, not a reliable indicator to the health of that sector, I would point out that for some years service station operators have been facing increased competition, due to the relatively static demand for petrol combined with an excess number of outlets servicing the market. In fact, despite the relatively high failure rate for new small businesses in Australia (Professor Williams of Newcastle University suggests that 40 per cent fail within 3 years and around 66 per cent within 5 years), it could be argued that the detailed screening undertaken by the oil companies tends to discourage persons of insufficient business acumen from adding to the list of failures. There is no evidence to support the claim that oil company practices, per se, have been a direct cause of business failure in the service station industry. Nevertheless, as I have previously indicated, I am prepared to consider intervention where there is evidence of harsh or unconscionable conduct by an oil company towards its franchisees.

(3) I am advised that, in October 1988, Ampol purchased a minority shareholding in Solo Oil Limited and that the latter continues to trade as an independent, non-integrated marketer. Consequently, Solo sites are currently exempt from the application of the Petroleum Retail Marketing Sites Act 1980 (and, for all practical purposes, the Petroleum Retail Marketing Franchise Act 1980) until such time as Ampol should acquire a majority shareholding or that Solo otherwise assumes the characteristics of a prescribed oil company (ie. it either refines or imports the bulk of its petrol requirements).

(4) I am informed that Coro Pty Ltd is a wholly-owned subsidiary of BP Australia Limited, established for the purpose of permitting company operation of selected sites. As the legislation applies to all subsidiaries of prescribed corporations, eligible Coro outlets are deemed to be part of the BP quota under the Petroleum Retail Marketing Sites Act 1980.

(5) I understand that the move towards multiple franchising by some oil companies is an innovation aimed at establishing uniformity of site presentation and service standards (a ``true franchise''), as well as enabling franchisors to place a realistic valuation on the contribution made by individual activities to the overall value of the marketing premises. While the ``petrol franchisee'' is normally offered the first option on ancillary activities, the taking up of such options is ultimately a matter for commercial judgment by the dealer concerned.

(6) I am not aware of any official statistics relating to this question. However, my Department has made a broad assessment of the significance of franchised sites compared with other classes of resellers. This indicates that oil company-owned or leased franchised outlets account for around 45 per cent of retail sites and 66 per cent of retail sales of petrol.

(7) The principal source of protection for service station franchisees is the Petroleum Retail Marketing Franchise Act 1980. Briefly, the Act confers certain basic rights on franchisees in relation to, inter alia, the right to prior disclosure, security of tenure, grounds for termination, prohibition of price discrimination, etc. It is enforceable by private action only.

(8) At this time, yes. I would further point out that the Petroleum Retail Marketing Franchise Act 1980 and Petroleum Retail Marketing Sites Act 1980 are currently the only pieces of Commonwealth legislation of their type. However, the Trade Practices Commission, in consultation with my Department, is currently facilitating the development of a code of conduct for the different business interests in the market that complements and supports the legislation. The Commission is also looking to establish guidelines on price discrimination. I support these initiatives which I understand are designed to ensure that a fair and competitive trading environment prevails. Clearly, if the current level of industry support for the Commission's initiatives is any indication then, in the longer term, the legislation could become redundant.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Button Sen The Hon J.N.

TALK.START.PARA: —On 21 December 1988 (Hansard, page 4768) Senator Newman asked me a question without notice relating to quality aspects of the manufacture of the new Steyr rifle at the Small Arms Factory, Lithgow, and the cost of 5.56 mm ammunition from the Ammunition Factory, Footscray. The answer to the honourable senator's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: On 12 August 1988 the Minister for Defence announced the formation of Australian Defence Industries Pty Ltd. This new company, wholly owned by the Commonwealth will take over the activities of the Office of Defence Production which currently runs Garden Island Dockyard and the various ammunition, ordinance, engineering, small arms and clothing factories. The move is planned for March 1989. The term `privatisation' is not a correct description of this initiative. The Prime Minister has stated that the company will remain Government-owned.

The quality control system in force at the Small Arms Factory Lithgow is adequate and was reassessed by the Army to be so in December 1988. Both the Army Quality Assurance Service and the Small Arms Factory have taken every necessary measure in recent months to ensure that there was no compromise in quality during the initial production phase of the Steyr rifle, albeit at the expense of some minor delays. It should be noted that the quality problems encountered thus far with SAF were neither insurmountable nor uncharacteristic of an initial production phase for military equipment where the QC standards are high.

The initial production quantity of the locally produced rifles was delivered in November 1988 for further Army test and evaluation. Prior to this delivery, during part of the initial production process, one bolt sub-assembly which was under endurance testing at the time did fracture in the area of the control pin which connects the bolt to the rest of the weapon assembly. This problem was found to be due to interpretation difficulties with the process data included in the Technical Data Package supplied under the terms of the licence agreement. The problem was corrected and has not recurred even under comprehensive testing. This problem should not be considered as unusual during an initial production phase.

Production of SS109 NATO 5.56 mm ball ammunition has commenced at the Ammunition Factory Footscray. Manufacturing tolerances and quality standards for this product are extremely high and some difficulties have been experienced in consistently meeting these standards. It would be wrong to assume that similar difficulties would not be experienced by the private sector and overseas manufacturers when attempting to produce the round for the first time. As a result of delays due to these difficulties, the Army initially ordered relatively small quantities of ammunition from Fabrique Nationale of Belgium, to ensure that ammunition was available to meet deliveries of production rifles. The decision to purchase initial supplies from an overseas supplier was not based on costs. It was purely a matter of assuring availability.
Senator Crichton-Browne's supplementary question on the Ordinance Factory Bendigo does not provide sufficient detail to enable a response to be made.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Macklin Sen M.J.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Macklin Sen M.J.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Defence, upon notice, on 20 December 1988:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Are the Australian Government's security and visiting procedures for the Australian-United States of America (USA) facilities at Pine Gap, Nurrungar and North West Cape such that the Government is aware of whether or not prominent foreign nationals visit these facilities; if so, what were the names of US Congressmen who have visited the aforementioned facilities since March 1983 and when and which facilities did they visit.
(2) Did the Congressmen conduct a classified or an unclassified visit to the facilities.

(3) How can it be that the Government is aware of the names and dates of visits by Congressional committee staff to the facilities (see answer to question No. 650, Senate Hansard, 14 December 1988, page 4232), but does not even know whether the Chairman of the US Senate Intelligence Committee has visited the facilities.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Richardson Sen The Hon G.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Defence has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) and (2) Procedures for US visits to the joint facilities are outlined in the answer to Senate Question No. 747. Records available do not indicate any visits by US Congressmen to the joint facilities since March 1983. Thus the issue of classified or unclassified visits does not arise.

(3) Records available do not indicate any visit to the joint defence facilities since March 1983 by a Chairman of the US Senate Intelligence Committee. However, in February 1986 US Senator David Boren, then and now the Chairman of the Senate Select Committee on Intelligence, visited Australia. The Government understands this visit was not in his capacity as Chairman but as a senior Democrat, and further understands that while Senator Boren was in Alice Springs he did receive an unclassified brief on the impact on the local community of the US presence and on conditions for US personnel.
